description: Would it make sense to have a (the?) project's "Version" menu on its popup in a  stream (in the repo explorer)?   NOTES:  Jean-Michel (22/03/2001 8:29:49 AM)  "Tagging affects the repository, not the working copy. That begs  the question: Why require a working copy at all when tagging? The only purpose that it serves is to designate which project and which revisions of the various files in the project are being tagged. If you could  specify the project and revisions independently of the working copy,  no working copy would be necessary. " from CVS manual.  CVS can tag (take workspace revisions and tag then in the repo) and  rtag (no workspace required, take repo revisions and tag. This command is mostly always used when branching 'cvs rtag -b -r version1 version1_bugfix'  so you don't tag the team stream but ). Currently we version using  rtag just because rtag records a tag event in the history and allows  us to query for existing tags. But using rtag on the team stream (HEAD) is  dangerous because you don't really know what you are tagging.  Notes: - in our cvs adapter we must use tag where we currently use rtag. - to find the versions created with tag in the repo the only thing to do (as  recommended by the CVS docs):   "Until then, there are workarounds. You can run cvs log -h and read the  sections of the output following the header symbolic names:."  but how do we chose which file to look into, it could be a file that has just  been added to the repo? - we must allow the user to enter his own tag name where ever he can select a  version. - we could use rtag internally when branching (creating a new team stream)  based on a version.  BB (26/03/2001 10:31:40 AM) 	I think we should provide two operations: Create a project version from  a team stream, 	and create a project version from the workspace. The API has both  operations: 	ISharingManager.createProjectVersion() 	ITeamStream.createProjectVersion() 	The first one should be on the context menu for projects in the  navigator, the second one 	on the context menu for projects in team streams (repository explorer). 	CVS has both operations too.  from Jean-Michel's comment: "- in our cvs adapter we must use tag where we  currently use rtag." 	I disagree. I think we need both because CVS provides both too.  KM (3/26/01 2:23:40 PM) 	Supporting both makes for a very confusing user model.  Versioning from  the workspace is closer 	to VAJ and is arguably better since you have a fixed state that you are  versioning 	(as opposed to trying to version a non-locking changing stream).  KM (4/4/01 4:36:51 PM) 	Decision is to support both.  Versioning stream is helpful for  baselining before releasing. 	Must make the distinction clear in the UI.  As a bonus, informing the  user that he his 	workspace differs from the stream when versioning the stream may be  helpful.  JohnA (4/6/01 5:20:27 PM) 	Added team stream versioning to the UI.  Moving the PR to active so we  don't 	loose Mark's useful comments above.

description: DW (6/7/01 9:27:33 AM) 	119++   	When doing an eval in the scrapbook/debugger, the package "org.eclipse.jdt.internal.eval.target" 	appears in the workspace, which is the home of "CodeSnippet".  	We do not clean-up (remove) this package when the target termiantes.  DW (6/7/01 2:09:06 PM) 	Simple fix would be to have the snippet support change the "CodeSnippet" class to 	be in the default package.  	There is a nasty side effect here. When a project uses the defualt source and binary 	folder config (i.e. project is the root), a new package appears when a evaluation is done. 	This package will also show up when releasing to a repository. This problem does not 	surface in the self hosting world because the package is hidden in the output 	directory.  	Another potential fix is to have the debugger delete the package - but that should only 	be done if the package is empty.  	Propose fix in JCORE.  DW (6/8/01 8:54:09 AM) 	Make into a README.  DW (6/15/01 10:08:55 AM) 	Added to README.

We do not clean-up (remove) this package when the target termiantes.  DW (6/7/01 2:09:06 PM) 	Simple fix would be to have the snippet support change the "CodeSnippet" class to 	be in the default package.  	There is a nasty side effect here. This package will also show up when releasing to a repository. This problem does not 	surface in the self hosting world because the package is hidden in the output 	directory.  	Another potential fix is to have the debugger delete the package - but that should only 	be done if the package is empty.  	Propose fix in JCORE.  DW (6/8/01 8:54:09 AM) 	Make into a README. description: 1. Debug a program or two and let them terminated. Keep the 	old launches in the debug view. 2. Debug a program to a breakpoint such that the stack frame will have 	a few variables to display in the variables view. 3. With the suspended stack frame selected, and variables showing in the 	variables view, select "Remove all terminated" from the debug view. 4. Note that the suspended stack frame is properly selected after the 	old launches are removed, but the variables view is empty.  The user must manually reselect the stack frame to force the variables view to update.  NOTES:
my_mothod: 1. Debug a program or two and let them terminated. Keep the 	old launches in the debug view. 2. Debug a program to a breakpoint such that the stack frame will have 	a few variables to display in the variables view. 3. With the suspended stack frame selected, and variables showing in the 	variables view, select "Remove all terminated" from the debug view. 4. Note that the suspended stack frame is properly selected after the 	old launches are removed, but the variables view is empty.  The user must manually reselect the stack frame to force the variables view to update.  NOTES: Variables view stays empty with stack frame selected (1GLE8PW) critical Debug JDT

description: Can the Eclipse provide a preference that allows the user to control whether to persist the open/close states of the resources/files from the last session?  That is, if a couple of files were opened when the Eclipse was closed, the user can choose to restart the Eclipse (1) with a "clean" desktop (all the files are closed) or (2) with all the files previously opened automatically reopened in the new session (the current Eclipse behavior).  A user can choose option (1) to cut down a lot of time on closing the files before shutdown or Eclipse's automactically reopening the files during startup.  This would make it easier for the users who have large files (e.g. Rose models) to use them in the way they like.  NOTES:
my_mothod: Can the Eclipse provide a preference that allows the user to control whether to persist the open/close states of the resources/files from the last session?  That is, if a couple of files were opened when the Eclipse was closed, the user can choose to restart the Eclipse (1) with a "clean" desktop (all the files are closed) or (2) with all the files previously opened automatically reopened in the new session (the current Eclipse behavior).  A user can choose option (1) to cut down a lot of time on closing the files before shutdown or Eclipse's automactically reopening the files during startup.  This would make it easier for the users who have large files (e.g. Rose models) to use them in the way they like.  NOTES: [Prefereces] preference to restart in fresh state (1G7HZJA) enhancement UI Platform

description: 1) install the UI examples 2) create a project 3) create a file file.people the icon is a 'E' 4) go to Window->Preferences->Workbench->File Editor and change the default editor for .people 5) Apply The icon has not changed in the navigator   NOTES:  KH (9/10/2001 3:53:03 PM) 	See also: 1GC2VOL: ITPUI:WIN2000 - Icons in navigator not updated on default editor change
my_mothod: 1) install the UI examples 2) create a project 3) create a file file.people the icon is a 'E' 4) go to Window->Preferences->Workbench->File Editor and change the default editor for .people 5) Apply The icon has not changed in the navigator   NOTES:  KH (9/10/2001 3:53:03 PM) 	See also: 1GC2VOL: ITPUI:WIN2000 - Icons in navigator not updated on default editor change [Navigator] Changing the default editor does not refresh the navigator (1GEX9PY) minor UI Platform

description: - new file B.txt - change B.txt in the filesystem - open B.txt in Eclipse - it gives an error dialog: "Problems Opening Editor" / "File has changed since  last synchronization".  A: This case will happen often B: What is synchronization?  We don't use that term in the UI anymore. C: It doesn't show how to rectify the situation.  How is a novice user supposed  to know to do a refresh local? D: It's not necessary.  There's only one content which can be seen in the  editor.  It could just do a refresh for you and open it.  NOTES:  NE (5/25/01 1:25:37 PM)  	Are there any disadvantages to just doing a refresh?  Need to check  with a Core person.  DS (5/29/01 8:43:27 PM) 	I will write an operation to do a refresh ( with user confirmation ) if  the resource has 	changed.  This operation can be reused throughout desktop in open  editor, copy, move, 	delete, etc.  	Out of sync states to deal with = modify, delete  DS (5/29/01 9:24:37 PM) 	According to Rodrigo there is no way to see if a file is out of sync.   Perhaps it would 	involve doing everything a localRefresh does, but without doing the  localRefresh.  KH (5/30/2001 2:50:50 PM) 	Local refresh will cause builders to run. We should NOT do this for  free.
my_mothod: - new file B.txt - change B.txt in the filesystem - open B.txt in Eclipse - it gives an error dialog: "Problems Opening Editor" / "File has changed since  last synchronization".  A: This case will happen often B: What is synchronization?  We don't use that term in the UI anymore. C: It doesn't show how to rectify the situation.  How is a novice user supposed  to know to do a refresh local? D: It's not necessary.  There's only one content which can be seen in the  editor.  It could just do a refresh for you and open it.  NOTES:  NE (5/25/01 1:25:37 PM)  	Are there any disadvantages to just doing a refresh?  Need to check  with a Core person.  DS (5/29/01 8:43:27 PM) 	I will write an operation to do a refresh ( with user confirmation ) if  the resource has 	changed.  This operation can be reused throughout desktop in open  editor, copy, move, 	delete, etc.  	Out of sync states to deal with = modify, delete  DS (5/29/01 9:24:37 PM) 	According to Rodrigo there is no way to see if a file is out of sync.   Perhaps it would 	involve doing everything a localRefresh does, but without doing the  localRefresh.  KH (5/30/2001 2:50:50 PM) 	Local refresh will cause builders to run. We should NOT do this for  free. SEVERE: UI is difficult when trying to open an out-of-synch file (1GEAL61) normal Resources Platform

description: - new file B.txt - modify it in the editor, but don't save - change B.txt in the filesystem - save B.txt in Eclipse - it gives an error dialog: "Save problems" / "Internal Error: Reason: File has  changed since last synchronization."  A: This case will happen often B: What is synchronization?  We don't use that term in the UI anymore. C: It doesn't show how to rectify the situation.  How is a novice user supposed  to know to do a refresh local? D: It's not an internal error.  Eclipse didn't fail (it is, however, failing to  meet the user's expectations.) E: It throws away the changes made in Eclipse!  This is really bad, as it loses  the user's work.    It should notify that the file has changed since it was opened, and offer to: 	1 - save anyway, overwriting other changes 	2 - abandon changes made in editor 	3 - compare differences and merge  For 1 and 2, it should not really lose the other contents, but put them in the  recycle bin or local history so they can be recovered later if the user makes the wrong choice here, or  needs them later.   NOTES:  NE (5/25/01 1:35:04 PM)	 	Similar behaviour if file has been deleted in filesystem. 	The editor contents are lost. 	In this case, it should just save the editor contents.
my_mothod: - new file B.txt - modify it in the editor, but don't save - change B.txt in the filesystem - save B.txt in Eclipse - it gives an error dialog: "Save problems" / "Internal Error: Reason: File has  changed since last synchronization."  A: This case will happen often B: What is synchronization?  We don't use that term in the UI anymore. C: It doesn't show how to rectify the situation.  How is a novice user supposed  to know to do a refresh local? D: It's not an internal error.  Eclipse didn't fail (it is, however, failing to  meet the user's expectations.) E: It throws away the changes made in Eclipse!  This is really bad, as it loses  the user's work.    It should notify that the file has changed since it was opened, and offer to: 	1 - save anyway, overwriting other changes 	2 - abandon changes made in editor 	3 - compare differences and merge  For 1 and 2, it should not really lose the other contents, but put them in the  recycle bin or local history so they can be recovered later if the user makes the wrong choice here, or  needs them later.   NOTES:  NE (5/25/01 1:35:04 PM)	 	Similar behaviour if file has been deleted in filesystem. 	The editor contents are lost. 	In this case, it should just save the editor contents. SEVERE: UI is difficult when trying to save an out-of-synch file (1GEALEF) normal Resources Platform

description: Currently, there is no way to perform a full save of the workspace without exiting and restarting, which can take a while. I would like a menu option allowing to perform a full save action when I feel it necessary. Then I can zip the corresponding folder manually. Ideally a save-as would be even better.  NOTES:
my_mothod: Currently, there is no way to perform a full save of the workspace without exiting and restarting, which can take a while. I would like a menu option allowing to perform a full save action when I feel it necessary. Then I can zip the corresponding folder manually. Ideally a save-as would be even better.  NOTES: [Workbench] Would like to be able to save workspace without exiting (1GEUMKI) enhancement UI Platform

description: During a "New" wizard, if an SWTError is thrown while building a wizard page, the error is not handled, and the IDE process terminates abnormally (i.e. no proper shutdown allowing edit sessions to save).  This will cause data loss and perceived instability in the IDE.  The problem is likely going to happen with any runtime exception, but I've only seen it with SWTError.  In particular, an SWTError was thrown under Linux when Combo.setItems(list) was called where list[0] == null.  This doesn't cause an SWTError in Windows.  To reproduce this, take any New wizard (eg new Java Project). In the  createControl() method that builds the wizard page content as called by  Wizard.createPageControls, manually throw an SWTError (throw new SWTError("oops");).   This is just to simulate an actual SWTError that might be thrown for a variety of  legitimate reasons such as low system resources.  With that throw in place, run the  IDE and attempt to create the new object.  When you click Next from the first wizard page, and it attempts to build the page we modified createControl for, the IDE will simply shut down.  I expected that the error would be caught, and the current operation (creating a new Java Project for example) would fail and info written to .log.  Here is the stack trace that was dumped to stdout in my case: org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: Item not added 	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:1724) 	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:1741) 	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.notifyListeners(Widget.java:505) 	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java(Compiled Code)) 	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.notifyListeners(Widget.java:505) 	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java(Compiled Code)) 	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java(Compiled Code)) 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java(Compiled Code)) 	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:401)  For additional info, contact Steve Francisco (cisco@ca.ibm.com)  NOTES:  KH (9/20/2001 9:27:41 AM) 	Customer will fix their code. The request is to be more robust when errors happen.

description: Menu entries for refactoring inconsistent: 	Sometimes we have: 		Rename 		Refactoring 	and sometimes we have 		Refactoring --> Rename  	Should be consistent.   NOTES:  The original idea was to have all refactorings inside a sub menu. But when introducing rename refactorings for the packages view we changed this strategy since the packages views shows heterogeneous resources (java, gif, properties) and a user wants to move, rename, copy those resources too. For non Java resources it doesn't make sense to have a menu entry Refactor->Rename. Additionally there are some actions which are supposed to be refactorings but aren't (for example Generate Setters and Getters). Those actions don't show up in the refactoring sub menu either. I opt to do the following:  	- we still keep the Refactor sub menu. 	- refactorings like Rename, Copy, Move are present in the main context menu. The don't show up in the sub menu. This is constent with 	  the navigator and the Windows Explorer. 	- Undo / Redo goes into the main menu too. 	- current actions which are supposed to be refactorings are implemented as refactorings and go into the Refactor submenu.  EG and AK please comment.
my_mothod: Menu entries for refactoring inconsistent: 	Sometimes we have: 		Rename 		Refactoring 	and sometimes we have 		Refactoring --> Rename  	Should be consistent. For non Java resources it doesn't make sense to have a menu entry Refactor->Rename. EG and AK please comment. Menu entries for refactoring inconsistent (1GF5RHZ) critical UI JDT

description: If I accept the free move when I change the package declaration of a CU,  it does several builds: 	first: in response to initial save, which has already modified the workspace 	second: due to creating new folder for package 	third: when source is moved  Instead, it should check whether the package has changed first, before modifying the workspace.   (Not sure if it does currently, but it should not have to depend on built state, or even whether auto-build is on or not). Then it should do all work inside an IWorkspace.run(). There should only be one workspace modification (perhaps containing several nested ones) for any save.   NOTES:  TM (26.07.2001 09:56:52) 	We're now doing the smart rename within the save operation (so we only get one build). 	However, there are issues with the editor not updating correctly.
my_mothod: If I accept the free move when I change the package declaration of a CU,  it does several builds: 	first: in response to initial save, which has already modified the workspace 	second: due to creating new folder for package 	third: when source is moved  Instead, it should check whether the package has changed first, before modifying the workspace.   (Not sure if it does currently, but it should not have to depend on built state, or even whether auto-build is on or not). Then it should do all work inside an IWorkspace.run(). There should only be one workspace modification (perhaps containing several nested ones) for any save.   NOTES:  TM (26.07.2001 09:56:52) 	We're now doing the smart rename within the save operation (so we only get one build). 	However, there are issues with the editor not updating correctly. Auto-move causes too many builds (1GCV109) critical UI JDT

description: The syntax colouring does not handle the keyword "goto".  See 1GCTDYM: ITPJCORE:WIN2000 - Error message is confusing: using token instead of identifier  NOTES: AK (4/27/01 11:11:01 AM) 	please note that 'goto' and 'const' are reserved keywords and as such are never used in syntactically correct java programs. 	coloring them is then more a question of consistency than of anything else.  KUM (8/3/2001 4:30:10 PM) 	Fixed. Added keywords: const, goto, strictfp

description: 0. Switch to packages view 	1. Create Java project JUnit 	2. Import junit.jar and junitsrc.jar 	3. Add junit.jar to JUnit classpath 	4. Create Java project JUnit2 	5. Leave JUnit2 expanded and ensure JUnit is collapsed 	5. Add junit.jar of Junit to classpath of Junit2 	6. In the packages view delete the junit.jar which is inside JUnit2   	The JAR remains in the package view (appears with the ghost icon (red square)). 	More severe is that the JAR is not only removed from the classpath of JUnit2 but 	also at its original location. This makes the project that actually contains the project 	unusable and also all other projects that had the JAR on the classpath.  	Now open the build path properties for JUnit2 ==> Error dialog: will set to default 																							Reason: CoreException error in opening zip file  		==> this dialog should show which zip file caused the problem.  	When I used the source self hosting setup it was even worse: the project that 	had such a JAR on their classpath could no longer be opened (i.e. they did not 	expand when pressing the +).	   NOTES:  JBL (5/4/2001 6:57:08 PM) 	There are 2 problems here: 	1. The jar is physically deleted: this is done by the UI which calls DeleteSupport.delete(...) 	2. A Java element delta is not triggered for JUnit2: this is a bug in the Java model.  JBL (5/7/2001 3:01:07 PM) 	Now report a java element delta for JUnit2 as well (in SDK > 103a) 	Moving to ITPJUI for consideration of first problem (ie. should the jar be physically removed when it doesn't belong to the project 	it appears in)  EG (5/8/2001 11:31:21 AM) 	we need to be smarter, when a JAR is still referenced on some build path we shouldn't remove 	it and tell the user in which project it is still referenced from.  TM (5/9/2001 13:06:08) 	We can't protect the user from this completely anyway (he can always do this in the resources  	view). I propose that we just remove the classpath entry if the jar is not in the project itself.  EG (5/9/01 2:08:27 PM) 	OK solution  TM (5/9/2001 17:15:21) 	No, we just should disallow the delete. If you want to remove a classpath entry, you do it via 	the classpath page.  TM (5/9/2001 17:30:17) 	The handling in the java model or packages view is not correct:  	1) create two java projects 	2) import junit.jar into one of them 	3) add the jar to the build path in both projects 	4) delete the jar in the project it has been imported to  	5) observe: you get the red icons in both projects. 		you can still expand the jar in the project where it was only on the classpath.  TM (5/9/2001 17:33:20) 	closing and reopening the packages view fixes the problem.  DM (5/10/01 12:21:35 PM) 	Please also see/consider 1GD3E9F: ITPJUI:WINNT - Removing JAR from packages view does not work  TM (5/10/2001 14:51:22) 	The problem here is that the tree viewer can't handle the fact that the same element is shown 	twice (we don't control equals). Known problem.  EG (5/15/01 10:58:35 AM) 	Will be addressed by wrappering the package fragment root so that the wrapper changes the 	equal condition.  EG (24.07.2001 22:24:22) 	the wrappering wasn't put in since the problem seems to have vanished.

description: AK (5/8/01 7:00:46 PM) 	i keep .java files as resources and want to put them in a resource folder - it's not possible  NOTES:  DB (10.05.2001 10:19:09) 	I tried to move / copy *.java files in resource folders via drag and drop and this is possible.  	Moving *.java from a source folder / package to resource folder is not possible. But this has nothing to do 	with DnD. It is a smart reorg problem.  TM (5/23/2001 15:52:48) 	This is intentional (which doesn't mean it's the right behaviour). Only package fragments are 	considered valid copy/move targets. 	The reason for this is that we use ISourceManipulation (a java model interface) for moving  	java compilation units (and it accepts only IJavaElements as move/copy targets). 	There are is another problem with this: When you move a java file (say Foo.java) from outside 	the build path into a package, the package declaration is not updated, because we're doing a  	regular resource move. 	while we can fix the original PR with a (major) fix to the reorg code, the second problem 	can't be adressed with the current API's.  EG (5/25/01 7:31:08 PM) 	defer, readme  AK (9/17/2001 5:12:07 PM) 	fixed in 201
my_mothod: AK (5/8/01 7:00:46 PM) 	i keep .java files as resources and want to put them in a resource folder - it's not possible  NOTES:  DB (10.05.2001 10:19:09) 	I tried to move / copy *.java files in resource folders via drag and drop and this is possible.  	Moving *.java from a source folder / package to resource folder is not possible. But this has nothing to do 	with DnD. It is a smart reorg problem. The reason for this is that we use ISourceManipulation (a java model interface) for moving  	java compilation units (and it accepts only IJavaElements as move/copy targets). 	There are is another problem with this: When you move a java file (say Foo.java) from outside 	the build path into a package, the package declaration is not updated, because we're doing a  	regular resource move. 	while we can fix the original PR with a (major) fix to the reorg code, the second problem 	can't be adressed with the current API's.  EG (5/25/01 7:31:08 PM) 	defer, readme  AK (9/17/2001 5:12:07 PM) 	fixed in 201 drag'n'drop - cannot dnd a file from a package to a resource folder (1GDF2T8) critical UI JDT

description: There may be a better way to reproduce this, but this is how I got it. 	1) I have the SWT code in my workspace - it has code for multiple platforms which we implemented using folders. 	2) While working on Windows, with my .classpath containing the "win32" folder, I made a change to a "motif" resource (Program.java), and saved it. 	3) I got a dialog saying: 		'Move compilation unit to "org.eclipse.swt.program - Eclipse SWT Program/win32 - /org.eclipse.swt.program/Eclipse SWT Program/win32"?'  	I am not really certain if the named place is correct - it seems a bit long? 	But what I am really complaining about here is that there is no "Cancel" button. 	I must choose between "Yes" or "No", and I really want to just cancel the whole thing. (i.e. oops, I'm sorry, I didn't mean it, please just let me quit).  	I believe this dialog should be Yes/No/Cancel.  NOTES:
my_mothod: There may be a better way to reproduce this, but this is how I got it. 	1) I have the SWT code in my workspace - it has code for multiple platforms which we implemented using folders. 	2) While working on Windows, with my .classpath containing the "win32" folder, I made a change to a "motif" resource (Program.java), and saved it. 	3) I got a dialog saying: 		'Move compilation unit to "org.eclipse.swt.program - Eclipse SWT Program/win32 - /org.eclipse.swt.program/Eclipse SWT Program/win32"?'  	I am not really certain if the named place is correct - it seems a bit long? 	But what I am really complaining about here is that there is no "Cancel" button. 	I must choose between "Yes" or "No", and I really want to just cancel the whole thing. (i.e. oops, I'm sorry, I didn't mean it, please just let me quit).  	I believe this dialog should be Yes/No/Cancel.  NOTES: Missing Cancel button on "Move Compilation Unit?" dialog (1GDSCT6) critical UI JDT

description: jkca (5/15/2001 11:04:56 AM) 	jre-sdk 106  Under certain circumstances code assist eats too much code. Consider the enclosed class.  As a programmer, I must add a  parameter to the baz call in bar to make the program correct.    Steps: 1. Change the baz call to 	baz(x.x.foo()) 2. Place the cursor after the first "x." 3. Ctrl-Space to bring up code assist 4. Type "f" to filter the list. 5. Select, "foo()" 6. The code is changed to: 	baz(x.foo().foo())  I would rather it gave me 	baz(x.foo()x.foo())  public class X {  	void bar(X x) { 		baz(x.foo()); 	} 	 	int foo() { 		return 5; 	} 	 	void baz(int i, int j) { 	} }  KUM (5/21/01 9:02:11 AM) 	The text to replace is computed by the code assist infrastructure. 	Moved to ITPJCORE.  PM (9/4/2001 2:58:56 PM) 	Option was added.  PM (9/25/2001 2:20:50 PM) 	Removing option. UI can decide whether it wants to use the codeassist end position (until the end of current identifier) or the cursor location it used to start with, so as to control 	the amount of source to replace. The choice amongst one or the other should be conditioned by a keystroke (enter=replace until end, insert=replace until cursor location).  	Moving to ITPJUI. Removing codeassist option.

description: When I drag a file from one project to another and drop it on the destination project itself (project name highlighted) the file I am dragging ends up in the top level of the source folder for that project.  I would expect the file to go into the top level of the project just like in the navigator.  NOTES: EG (5/28/01 9:34:17 PM) 	Reorg problem. Similar test case: 	1) select the the doc folder in org.eclipse.ui 	2) try to copy it to org.eclipse.jdt.ui   TM (5/30/01 6:46:06 PM) 	Check why we're copying to the source folder.  TM (5/31/2001 17:53:15) 	The resource reorg strategy was using the same policy for finding it's "real" target as the  	compilation unit reorg strategy.  TM (5/31/2001 19:53:19) 	fixed for the resource case (the doc folder) 	EG&TM: Will not do the case where we copy java elements to resource containers (i.e. copy 	compilation unit); we should revisit the architecture post-june.  	Moving to inactive.  PA (6/1/01 7:18:37 PM) 	can verify the first. > 116.2 	moving to inactive.  AK (9/17/2001 5:12:56 PM) 	fixed in 201

description: I'd like a hierarchy view without the method in list.    1. In many situations I am curious about a hierarchy, but the methods within a hierarchy provide little information until I actually open up an editor and look at the methods + comments.  At that point the outline + editor do the complete job and are more familiar.  2. The two panes within the hierarchy view are always difficult to layout within a window.   Especially because they force a vertical layout, and may times I want a horizontal layout.    Perhaps the functionality within the method list could just be moved to the outline?  NOTES: EG (5/24/2001 7:16:55 AM) 	what kind of horizontal layout do you have in mind. Can you send me a screen shot?
my_mothod: I'd like a hierarchy view without the method in list.    1. In many situations I am curious about a hierarchy, but the methods within a hierarchy provide little information until I actually open up an editor and look at the methods + comments.  At that point the outline + editor do the complete job and are more familiar.  2. The two panes within the hierarchy view are always difficult to layout within a window.   Especially because they force a vertical layout, and may times I want a horizontal layout.    Perhaps the functionality within the method list could just be moved to the outline?  NOTES: EG (5/24/2001 7:16:55 AM) 	what kind of horizontal layout do you have in mind. Can you send me a screen shot? DCR - Hierarchy view without Method List (1GE8MPK) minor UI JDT

description:
Aaargh, my mind hurts. In the package and hierarchy views the status line is used to show the complete path for the selected java class. Unfortunately, the root of the path is shown after the class name. Problem 1: it is contrary to most instances of hierarchical presentation ( ie, left to right, root to class ). 2: it is inconsistent with the navigator. For instance .. in navigator = project/x/y/MyClass.java in hierarchy = x.y.MyClass - /project 3: It is hard to interpret. The use of the dash immediately makes me think it is some sort of mathematical formula. It would be better to use a comma or colon. This is sentence, not a formula. 4. It is hard to interpret. You break the project and class up. Then you throw a slash before the project name, reaffirming my desire to append the project name after the class name. Suggestions .. project/x.y.MyClass NOTES: DS (5/24/01 3:25:58 PM) Aaah ! The same approach is taken in the Outline view, but it gets even more complex .. member - class - project MA (5/25/01 11:28:40 AM) How whould we render types in jar files? Java Elements belong to a package fragment root, which is either a project or folder or a jar. EG (5/29/01 7:06:59 PM) defer EG (18.07.2001 15:16:41) revisit for 2.0 MA (09.08.2001 17:05:36) The JavaElementLableProvider should be redesigned, and we should use a consistent style of rendering elements MA (15.08.2001 17:50:00) Suggestion: Java element name (fully qualified) = Corresponding Resource name Max. 1 separator EG (15.08.2001 17:54:57) Wait with redesign for code review MA (17.09.2001 18:44:17) changed: Reduced the number of dashs Java element name '-' underlying resource container * Java Elements are formatted like this: *
    *
  • IJavaProject: name
    • *
  • IPackageFragmentRoot: underlying path (contains project if internal)
    • *
  • IPackageFragment: package name '-' path of parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
  • ICompilationUnit: fully qualified name '-' path of parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
  • IClassFile: fully qualified name '-' path of parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
  • IType: fully qualified name '-' path of IClassFile/ICompilationUnit or * , if in archive, parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
  • Elements in ICompilationUnit: name '-' path of IClassFile/ICompilationUnit or * , if in archive, parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
  • Fiels, Methods: name with signature '-' fully qualified name of descaring type '-' * path of IClassFile/ICompilationUnit or if in archive, parent PackageFragmentRoot
    • *
my_mothod:

For instance .. in navigator = project/x/y/MyClass.java in hierarchy = x.y.MyClass - /project 3: It is hard to interpret. The use of the dash immediately makes me think it is some sort of mathematical formula. It would be better to use a comma or colon. This is sentence, not a formula. 4. It is hard to interpret. You break the project and class up. Then you throw a slash before the project name, reaffirming my desire to append the project name after the class name. Suggestions .. project/x.y.MyClass NOTES: DS (5/24/01 3:25:58 PM) Aaah ! The same approach is taken in the Outline view, but it gets even more complex .. member - class - project MA (5/25/01 11:28:40 AM) How whould we render types in jar files? Java Elements belong to a package fragment root, which is either a project or folder or a jar. description: It does not appear possible to copy something from one project into the top-level of another project in the packages view.   - select Foo in project B and use the copy menu - in the dialog, select the project into which you want to copy Foo. - the OK button is not enabled.  it appears only to be enabled if you select some subfolder  Similarly (but more confusingly) if you use drag and drop and drop Foo over the project you want, a copy is done but not into the project.  Foo ends up in some subdir which was not what was selected when I dropped.  NOTES:  JM (27/05/2001 6:37:57 PM) 	I have entered prs about the drag and drop problem but assume it was just a bug.  This newly  	discovered behaviour seems to indicate a plot to not allow users to put stuff in their projects. 	Is this the intended behaviour?  Why?  EG (5/29/01 9:49:37 PM) 	reorg problem?  TM (5/31/2001 17:20:52) 	Two things:  	1) If there is exactly one source folder in a project. Anything that is copied to that project is	 		copied to the source folder. This is a bug and quickly fixed. 	2) As detailed in another PR, the copying of java elements to non-package java elements 		(for example a folder) is a problem. It's a big change we might not want to do right now. 		Also, we are going to lose the "smart rename" feature, as this depends on the copied/moved/ 		renamed elements being java elements.  TM (5/31/2001 19:53:19) 	fixed for the resource case (the doc folder) 	EG&TM: Will not do the case where we copy java elements to resource containers (i.e. copy 	compilation unit); we should revisit the architecture post-june.  	Moving to inactive.  AK (9/17/2001 5:09:31 PM) 	fixed in 201

description: The handling of the return statement (e.g. adjusting the selection end) turned  out to be a pooridea.  	Fix this after June. Really extract the return statement and generate a  new one.   NOTES:  DB (08.08.2001 13:32:42) 	Now a new  return statement is generated. Additionally it is now  possible to extract any return statement 	as long as all possible execution flows return a value.  	Fixed in build 200.
my_mothod: The handling of the return statement (e.g. adjusting the selection end) turned  out to be a pooridea.  	Fix this after June. Really extract the return statement and generate a  new one.   NOTES:  DB (08.08.2001 13:32:42) 	Now a new  return statement is generated. Additionally it is now  possible to extract any return statement 	as long as all possible execution flows return a value.  	Fixed in build 200. Rework handling of return statement (1GEK2XO) critical UI JDT

description: I have been profiling the workbench to determine why the Perspective | Open  action takes so long to run.  The profiling revealed that 90% of the time is spent in the  creation of view widgets.  In the java perspective over 50% of the time is spent creating the  parts for the packages view and hierarchy view.  In my test scenario there are no resources in the workspace.  However, the  createPartControl method for the Hierarchy View takes 4.6s to run.    The createPartControl  method for the Package view takes .87s to run.   This is also surprising, given that there are no resources in the workspace.   In comparison,  the createPartControl method for most of the other views is completed in .2  to .3s.    Here are the stats.  		RootLayoutContainer.createControl started 			PartPane.createControl Navigator finished in 311 ms 			PartPane.createControl Hierarchy finished in 4326 ms 			PartPane.createControl Packages finished in 872 ms 			PartPane.createControl Tasks finished in 250 ms 			PartPane.createControl Search Results finished in 271 ms 			PartPane.createControl Console finished in 210 ms 			PartPane.createControl Outline finished in 241 ms 		RootLayoutContainer.createControl finished in 7701 ms  Note: This profiling was done on top of VaJava.  However, it illustrates that these views are way out of proportion in comparison to other views.  NOTES: EG (5/31/2001 10:37:36 AM) 	AK please add a trace of this scenario. It was already on our list.  AK (6/1/01 5:14:50 PM) please see comments (look only on percentage, not ms numbers)  Description of CPU usage for thread main     100.0% - 53629 ms - intuitive.audit.Audit.main()       100.0% - description: DW (6/1/01 8:15:59 AM) 	In the self hosting setup, If I create a simple Test project with one "HelloWorld" class, 	and debug that class (breakpoint on println), I do not see source for the HelloWorld 	class.  	I am using the default source locating strategy for that project, and a custom strategy 	for the "Eclipse Core Launching" project.   	If I change to use a "custom lookup" with just the one "Test" project, source is found.  TM (6/1/2001 15:24:18) 	I just tried this in 116. I do this in the package viewer:  	1) create a new java project "Test", press finish on the first wizard page 	2) create a class "Foo" in the default package, check the box to add a main method 	3) add 		 	 		System.out.println("foobar");  		to the main method 	4) add a breakpoint 	5) build & hit debug 	6) source of the main method is shown in the debugger.  EG (6/2/2001 4:43:32 AM) 	I can't reproduce it either but DM & DB had problems with the source attachment 	for rt.jar in 117. The variable settings were correct in their workspaces.  EG (6/4/2001 12:36:22 AM) 	I suspect a race condition. I'm observing that when a type from a JAR 	is restored as part of the persistent layout then it can happen that 	the type does not exist.  DW (6/4/01 2:14:05 PM) 	Tracked this down to a NotPresentException - I have a closed & non-existent project on a classpath. 	My classpath for "org.eclipse.jdt.debug" included "org.eclipse.jdt.core". 	This happenned because we once had the "org.eclipse.jdt.core" project in the workspace as source, 	but no longer do.  By removing the project from my classpath, the problem goes away. However, 	I do not see why it was even checking the classpath of that project, since the project I was debugging 	was a simple stand-alone "HelloWorld" project. This property is only set by the 	"SourceLookupPropertyPage". Generally, the user will never go to this page 	or change the property, so the source lookup is probably always degrading to looking 	in the entire workspace. 	  	public static IJavaProject[] getSourceLookupPath(IJavaProject project) throws JavaModelException { 		IProject p= project.getProject(); 		try { 			String property= p.getPersistentProperty(new QualifiedName(LaunchingPlugin.getPluginId(), ADDITIONAL_LOOKUP_PROPERTY)); 			if (property == null) 				return null; 			return decodeProjects(property); 		} catch (CoreException e) { 			throw new JavaModelException(e); 		} 	}  EG (6/4/2001 10:49:18 AM) 	should fix. Source lookup should be robust against non-existing class path entries.  JW (6/5/01 6:01:03 PM) 	OK to fix.  TM (6/5/2001 11:06:11) 	fixing the original scenario should be easy & safe  TM (6/6/2001 15:32:50) 	fix is to ignore non-existing & closed projects.  	fix in the works.  TM (6/6/2001 15:50:58) 	have fix.  TM (6/6/2001 16:45:53) 	reviewed by AW.  EG (23.07.2001 11:19:16) 	pls check that fix is 0.9  TM (23.07.2001 11:28:52) 	The fix is in 0.9. 	moving to verify.

description: The JAR packager "simply" stores all exported elements 	in the JAR description. This is bad if a folder content 	changes. 	If all children of x are exported then x should be in the JAR 	instead of the children (same applies for x if it is a child).   NOTES: EG (6/4/2001 12:37:52 AM) 	defer  DM (8/15/01 1:45:06 PM) 	Fixed in 2.0 stream
my_mothod: The JAR packager "simply" stores all exported elements 	in the JAR description. This is bad if a folder content 	changes. 	If all children of x are exported then x should be in the JAR 	instead of the children (same applies for x if it is a child).   NOTES: EG (6/4/2001 12:37:52 AM) 	defer  DM (8/15/01 1:45:06 PM) 	Fixed in 2.0 stream JAR Package description should only store parent - not all children (1GENRJY) critical UI JDT

description: To reproduce: 	Perform a refactoring on a Java resource that causes some changes to occur.  [Renaming a class is a good choice] 	Click through the Refactoring wizard until the change browser pops up. 	Notice that while the change browser looks just like others in the Eclipse platform, the up/down arrows that in other 	browsers provide one-click scanning of the changes are not available.  	Recommend these buttons get added as it is difficult to see all the changes that have occurred without scrolling 	through the entire file.  NOTES: GDA (6/5/01 10:45:12 AM) 	Defer  AK (8/14/2001 6:01:45 PM) 	fixed
my_mothod: To reproduce: 	Perform a refactoring on a Java resource that causes some changes to occur.  [Renaming a class is a good choice] 	Click through the Refactoring wizard until the change browser pops up. 	Notice that while the change browser looks just like others in the Eclipse platform, the up/down arrows that in other 	browsers provide one-click scanning of the changes are not available.  	Recommend these buttons get added as it is difficult to see all the changes that have occurred without scrolling 	through the entire file.  NOTES: GDA (6/5/01 10:45:12 AM) 	Defer  AK (8/14/2001 6:01:45 PM) 	fixed Missing up/down arrows in the refactoring source change browser (1GET5T0) critical UI JDT

description: 1. Install 2 JREs using the Preferences page: Sun's JDK1.2.2 and J9 	2. Make Sun's JDK1.2.2 the default JRE 	3. Create a Java project with a HelloWorld class: [public class HelloWorld {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		System.out.println("Hello World"); 	} }] 	4. Use custom JRE for launching: use J9 	5. Put a breakpoint on 'System.out.println("Hello World");' 	6. Launch under debug 	7. When the breakpoint is hit, step into 	Observe: The top stack frame is PrintStream.println(String) 					however, the source shown is the comment of print(double)  	The debugger should use the source of the launched JRE and not the one of the default JRE.  NOTES:  DW (6/7/01 2:16:38 PM) 	I think this is a reasonable request, but hard to implement. The java model in the IDE does 	not know about the launched program, or what JRE it is running with. The source lookup is 	performed in the IDE with the JRE that is present.  DW (6/7/01 6:35:30 PM) 	Workaround is to associate the source jar for the runtime source with the rt.jar that is 	in the IDE.  DW (6/7/01 6:36:50 PM) 	Moved to JUI for future consideration.
my_mothod: 1. Install 2 JREs using the Preferences page: Sun's JDK1.2.2 and J9 	2. Make Sun's JDK1.2.2 the default JRE 	3. Create a Java project with a HelloWorld class: [public class HelloWorld {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		System.out.println("Hello World"); 	} }] 	4. Use custom JRE for launching: use J9 	5. Put a breakpoint on 'System.out.println("Hello World");' 	6. Launch under debug 	7. When the breakpoint is hit, step into 	Observe: The top stack frame is PrintStream.println(String) 					however, the source shown is the comment of print(double)  	The debugger should use the source of the launched JRE and not the one of the default JRE.  NOTES:  DW (6/7/01 2:16:38 PM) 	I think this is a reasonable request, but hard to implement. The java model in the IDE does 	not know about the launched program, or what JRE it is running with. The source lookup is 	performed in the IDE with the JRE that is present.  DW (6/7/01 6:35:30 PM) 	Workaround is to associate the source jar for the runtime source with the rt.jar that is 	in the IDE.  DW (6/7/01 6:36:50 PM) 	Moved to JUI for future consideration. Should use launched JRE for source lookup (1GEW4FM) normal Debug JDT

description: - add a classpath variable that represents a file (e.g. TestVar) 	- now open the build path properties page for a Java project 	- switch to the Libraries page 	- press Add Variable... 	- select TestVar 	observe: you can type into the path extension field although the selected var represents a file.   NOTES:  GDA (6/5/01 12:07:50 PM) 	Defer.  MA (31.07.2001 16:04:55) 	Added warning when resolved path does not exist. 	(Error would be too limiting) 	fix in 200

description: Create a new class. 	Decide to copy the package imports and the first method from another  class, 	so go to the other class and select the text from the first import  statement to the end of the first method, 	copy it, go to the new class, select almost everything except for the  package statement and the final } 	and paste overtop.  Forget to change the pasted class name back to the  new class name, and save. 	You get the dialog that asks if you want to rename the compilation unit  to the new name. (Yes/No) 	No, you don't, but if you click "No", you will mess up the constructor  names. 	What you *really* want here is a cancel button in the dialog.  NOTES: 	CM (6/5/2001 11:24:55 AM) 		I opened a similar PR before, but against a different dialog: 		1GDSCT6: ITPJUI:ALL - Missing Cancel button on "Move  Compilation Unit?" dialog  EG (6/5/2001 9:43:07 AM) 	annoying, but not critical, defer
my_mothod: Create a new class. 	Decide to copy the package imports and the first method from another  class, 	so go to the other class and select the text from the first import  statement to the end of the first method, 	copy it, go to the new class, select almost everything except for the  package statement and the final } 	and paste overtop.  Forget to change the pasted class name back to the  new class name, and save. 	You get the dialog that asks if you want to rename the compilation unit  to the new name. (Yes/No) 	No, you don't, but if you click "No", you will mess up the constructor  names. 	What you *really* want here is a cancel button in the dialog.  NOTES: 	CM (6/5/2001 11:24:55 AM) 		I opened a similar PR before, but against a different dialog: 		1GDSCT6: ITPJUI:ALL - Missing Cancel button on "Move  Compilation Unit?" dialog  EG (6/5/2001 9:43:07 AM) 	annoying, but not critical, defer Missing critical UI JDT

description: When performing a rename on parameters, a map of parameter names (old name -> new name) is presented, which is nice. However when choosing one to rename, its new name is emptied which is somewhat disruptive. I would prefer having it fully selected, so as to easily choose to rename or discard, i.e. the old name could be treated as a suggestion (similarily to rename field or method).  NOTES:  AK (8/14/2001 12:56:19 PM) 	fixed

description: 1. In the workbench prefs dialog, select *.java. 2. Add "Jar Description Editor" and "Properties File Editor" to the list of valid editors. 3. description: If the new class wizard can figure out the folder (based on the active view) it gives focus to the class name field. If it can't, it gives focus to the folder field.  It should always give focus to the same field. It quickly become an automatic response to hit the new class button and type the class name. This fails if it gives focus to the folder field. The user then has to undo the wrong entry, copy it to the class name field, then pick the folder, rather than just picking the folder after entering the class name.  NOTES:  MA (31.07.2001 11:26:41) 	Removed the current feature.	 	Fix in 200
my_mothod: If the new class wizard can figure out the folder (based on the active view) it gives focus to the class name field. If it can't, it gives focus to the folder field.  It should always give focus to the same field. It quickly become an automatic response to hit the new class button and type the class name. This fails if it gives focus to the folder field. The user then has to undo the wrong entry, copy it to the class name field, then pick the folder, rather than just picking the folder after entering the class name. description: 1. create a java project, just give a name (eg. 'Bad') 2. go to properties, buildpath.  Give it a /src and a /bin.  Finish. 3. go to properties, buildpath.  		3.1  switch to "Use project as source folder" option 		3.2  take out /bin from buildpath text field.  Finishing gives 	Error Setting Build Path 	Reason: 		Invalid path: /Bad		  If you do 3.1, Finish, then do 3.2, Finish, it will work.  Its doing them both in the same dialog session that's the problem.  NOTES: MA (31.07.2001 11:01:58) 	The Java project wizard first sets the new Output location, then the classpath. This leads to incorrect state 	after setting the output location. 	The solution should be, that Java core offers one set routine.  		setBuildPaths(IClasspathEntry[] cp, IPath outputLocation)  	Still pending and really important is als a public verification routine, returning a displayable status.  		IStatus validateBuildPaths(IClasspathEntry[] cp, IPath outputLocation) 	 	See also 1G7A1TL: ITPJCORE:WINNT - DCR - JM - Rules for classpath not specified  	Move to JCORE  PM (8/2/2001 4:22:27 PM) 	The requested API is available in 2.0 stream (JavaConventions.validateClasspath/validateClasspathEntry). 	Moving to ITPJUI for making the necessary adjustments.   MA (05.09.2001 18:03:45) 	implemented in 200 (with JCore 2.0 stream)

Finishing gives 	Error Setting Build Path 	Reason: 		Invalid path: /Bad		  If you do 3.1, Finish, then do 3.2, Finish, it will work.  Its doing them both in the same dialog session that's the problem.  NOTES: MA (31.07.2001 11:01:58) 	The Java project wizard first sets the new Output location, then the classpath. IStatus validateBuildPaths(IClasspathEntry[] cp, IPath outputLocation) 	 	See also 1G7A1TL: ITPJCORE:WINNT - DCR - JM - Rules for classpath not specified  	Move to JCORE  PM (8/2/2001 4:22:27 PM) 	The requested API is available in 2.0 stream (JavaConventions.validateClasspath/validateClasspathEntry). 	Moving to ITPJUI for making the necessary adjustments.   MA (05.09.2001 18:03:45) 	implemented in 200 (with JCore 2.0 stream) Error changing classpath to not use /bin (1GFQT1W) critical UI JDT

description: Have a package with some classes and many of them have references to java.io.File. The classes have no compilation errors. 	Create in the same package a class called File. Many errors show up. Rename (in the packages view) the class File to FileObject. 	It renames all references to File, including the ones that are java.io.File to be FileObject.  NOTES:  AK (8/15/2001 12:26:05 PM) 	nothing can be done on the refactoring side - all these are found and reported as accurate matches 	moving to jcore for comment  PM (9/13/2001 11:20:33 AM)	 	The only case were we aren't suppose to find accurate matches is cases where the errors show up on reference to File. 	But I presume that once having rebound (java.io.)File to (pkg.)File, lots of secondary errors are discovered when using variable of type File. 	There is nothing wrong with search finding these. File really means pkg.File from now on.  	The compiler would produce the secondary errors, and if the user persists in willing to refactor, then there is nothing we can do.  	Maybe refactoring could discourage from refactoring code which has errors, and let the user confirm he wants to do so at his own risks... 	Moving back to ITPJUI for disposal.  EG (18.09.2001 19:03:50) 	we are warning the user in the case of errors. 	AK pls confirm and dispose if we do so.  AK (9/18/2001 7:07:27 PM) 	we do warn in case of syntax errors. 	we do not in case of compile errors. 	with compiler errors the problem is that some unaffected files should actually by modified. 	not sure what to do in that case - should we warn if there are _any_ compile errors in the workspace? 	only in the project and the related ones? only in affected files? not at all?  AK (9/20/2001 11:33:41 AM) 	warnings are issed when an affected resource has compiler errors. 	201

NOTES:  AK (8/15/2001 12:26:05 PM) 	nothing can be done on the refactoring side - all these are found and reported as accurate matches 	moving to jcore for comment  PM (9/13/2001 11:20:33 AM)	 	The only case were we aren't suppose to find accurate matches is cases where the errors show up on reference to File. 	But I presume that once having rebound (java.io.)File to (pkg.)File, lots of secondary errors are discovered when using variable of type File. 	There is nothing wrong with search finding these. File really means pkg.File from now on.  	The compiler would produce the secondary errors, and if the user persists in willing to refactor, then there is nothing we can do.  	Maybe refactoring could discourage from refactoring code which has errors, and let the user confirm he wants to do so at his own risks... 	Moving back to ITPJUI for disposal. description: If I am showing the TypeHierarchy for an interface and I add another class to the interface I have to close the TypeHierarchy view and reopen it.  STEPS 	1) Open the TypeHierarchyView on an interface 	2) Create a class that implements that interface 	3) The interface is not updated and must be closed and reopened to refresh   NOTES: EG (17.08.2001 10:27:24) 	suspect that the UI isn't getting the proper hierarchy deltas. 	MA pls confirm  MA (20.08.2001 12:54:34) 	reproducable: 	1. Create interface XY, open it in the Type Hierarchy 	2. Create a class A, not yet implementing the interface. 	3. Open in editor and edit to 'implements XY'. 	4. The type hierarchy is not updated. No hierarchyChanged is invoked.  	5. Now add a new package x. 	6. The type hierarchy is now correctly updated.  	Moving to jcore  JBL (9/10/2001 6:04:20 PM) 	Reproduced and fixed JDT CORE to send a hierachyChanged event in the above case 	(released in SNZ's HEAD stream). 	However symptoms are still there since the UI calls refresh() on the hierarchy before the 	end of the resource delta processing. As a result, the .java file is not reindexed yet, and A 	doesn't appear as a potential subtype of XY. 	Moving back to JDTUI.  EG (18.09.2001 18:13:46) 	MA is there a way to do this cleanly or is this a problem related to the order 	listener notification?  MA (28.09.2001 12:36:52) 	We need to solve the problem of the order of IElementChangedListeners. 	The problem is that I have to listen to hierarchy changes (as ITypeHierarchyChangedListener) and 	as well to method changes in the types contained in the hierarchy (-> IElementChangedListener) 	-> I need the hierarchy to be up to date when the IElementChangedListener is called 		if I want to find out if methods have to be added / removed from the hierarchy view. 		-> The ITypeHierarchyChangedListener has to be a invoked before all IElementChangedListener  	What could be done: 		- we could make the TypeHierarchy- IElementChangedListener a first class IElementChangedListener. It is guaranteed to 			be invoked before all (client-) IElementChangedListeners. 		- it must be guaranteed that whenever a type hierarchy changed, also a IElementChangedListener will be there.  	Another approach could be to give more information to the ITypeHierarchyChangedListeners. They could contain the 	IElementChangedListener delta as an argument. 	But then, In my case, I would also need to also be informed if a type in the hierarchy changed (even if the hierarchy stayed the same)
my_mothod: If I am showing the TypeHierarchy for an interface and I add another class to the interface I have to close the TypeHierarchy view and reopen it.  STEPS 	1) Open the TypeHierarchyView on an interface 	2) Create a class that implements that interface 	3) The interface is not updated and must be closed and reopened to refresh   NOTES: EG (17.08.2001 10:27:24) 	suspect that the UI isn't getting the proper hierarchy deltas. 	MA pls confirm  MA (20.08.2001 12:54:34) 	reproducable: 	1. Create interface XY, open it in the Type Hierarchy 	2. Create a class A, not yet implementing the interface. 	3. Open in editor and edit to 'implements XY'. 	4. The type hierarchy is not updated. No hierarchyChanged is invoked.  	5. Now add a new package x. 	6. The type hierarchy is now correctly updated.  	Moving to jcore  JBL (9/10/2001 6:04:20 PM) 	Reproduced and fixed JDT CORE to send a hierachyChanged event in the above case 	(released in SNZ's HEAD stream). 	However symptoms are still there since the UI calls refresh() on the hierarchy before the 	end of the resource delta processing. As a result, the .java file is not reindexed yet, and A 	doesn't appear as a potential subtype of XY. 	Moving back to JDTUI.  EG (18.09.2001 18:13:46) 	MA is there a way to do this cleanly or is this a problem related to the order 	listener notification?  MA (28.09.2001 12:36:52) 	We need to solve the problem of the order of IElementChangedListeners. 	The problem is that I have to listen to hierarchy changes (as ITypeHierarchyChangedListener) and 	as well to method changes in the types contained in the hierarchy (-> IElementChangedListener) 	-> I need the hierarchy to be up to date when the IElementChangedListener is called 		if I want to find out if methods have to be added / removed from the hierarchy view. 		-> The ITypeHierarchyChangedListener has to be a invoked before all IElementChangedListener  	What could be done: 		- we could make the TypeHierarchy- IElementChangedListener a first class IElementChangedListener. It is guaranteed to 			be invoked before all (client-) IElementChangedListeners. 		- it must be guaranteed that whenever a type hierarchy changed, also a IElementChangedListener will be there.  	Another approach could be to give more information to the ITypeHierarchyChangedListeners. They could contain the 	IElementChangedListener delta as an argument. 	But then, In my case, I would also need to also be informed if a type in the hierarchy changed (even if the hierarchy stayed the same) Type Hierarchy does not update when class added (1GII73E) critical UI JDT

description: Java editor will pad invalid characters at end of file when the file includes DBCS.  STEPS 1) INPUT DBCS at comment area or sentences in Java file 2) Save 3) At Task list, Syntax error shown and dot characters were padded at the end of file in Java editor.     NOTES:  KH (9/4/2001 5:34:46 PM) 	Steps (as I observed them)  	1. Import an example (eg. JUnit)  	2. Pick a class and change a comment to include DBCS characters  	3. Save the file  	4. Notice problems as reported above.   NOTE:  	The file on disk is fine. Only in the Java editor to extra characters appear at the end of the file.   EG (07.09.2001 19:50:08) 	fixed in 135  KH (9/10/2001 12:11:27 PM) 	Moving to JUI for disposal.  MF (2001/09/21 13:51:10) 	Verified the fix with 136a.

description: jkca (9/26/2001 1:57:09 PM)  From Mike Stock <mike.stock@csfs.com> on the corner:  This is a feature request regarding the Debug component: It would be very nice to have a built-in Java decompiler to see the binary classes that have no source associated with. Can that be done by third party plug-ins?  jkca (9/26/2001 1:58:06 PM) 	Currently this is possible, if the decompiler provider is the one who registers the launch & the source locator.  Feels like too much work for the source locator provider to me.  In the future, I think we should provide an extension point for  source locators so that third party vendors can just plugin a source locator.  DW (9/27/2001 9:25:07 AM) 	This is "java editor" work. Moved to JUI.

Feels like too much work for the source locator provider to me.  In the future, I think we should provide an extension point for  source locators so that third party vendors can just plugin a source locator.  DW (9/27/2001 9:25:07 AM) 	This is "java editor" work. Moved to JUI. Decompiler (1GKOC76) normal UI JDT

description: 1) Create two Java projects  Project1  and Project2 2) Make the .classpath file for  Project1 read-only  (RMB on .classpath file,  choose Properties, check read only) 3) Update Project1's Java Build Path to include Project2  (RMB on Project1,  choose Properties, choose Java Build Path, choose Projects tab) 4) To the user it looks like this has occurred without problem (it's still in  Project1's Java Build Path, and calls to the JavaModel return the correct  information) but since the .classpath file is read-only, this change has never occured).  At  this point we believe the user should have been told that the file could not be updated. 5) Bring down the workbench and bring it back up, and it is no longer in   Project1's Java Build Path.  They need a message to remind them that they need  to check out the .classpath file.  NOTES:
my_mothod: 1) Create two Java projects  Project1  and Project2 2) Make the .classpath file for  Project1 read-only  (RMB on .classpath file,  choose Properties, check read only) 3) Update Project1's Java Build Path to include Project2  (RMB on Project1,  choose Properties, choose Java Build Path, choose Projects tab) 4) To the user it looks like this has occurred without problem (it's still in  Project1's Java Build Path, and calls to the JavaModel return the correct  information) but since the .classpath file is read-only, this change has never occured).  At  this point we believe the user should have been told that the file could not be updated. 5) Bring down the workbench and bring it back up, and it is no longer in   Project1's Java Build Path.  They need a message to remind them that they need  to check out the .classpath file.  NOTES: Updating a Read-only .classpath file does not warn the user that the update did not  happen (1GLEVO4) critical UI JDT

description: Until PR 1G2QFBA: SWT:WINNT - Font metrics wrong for some italics fonts is fixed, we can't support italics properly.  NOTES:  LK (1/18/01 3:30:40 PM) 	Low priority until someone asks for this.  LK (1/30/01 11:58:30 AM) 	Supporting this is now further complicated by the fact that we are using bit bltting when typing. 	Italic fonts won't hold up to the bltting.	We did this to improve performance on Linux.  LK (2/7/01 12:04:18 PM) 	Opened 1G8SBZX: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic fonts and bltting overhangs on our end. 	This will deal with the bltting problem when the font for the entire widget is italic.  Still not going 	to do individual italic styles until someone asks.  LK (2/7/01 12:11:18 PM) 	We don't support italic fonts for the entire widget.  Cheese will occur during text changes (due to our 	bltting) and when changing from italic bold to italic regular (and vice versa).  In these instances, 	more of the changed text area has to be drawn in order to deal with overhangs.  See PR 	1G8SBZX: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic fonts and bltting overhangs.  Moving to Inactive. 	 LK (2/8/01 12:06:13 PM) 	Also see PR 1G8SBXB: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic font and bold styles not working together. 	Mentions that for a lot of italic fonts the baseline seems to different from the bold version.
my_mothod: Until PR 1G2QFBA: SWT:WINNT - Font metrics wrong for some italics fonts is fixed, we can't support italics properly. description: We need to be able to register eclipse as the default editor for a file type  with the OS. This will allow double clicking on a file and opening it in  eclipse. This is important for being able to view a .java file in a zip etc.   I don't think it should be a problem to get the file name from the command line  through to the workbech application which will be able to determine what editor  to use.  The question is where to put it in the workspace. I think the easiest answer is  to just create a "miscellaneous" project mapped to the file's location.  Remember this is not a project for "real work", its just a way of allowing the  file to be viewed/edited using an eclipse editor.
my_mothod: We need to be able to register eclipse as the default editor for a file type  with the OS. This will allow double clicking on a file and opening it in  eclipse. This is important for being able to view a .java file in a zip etc.   I don't think it should be a problem to get the file name from the command line  through to the workbech application which will be able to determine what editor  to use.  The question is where to put it in the workspace. I think the easiest answer is  to just create a "miscellaneous" project mapped to the file's location.  Remember this is not a project for "real work", its just a way of allowing the  file to be viewed/edited using an eclipse editor. [EditorMgmt] Need ability to open a file in eclipse from the command line enhancement UI Platform

description: DESRIPTION:  This was written against the Web Project,  but it is reproducable with a Java Project      <Note by Customer Rep, 2001/10/02 18:21:03, seq: 1 rel: 0  action: open> When you rename a web project from (select project->right click->rename) from "Webproj" to "WEBPROJ". Notice that all we did was change the case  not the length of the project name. Doing this caused WSAD to display a  dialog box saying that an internal error was encountered whenever we  accessed files in the renamed project. I looked at the .log file and  noticed      that the exception occured when WSAD tried to open          the .properties files for the project.      Log: Tue Oct 02 17:53:14 EDT 2001 4 org.eclipse.core.resources 272 Could not open indexed store: C:\Program  Files\IBM\WebSphere Studio Application  Developer\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.core.resources\.projects\WEBP ROJ\.properties. java.lang.NullPointerException        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.ObjectStore.commit(ObjectStore.java:183)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.ObjectStore.close(ObjectStore.java:168)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.IndexedStore.create(IndexedStore.java:151)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.IndexedStore.open(IndexedStore.java:314)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.open(IndexedStoreWrappe r.java:138)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.create(IndexedStoreWrap per.java:51)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getStore(IndexedStoreWr apper.java:132)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getIndex(IndexedStoreWr apper.java:97)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getCursor(IndexedStoreW rapper.java:88)                  After this, deleting a project fails with a NullPointerException during build.  Also, trying to rename any project  (eg a java project) now results in the same error (this worked prior to  renaming  the web project). Also, the workspace is messed up - here are a couple of examples:  - When I create a project, the 'Create a Project' smartguide does not close on completion, I have to hit cancel to get out of it.   - File->New->Enterprise Java Bean Sample does not load the sample's java code  Eventually, I need to reinstall to get WSAD to behave properly.       <Note by developer, 2001/10/03 17:12:40, seq: 4 rel: 0  action: assign> This is a severe error with "Navigator View".  Though Java's "Packages View"  does not have this problem, it has a related problem.  Overview:  If, in the "Navigator View", a resource is renamed so as the name is the same,  except some capitalization is changed (i.e. JavaProject is renamed to javaProject),  errors,  exceptions, and worse problems occur.  The only scenario where this does not  occur is in a "Simple Project" which has nothing in it.  Once you put something in a  simple  project (i.e. a file or folder), it too has the same problems.  In the worse case scenario, let's say you create a java project called "Jp1"  and  then rename it to "JP1".  You will get errors and exceptions, but you may (I stress - MAY) also  end up with two projects - one called "Jp1" and one called "JP1" - the contents of each  pointing  to the same files. If you try to delete or close either project you will get various exceptions  and  errors. If you try to create another java project you will receive more errors and  exceptions (regarding validation) - and will return to the wizard (but the project will have actually  been created).   "Packages View"  Packages View doesn't have this problem, but it has one similar to it.  If you  try to rename a resource in this view to a name that already exists (except the capitalization is  different), you will get an  exception.  Example: say you have two projects, one called "javaproject" and  one  called "javaProj". If you rename "javaproject" to javaproj you will get an exception.   note:  these rename problems occur not only with projects, but also with  files/folders.

Notice that all we did was change the case  not the length of the project name. Doing this caused WSAD to display a  dialog box saying that an internal error was encountered whenever we  accessed files in the renamed project. I looked at the .log file and  noticed      that the exception occured when WSAD tried to open          the .properties files for the project.      Log: Tue Oct 02 17:53:14 EDT 2001 4 org.eclipse.core.resources 272 Could not open indexed store: C:\Program  Files\IBM\WebSphere Studio Application  Developer\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.core.resources\.projects\WEBP ROJ\.properties. java.lang.NullPointerException        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.ObjectStore.commit(ObjectStore.java:183)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.ObjectStore.close(ObjectStore.java:168)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.IndexedStore.create(IndexedStore.java:151)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.indexing.IndexedStore.open(IndexedStore.java:314)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.open(IndexedStoreWrappe r.java:138)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.create(IndexedStoreWrap per.java:51)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getStore(IndexedStoreWr apper.java:132)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getIndex(IndexedStoreWr apper.java:97)        at  org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.IndexedStoreWrapper.getCursor(IndexedStoreW rapper.java:88)                  After this, deleting a project fails with a NullPointerException during build.  Also, trying to rename any project  (eg a java project) now results in the same error (this worked prior to  renaming  the web project). Also, the workspace is messed up - here are a couple of examples:  - When I create a project, the 'Create a Project' smartguide does not close on completion, I have to hit cancel to get out of it.   - File->New->Enterprise Java Bean Sample does not load the sample's java code  Eventually, I need to reinstall to get WSAD to behave properly.       <Note by developer, 2001/10/03 17:12:40, seq: 4 rel: 0  action: assign> This is a severe error with "Navigator View".  Though Java's "Packages View"  does not have this problem, it has a related problem.  Overview:  If, in the "Navigator View", a resource is renamed so as the name is the same,  except some capitalization is changed (i.e. JavaProject is renamed to javaProject),  errors,  exceptions, and worse problems occur.  The only scenario where this does not  occur is in a "Simple Project" which has nothing in it.  Once you put something in a  simple  project (i.e. a file or folder), it too has the same problems.  In the worse case scenario, let's say you create a java project called "Jp1"  and  then rename it to "JP1".  You will get errors and exceptions, but you may (I stress - MAY) also  end up with two projects - one called "Jp1" and one called "JP1" - the contents of each  pointing  to the same files. If you try to delete or close either project you will get various exceptions  and  errors. If you try to create another java project you will receive more errors and  exceptions (regarding validation) - and will return to the wizard (but the project will have actually  been created).   "Packages View"  Packages View doesn't have this problem, but it has one similar to it.  If you  try to rename a resource in this view to a name that already exists (except the capitalization is  different), you will get an  exception.  Example: say you have two projects, one called "javaproject" and  one  called "javaProj". If you rename "javaproject" to javaproj you will get an exception.   note:  these rename problems occur not only with projects, but also with  files/folders. Renaming Project from project to PROJECT messes everything up (1.0) blocker Resources Platform

description: Version: 204  Description: Originally reported as part of bug 2694  (b.)  The editor selection dialog should allow multiple selections.  ALSO, double-click (to select and accept) does not work in this dialog.  Steps: *Window->Preferences *Expand Workbench, select File Editors. *Click Add button next to associated editors table BUG: Notice list is not multi-select.  Also notice that double-click does not  do anything.

ALSO, double-click (to select and accept) does not work in this dialog.  Steps: *Window->Preferences *Expand Workbench, select File Editors. *Click Add button next to associated editors table BUG: Notice list is not multi-select.  Also notice that double-click does not  do anything. [EditorMgmt] associations: Editor selection dialog needs to be multiselect enhancement UI Platform

my_mothod: - Load a java project from a repository - Edit several java files in the project, deleting several methods   (I am not sure if it is important, but there were methods added as well) - Synchronize - Double-click on the first modified java file so you can see the Structured   Compare view - Now click on the 'Two way compare (ignore ancestor)' button - Internal error, Walkbacks in the log (pasted below)  I have never clicked on that button before, so I don't even know what it does. description: I have added an action in the Team menu to create a patch file using CVS diff.  The patch format is 'unified' with local addition showing (e.g. options -u -N  to diff). When trying to apply this patch I get an invalid date error and a  runtime exception. Please let me know if the patch file format is wrong. Or  what diff options you expected to be used to create the CVS diff output.  Here is an example patch file that I have generated:  Index: bin/a.txt =================================================================== RCS file: /home/jlemieux/workrepo/patch_example/bin/a.txt,v retrieving revision 1.1 diff -u -r1.1 a.txt --- bin/a.txt	19 Oct 2001 18:24:16 -0000	1.1 +++ bin/a.txt	22 Oct 2001 18:20:28 -0000 @@ -1 +1,2 @@ -sadfasdf \ No newline at end of file +sadfasdf +ADDED L LINE Index: src/newfile.txt =================================================================== RCS file: src/newfile.txt diff -N src/newfile.txt --- /dev/null	1 Jan 1970 00:00:00 -0000 +++ src/newfile.txt	22 Oct 2001 18:20:28 -0000 @@ -0,0 +1 @@ +NEW

description: protected ITextBuffer doCreate(IFile file) throws CoreException { 		FileEditorInput input= new FileEditorInput(file);	 		IDocument document= fDocumentProvider.getDocument(input); 		if (document != null) { 			return new TextBuffer(document); 		} else { 			InputStreamReader in= null; 			/*]*/try {		 				document= new Document(); 				in= new InputStreamReader(new  BufferedInputStream(file.getContents())); 				StringBuffer buffer= new StringBuffer(); 				char[] readBuffer= new char[2048]; 				int n= in.read(readBuffer); 				while (n > 0) { 					buffer.append(readBuffer, 0, n); 					n= in.read(readBuffer); 				} 				document.set(buffer.toString()); 				return new TextBuffer(document); 			} catch (IOException x) { 				IStatus s= new Status(IStatus.ERROR,  JavaPlugin.getPluginId(), JavaStatusConstants.INTERNAL_ERROR, x.getMessage(),  x); 				throw new CoreException(s); 			} finally { 				if (in != null) { 					try { 						in.close(); 					} catch (IOException x) { 					} 				} 			}/*[*/ 		} 	}  Extracting a method from the code /*]*/.../*[*/ doesn't return the created text buffer.

description: A breakpoint will be hit regardless of the project it was defined in.  Given projects P1, and P2, and in both projects the package foo which contains the class Bar.  Bar has a main method that contains one line which does System.out.print(<project name>).  Put a breakpoint on the System.out line in P1's Bar.  Debug P2's bar.  The breakpoint will get hit, but it was not set on P2!
