The breakpoint will get hit, but it was not set on P2! [breakpoints] Breakpoints from one project, hit in another project normal Debug JDT

description: NOTE: TVT problem from RTP.  Summary:   Create a task, try to enter all the letters of the alphabet (including special  characters such as u with umlaut) in the description.  Unable to type characters a, c, f, p, v, x, y and z on German version of  Win2000.  It acts as if the Ctrl key is stuck in the down position, but we  verified independently on three different German machines the same behavior.  We can enter text in the default text editor.  I suspect this bug lies in the  CText code.
my_mothod: NOTE: TVT problem from RTP.  Summary:   Create a task, try to enter all the letters of the alphabet (including special  characters such as u with umlaut) in the description.  Unable to type characters a, c, f, p, v, x, y and z on German version of  Win2000.  It acts as if the Ctrl key is stuck in the down position, but we  verified independently on three different German machines the same behavior.  We can enter text in the default text editor.  I suspect this bug lies in the  CText code. TVT1: Cannot type characters a, c, f, p, v, x, y and z in Task List description field on German machine critical UI Platform

description: The Java editor fails to open a java source file when we have PICLDebugTargets  in the debug view. There is java.lang.ClassCastException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.javaeditor.RunToLineAction.getContextFromModel  (RunToLineAction.java:111)  The getContextFromModel() method incorrectly assumes that all debug targets are of type JDIDebugTarget. I see a few other spots in RunToLineAction where a  debug target is blindly cast to a JDIDebugTarget without checking it first.  I am seeing this with the R1.0 (0.137 build) driver.  I don't think this is a new problem.
my_mothod: The Java editor fails to open a java source file when we have PICLDebugTargets  in the debug view. There is java.lang.ClassCastException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.javaeditor.RunToLineAction.getContextFromModel  (RunToLineAction.java:111)  The getContextFromModel() method incorrectly assumes that all debug targets are of type JDIDebugTarget. I see a few other spots in RunToLineAction where a  debug target is blindly cast to a JDIDebugTarget without checking it first.  I am seeing this with the R1.0 (0.137 build) driver.  I don't think this is a new problem. 1.0 -- Casting problem in RunToLineAction class critical Debug JDT

description: Customer experiences compare timeout if the compare takes more than 20 seconds. He wants to be bale to change timout value. Cust Using 1.0  ************************************** We can reproduce this just comparing two local files. So it appears to be the compare framework.  Ydo a diff on a file, and it pops up a dialog explicitly telling you about a 20 second time-out.  I'll repeat the exercise and post you the dialog in a short while...  where does it tell you about the 20 sec ? window popping up ?  Very odd.  Where are you suggesting an error message might be present? There are no other messages obvious in the UI, although I imagine there might be some logged.  The reason it looked like a coded time-out is that it consistently tells us that the diff took longer than 20 seconds and therefore was aborted (or words to that effect).    Customer Said: I'm using extssh and haven't experienced any problems with the same CVS repository with other tools (at least nobody has reported any).  The diff engine timing out after 20 seconds does not seem right.  Is there a way I can tweak this magic period (perhaps a property in some XML somewhere)?  There's nothing I can find in the preferences to allow this to be changed.   *****************************

description: 20011018 Drop  I attepmted to use a JDK that had a sourc jar file, but it doesn't work When the locate source dialog pops up in the debugger, it appears that the JDK_SRC classpath variable points to "src" and not to "<jdkInstallDir>\src.jar".  A workaround it to define a new FOO_SRC variable, and assign it to point to the src.jar.  However, this is not a very good workaround, because you need to redo it every time you start the workbench.

description: This is a fix candidate for 1.0  Changing the name of the top-level type of a CU followed by save prompts the  user whether they want to rename the compilation unit as well.  The current implementation is problematic since the prompt is done inside the  delta processing. As a consequence, when changing a type programmatically a  dialog can show up as a side effect.  We have removed this behaviour in the 2.0 stream since the same effect can be  achieved with the rename type refactoring.  Proposal is to remove this behaviour in the 1.0 stream as well (1.0 already has  the rename type refactoring).
my_mothod: This is a fix candidate for 1.0  Changing the name of the top-level type of a CU followed by save prompts the  user whether they want to rename the compilation unit as well.  The current implementation is problematic since the prompt is done inside the  delta processing. As a consequence, when changing a type programmatically a  dialog can show up as a side effect.  We have removed this behaviour in the 2.0 stream since the same effect can be  achieved with the rename type refactoring.  Proposal is to remove this behaviour in the 1.0 stream as well (1.0 already has  the rename type refactoring). Smart Save behaviour of a CU is problematic (1.0 fix candidate) normal UI JDT

description: Code complete includes fields and methods that are not code legal in the current context. For example, code completion shows private methods defined in Object. This not only clutters the code complete dialog with tons of useless data, it also generates compiler errors if a user unwittingly selects a private/protected field/method out of context.  The results of code complete should be filtered by protection and context.
my_mothod: Code complete includes fields and methods that are not code legal in the current context. For example, code completion shows private methods defined in Object. This not only clutters the code complete dialog with tons of useless data, it also generates compiler errors if a user unwittingly selects a private/protected field/method out of context.  The results of code complete should be filtered by protection and context. Code complete is TOO complete normal UI JDT

description: Eclipse 20011025 Windows 2000  1) Create the class included below. 2) Place a breakpoint as described in the comments of the code. 3) Run in the debugger.  public class _Scrapbook {  public static void main(String[] args) { 	_Scrapbook app = new _Scrapbook(); 	app.doit(); } void doit() { 	Object object = this; // put breakpoint here !!! 	do { 		System.out.println("asdads"+object); 		object.toString(); 	} while (false); } }  The line "Object object = this;" assigns to the variable 'object' but then when  you step into the do loop, the variable does not appear in the Variables view.   When you step over the println statement, then 'object' appears in the  Variables view.  I asked Olivier to investigate and he said the ranges returned are valid.
my_mothod: Eclipse 20011025 Windows 2000  1) Create the class included below. 2) Place a breakpoint as described in the comments of the code. 3) Run in the debugger.  public class _Scrapbook {  public static void main(String[] args) { 	_Scrapbook app = new _Scrapbook(); 	app.doit(); } void doit() { 	Object object = this; // put breakpoint here !!! 	do { 		System.out.println("asdads"+object); 		object.toString(); 	} while (false); } }  The line "Object object = this;" assigns to the variable 'object' but then when  you step into the do loop, the variable does not appear in the Variables view.   When you step over the println statement, then 'object' appears in the  Variables view.  I asked Olivier to investigate and he said the ranges returned are valid. Variable not showing in Variables view even when assigned a value normal Debug JDT

description: The main template creates the following:  public static void main(String arguments[]) { 	 }  The "[]" after the variable name is considered a C++ construct.  This should be changed to the following in order to give the tool a more Javaish feel.  public static void main(String[] arguments) { 	 } or, as main is most oftenly written:  public static void main(String[] args) { 	 }
my_mothod: The main template creates the following:  public static void main(String arguments[]) { 	 }  The "[]" after the variable name is considered a C++ construct.  This should be changed to the following in order to give the tool a more Javaish feel.  public static void main(String[] arguments) { 	 } or, as main is most oftenly written:  public static void main(String[] args) { 	 } The template for "main" puts "[]" after variable name normal UI JDT

description: The debug and run menus give a list of the latest commands at the top.  However,  this list appears to be shared, and selecting an entry that was previously a run  from the debug menu causes a run, not a debug.  This is confusing.  Also, there  is no information in the menu indicating whether the command was a debug or run.    I can see at least three ways to resolve this:  Each menu should have it's own latest menu. The menu contains info as to whether the command is run or debug. The command takes the context of the menu it is in.  More info on the third option:  Let's say I run a java application.  I then want  to debug it.  It shows up on the debug "latest" list, but rather than submitting  a run again, it submits a debug for the same program.

The menu contains info as to whether the command is run or debug. The command takes the context of the menu it is in.  More info on the third option:  Let's say I run a java application.  I then want  to debug it.  It shows up on the debug "latest" list, but rather than submitting  a run again, it submits a debug for the same program. Debug/Run "latest" Menus Confusing normal Debug JDT

description: Opening on behalf of George, who has been working with Jed on this one George will add more information soon based notes that he has had with Jed.  If the JSP source file name has an underscore in it, breakpoints in the JSP won't get installed successfully until after the JSP has been executed once.  Here are the steps to recreate it:  - Create the JSPandServletExample web project - Rename webApplication/Form/FormServletResultPage.jsp to   FormServletResult_Page.jsp - From the Project's context menu, select Edit Deployment Descriptor - Go to the Servlets page, select FormServlet and click the   Initialization button - Click twice on the result_page value to edit it and change it to   Form/FormServletResult_Page.jsp - Save web.xml - Put a breakpoint in the Java code of FormServletResult_Page. - Run the web project and run the form example to completion - The breakpoint remains blue and the debugger doesn't stop at it - Now you can remove and re-set the breakpoint and it will be green and   will stop correctly  This doesn't happen if you run the Form example without adding the underscore to the JSP file name.
my_mothod: Opening on behalf of George, who has been working with Jed on this one George will add more information soon based notes that he has had with Jed.  If the JSP source file name has an underscore in it, breakpoints in the JSP won't get installed successfully until after the JSP has been executed once.  Here are the steps to recreate it:  - Create the JSPandServletExample web project - Rename webApplication/Form/FormServletResultPage.jsp to   FormServletResult_Page.jsp - From the Project's context menu, select Edit Deployment Descriptor - Go to the Servlets page, select FormServlet and click the   Initialization button - Click twice on the result_page value to edit it and change it to   Form/FormServletResult_Page.jsp - Save web.xml - Put a breakpoint in the Java code of FormServletResult_Page. - Run the web project and run the form example to completion - The breakpoint remains blue and the debugger doesn't stop at it - Now you can remove and re-set the breakpoint and it will be green and   will stop correctly  This doesn't happen if you run the Form example without adding the underscore to the JSP file name. Breakpoint not installed if filename has underscore blocker Debug JDT

description: When inadvertantly versioning on the server using an existing version name, VCM corrupted the existing version by adding to it all the new files.  Our org.eclipse.jdt.core version v_206 got thus corrupted and broke the build  208 (we were not planning on releasing new stuff in it), since in the meantime,  we made changes, and versioned again using v_206 as the version name (due to  <shift> key being close to <enter> one).  It produced errors in the dialog, but actually did tag all new files with  version name 'v_206'.   So to the question: what happens if you get the version name wrong ? The answer  is: you corrupt it likely.   It should scan for ALL resources before it can claim there is no collision.  The net effect for us is that we lost version v_206, which was our integration  build input...
my_mothod: When inadvertantly versioning on the server using an existing version name, VCM corrupted the existing version by adding to it all the new files.  Our org.eclipse.jdt.core version v_206 got thus corrupted and broke the build  208 (we were not planning on releasing new stuff in it), since in the meantime,  we made changes, and versioned again using v_206 as the version name (due to  <shift> key being close to <enter> one).  It produced errors in the dialog, but actually did tag all new files with  version name 'v_206'.   So to the question: what happens if you get the version name wrong ? The answer  is: you corrupt it likely.   It should scan for ALL resources before it can claim there is no collision.  The net effect for us is that we lost version v_206, which was our integration  build input... VCM corrupting existing versions on naming collisions critical Team Platform

description: Stepping out of an Object.wait() call causes the debugger to hang.  To reproduce:  1. Import sources from wait.zip 2. Debug Main 3. Pause Producer Thread, step over until you are at the line that reads fConsumer.consume(); (Producer.java line 17) 4. Pause Consumer Thread 5. Do a step out on the Consumer Thread 6. Do a step over on the Producer Thread  Now the stack looks like: Main at localhost:13023 	System Thread [Finalizer] (Running) 	System Thread [Reference Handler] (Running) 	System Thread [Signal dispatcher] (Running) 	Thread [Consumer] (Stepping) 	Thread [Producer] (Suspended) 	Thread [Thread-0] (Running)  But there are no children of the Producer Thread, and the Consumer thread should have returned from its step.
my_mothod: Stepping out of an Object.wait() call causes the debugger to hang.  To reproduce:  1. Import sources from wait.zip 2. Debug Main 3. Pause Producer Thread, step over until you are at the line that reads fConsumer.consume(); (Producer.java line 17) 4. Pause Consumer Thread 5. Do a step out on the Consumer Thread 6. Do a step over on the Producer Thread  Now the stack looks like: Main at localhost:13023 	System Thread [Finalizer] (Running) 	System Thread [Reference Handler] (Running) 	System Thread [Signal dispatcher] (Running) 	Thread [Consumer] (Stepping) 	Thread [Producer] (Suspended) 	Thread [Thread-0] (Running)  But there are no children of the Producer Thread, and the Consumer thread should have returned from its step. Stepping out of Object.wait() normal Debug JDT

description: From the newsgroups:  When I try to create a new plugin with the last version of Eclipse, I have some problems to build it because the build.xml reference a external zip command that does not work on my PC. I don't understand why this version of eclipse generate a build.xml that does not support the ant's internal zip and jar task.  May be I do something wrong when I generate the plugIn project ?  Thomas Papiernik
my_mothod: From the newsgroups:  When I try to create a new plugin with the last version of Eclipse, I have some problems to build it because the build.xml reference a external zip command that does not work on my PC. I don't understand why this version of eclipse generate a build.xml that does not support the ant's internal zip and jar task.  May be I do something wrong when I generate the plugIn project ?  Thomas Papiernik External Zip program is called by build.xml even though the program is not available normal Build PDE

description: I tried setting a breakpoint in  org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPage.activatePart(), in the inner class, to  hook into part activation (e.g. clicking between views and editors). It had no effect. Setting it on the first statement worked fine. This code is definitely getting run. Here is the code:  static private void activatePart(final IWorkbenchPart part, final boolean  switchActions, final boolean switchActionsForced) { 	Platform.run(new SafeRunnableAdapter(WorkbenchMessages.getString ("WorkbenchPage.ErrorActivatingView")) { //$NON-NLS-1$ 		public void run() { 			if (part != null) { 				part.setFocus(); 				PartSite site = (PartSite)part.getSite(); 				PartPane pane = site.getPane(); 				pane.showFocus(true); 				SubActionBars bars = (SubActionBars) site.getActionBars(); 				bars.partChanged(part); 				if (switchActions) 					bars.activate(switchActionsForced); 				WorkbenchPage page = (WorkbenchPage)  site.getPage(); 				page.getClientComposite().setTabList(new Control [] { pane.getControl() }); 			} 		} 	}); }

description: build 20011106  -Open org.eclipse.swt.internal.win32.OS.java in the java editor. -Place the cursor somewhere at the beginning of a line near the top of the file -Press and hold the delete key to delete the line ->You should see a reasonably smooth delete operation  -Go a few pages down in the file (within the top 1/8 of the file is enough) -Press and hold the delete key to delete one of the public static fields ->The delete operation is so slow that the screen doesn't update anymore. Something is taking away too many CPU cycles.
my_mothod: build 20011106  -Open org.eclipse.swt.internal.win32.OS.java in the java editor. -Place the cursor somewhere at the beginning of a line near the top of the file -Press and hold the delete key to delete the line ->You should see a reasonably smooth delete operation  -Go a few pages down in the file (within the top 1/8 of the file is enough) -Press and hold the delete key to delete one of the public static fields ->The delete operation is so slow that the screen doesn't update anymore. Something is taking away too many CPU cycles. Java editor is slow to delete in a file with lots of fields normal UI JDT

description: If I use code assist in an anonymous inner type then the proposal is fully qualified even if this is not necessary. This is really annoying since the ful  qualification is 99% of the time not needed. Please make this an option or do  only fully qualify if the qulification is needed. Example:  class A {   Object element;   public void m {     Runnable runnable= new Runnable() {       public void run() {         element<code assist> produces A.this.element          }     }   } }
my_mothod: If I use code assist in an anonymous inner type then the proposal is fully qualified even if this is not necessary. This is really annoying since the ful  qualification is 99% of the time not needed. Please make this an option or do  only fully qualify if the qulification is needed. Example:  class A {   Object element;   public void m {     Runnable runnable= new Runnable() {       public void run() {         element<code assist> produces A.this.element          }     }   } } Code assist should only fully qualify if needed normal Core JDT

description: Build 20011112  I am finding that, when stepping in the debugger, variables do not show up in  the variables view until they are read. They do not show up when first declared and assigned. Here are a couple of examples:  Stepping through StyledText(Composite).setFocus(), in the following lines,  children did not show up in the variables view until I stepped into the for  statement: 	Control [] children = _getChildren (); 	for (int i=0; i<children.length; i++) {  Stepping through WorkbenchPage.setActivePart(IWorkbenchPart), oldPart did not  show up until the third statement below: 	IWorkbenchPart oldPart = activePart; 	activePart = null;		 	if (oldPart != null) { 		deactivatePart(oldPart, switchActions, switchActionsForced); 		firePartDeactivated(oldPart); 	}

description: Build 20011116  - move the text insertion point into the middle of a type name in a Java editor - press F3 - it has no effect  It would be better if it opened on the current word.  (I notice that it currently works for a partial selection, if the selection  includes the start of the type name, as if it's doing code-assist or something.)  This is an issue for keyboard accessibility.  It currently requires you to move  the cursor to the start of the word, hit CTRL+SHIFT+RIGHT to select the word,  then F3.  It would be better if you could just move to the word and hit F3.
my_mothod: Build 20011116  - move the text insertion point into the middle of a type name in a Java editor - press F3 - it has no effect  It would be better if it opened on the current word.  (I notice that it currently works for a partial selection, if the selection  includes the start of the type name, as if it's doing code-assist or something.)  This is an issue for keyboard accessibility.  It currently requires you to move  the cursor to the start of the word, hit CTRL+SHIFT+RIGHT to select the word,  then F3.  It would be better if you could just move to the word and hit F3. Open on selection shouldn't require selection normal Core JDT

description: It is not common for people to use "focus follows mouse" in windows, but I do.   When I happen to move my mouse over any eclipse window, it is popped to the  front of other windows.  To turn on sloppy focus in WinNT, set the following registry var:      HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\Mouse\ActiveWindowTracking = 1 (DWORD)  If it doesn't exist, create it as a DWORD.  Then to test, start eclipse and any other window together.  Make sure the  windows overlap, but you can see parts of both windows.  Now click on the non- eclipse window.  It'll come to the top.  Now just move the mouse over the  eclipse window, and it will be brought to the front without clicking.  Why???   Please disable this.  It should only come to front when clicked on, like all  other apps.
my_mothod: It is not common for people to use "focus follows mouse" in windows, but I do.   When I happen to move my mouse over any eclipse window, it is popped to the  front of other windows.  To turn on sloppy focus in WinNT, set the following registry var:      HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\Mouse\ActiveWindowTracking = 1 (DWORD)  If it doesn't exist, create it as a DWORD.  Then to test, start eclipse and any other window together.  Make sure the  windows overlap, but you can see parts of both windows.  Now click on the non- eclipse window.  It'll come to the top.  Now just move the mouse over the  eclipse window, and it will be brought to the front without clicking.  Why???   Please disable this.  It should only come to front when clicked on, like all  other apps. Workbench is automatically brought to front in focus follows mouse mode enhancement SWT Platform

description: We had the problme that after moving to a new workspace all the installed JRE  got lost. When trying to start an application in this set-up you get the error  message: Cannot Launch Java Application. This isn't helpful. When there is no JRE type installed then this should be told to the user.  It is not understood yet how we lost the installed JRE information, but it  happend to 2 developers up to now.
my_mothod: We had the problme that after moving to a new workspace all the installed JRE  got lost. When trying to start an application in this set-up you get the error  message: Cannot Launch Java Application. This isn't helpful. When there is no JRE type installed then this should be told to the user.  It is not understood yet how we lost the installed JRE information, but it  happend to 2 developers up to now. Insufficient error reporting in JavaApplicationLauncher critical Debug JDT

description: On Integration build 20011127.  Put a breakpoint on the Thread.yield() line of the class below.  Debug the program, you will hit the breakpoint, but you won't get any stack frames.  I have tried this with all of the SUN VMs I have.  To duplicate this bug, you _must_ follow the following steps: 1. New workspace, start eclipse 2. Switch to Java perspective 3. New project, Test 4. New Class, Test in package foo (do not just copy and paste) 5. Paste the methods included below 6. Add breakpoint to the Thread.yield() line. 6.5 Change your VM (mine currently defaults to a JRE) (may not be necessary) 7. Click the Debug button, the debug perspective pops up and shows the debug target. 8. Hit F10 to debug again, I usually get the bug here. 9. You can continue to hit F10, and see the bug.  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		while(true) { 			try { 				throwIt(); 			} catch (Exception e) { 			} 		} 	} 	 	public static void throwIt() throws InterruptedException { 		while(true) { 			Thread.yield(); 		} 	}

description: Build 20011127 Windows NT 4.0 SDK running on IBM JRE 3.0  JDIValue.evaluateToString(IJavaThread) uses wait(long) for timeout in a wrong  way. The spec for this method says that the VM can throw an  InterruptedException at any time (even if the amount of time has not expired.)  Running Eclipse on IBM JRE 3.0, I can see that indeed the VM throws this  exception early (i.e. before the 3000ms of timeout I have set). As a result,  most of the details of the variable show up as <timeout> or <error>.  I would suggest to use the same pattern as in PacketReceiveManager.getCommand (int  command, long timeToWait) to solve this problem.
my_mothod: Build 20011127 Windows NT 4.0 SDK running on IBM JRE 3.0  JDIValue.evaluateToString(IJavaThread) uses wait(long) for timeout in a wrong  way. The spec for this method says that the VM can throw an  InterruptedException at any time (even if the amount of time has not expired.)  Running Eclipse on IBM JRE 3.0, I can see that indeed the VM throws this  exception early (i.e. before the 3000ms of timeout I have set). As a result,  most of the details of the variable show up as <timeout> or <error>.  I would suggest to use the same pattern as in PacketReceiveManager.getCommand (int  command, long timeToWait) to solve this problem. VM Timeout settings normal Debug JDT

description: From Eclipse Corner:  "I am continuing to experience problems with timeouts with both JDK 1.3 and JDK 1.4. I think, however, that I found one resonably reproducible quirk  in this. It seems that when I am connected to the network I do not experience any timouts, but when I am disconnected (I use a laptop), I get the timeouts, though if I try again it does connect to the VM. Any ideas on why this may be happenning, and how to solve it?"

description: From the newsgroup:  I just tried it on 1127, and it wouldn't break for me.  I tested the following code:  public class Test1 {     public static void main(String[] arguments) {         new Test1().fork("What?");     }      protected void fork(final String message) {         Runnable runnable = new Runnable() {             public void run() {                 System.out.println(message);  // BREAKPOINT 1                 breakpoint();             }         };         new Thread(runnable).start();     }      protected void breakpoint()     {         System.out.println("break here");  // BREAKPOINT 2     } }  Breakpoint 1 was not hit.  Breakpoint 2 was hit.

description: Linux 7.1 Build 1206  If you get hover help over a type in a JavaEditor on Linux occasionally the  help box will not go away and you will no longer get focus on any of your  windows.  STEPS  In the following class  import java.io.FileOutputStream;  public class FileTest { 	 	public static void main(String[] args){ 		FileOutputStream stream = new FileOutputStream("~/fred.txt"); 	}   I hovered over FileOutputStream and got the help box which gave me the  qualified name. However moving the mouse did not get rid of this - it remained  on my desktop even after I killed Eclipse.  I have not as of yet been able to replicate this.

description: Build: 2001-12-06, Win2000.  Sorry, I have very little information to go on.  I was working away, and I got a  very generic "Internal Error" dialog... it gave no interesting information  (check log).  When I clicked OK on that dialog, the VM immediately exited. description: Test program:  public class InfiniteLoop { 	public static void main(String[] args) { 		(new InfiniteLoop()).loop(); 	}  	public void loop() { 		int i = 0; 		while (true) { 			System.out.println("Looping " + i); 			i++; 		} 	} }  Steps: * put a breakpoint on the println statement * debug to the breakpoint * activate the variables view  * remove the breakpoint * hold down the F6 key - stepping works as expected * stop stepping * active the inspector view * hold down the F6 key - stepping continues * while holding down the F6 key, activate the variables view * the thread now "hangs" on "stepping" * pressing "resume" on the thread seems to bring it back to life
my_mothod: Test program:  public class InfiniteLoop { 	public static void main(String[] args) { 		(new InfiniteLoop()).loop(); 	}  	public void loop() { 		int i = 0; 		while (true) { 			System.out.println("Looping " + i); 			i++; 		} 	} }  Steps: * put a breakpoint on the println statement * debug to the breakpoint * activate the variables view  * remove the breakpoint * hold down the F6 key - stepping works as expected * stop stepping * active the inspector view * hold down the F6 key - stepping continues * while holding down the F6 key, activate the variables view * the thread now "hangs" on "stepping" * pressing "resume" on the thread seems to bring it back to life Thread remains as "stepping" normal Debug JDT

description: 20011206  I was in a loop that was populating an array (I'll paste the loop below, for  reference). I had the array expanded in the Variables pane and I was watching  the values fill the array as they were read. Each time through the loop, I  would start clicking on the "Step Over" tool fairly quickly (I really should  have had a breakpoint on the 7th line, but I was being lazy and figured I could  click on "Step over" 7 times quickly instead). After 3 or 4 clicks, I suddenly  had no more Step tools - they were all disabled. I could still resume, so I  added a breakpoint and clicked Resume, and the UI acted like the "Step over"  was completed. i.e. I had Step tools again and things were normal. This is very  repeatable - the next time through the loop (numIcons == 6) I was easily able  to click quickly a few times on "Step over" and get into the same limbo state.  FYI, here is the loop where I saw the problem. If a simple test case does not  show the problem right away (I suspect it will), then just ask me and we can  set you up to run this exact loop.  	int[][] headers = new int[numIcons][7]; 	try { 		for (int i = 0; i < numIcons; i++) { 			headers[i][0] = inputStream.read(); 			headers[i][1] = inputStream.read(); 			headers[i][2] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][3] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][4] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][5] = inputStream.readInt(); 			headers[i][6] = inputStream.readInt(); 		} 	} catch (IOException e) { 		SWT.error(SWT.ERROR_IO, e); 	}
my_mothod: 20011206  I was in a loop that was populating an array (I'll paste the loop below, for  reference). I had the array expanded in the Variables pane and I was watching  the values fill the array as they were read. Each time through the loop, I  would start clicking on the "Step Over" tool fairly quickly (I really should  have had a breakpoint on the 7th line, but I was being lazy and figured I could  click on "Step over" 7 times quickly instead). After 3 or 4 clicks, I suddenly  had no more Step tools - they were all disabled. I could still resume, so I  added a breakpoint and clicked Resume, and the UI acted like the "Step over"  was completed. i.e. I had Step tools again and things were normal. This is very  repeatable - the next time through the loop (numIcons == 6) I was easily able  to click quickly a few times on "Step over" and get into the same limbo state.  FYI, here is the loop where I saw the problem. If a simple test case does not  show the problem right away (I suspect it will), then just ask me and we can  set you up to run this exact loop.  	int[][] headers = new int[numIcons][7]; 	try { 		for (int i = 0; i < numIcons; i++) { 			headers[i][0] = inputStream.read(); 			headers[i][1] = inputStream.read(); 			headers[i][2] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][3] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][4] = inputStream.readShort(); 			headers[i][5] = inputStream.readInt(); 			headers[i][6] = inputStream.readInt(); 		} 	} catch (IOException e) { 		SWT.error(SWT.ERROR_IO, e); 	} Debugger: Clicking too quickly on Step tool disables Step tools normal Debug Platform

If it's not possible to make it faster, it would be usefull to have the option  to turn off the javadoc tooltip, and leave the source in jre-setting for  debugging. I'm using a p2-233 with 256MB. Version 20011206.

description: Add a breakpoint. Open debug perspective. Open the java file the breakpoint is  in. Double-click on the breakpoint in the margin of the editor. The breakpoint  disappears from the breakpoints view, but does not disappear from the editor.  Scroll the editor around; the breakpoint disappears. Similar situation for  adding breakpoints. Build 1211.
my_mothod: Add a breakpoint. Open debug perspective. Open the java file the breakpoint is  in. Double-click on the breakpoint in the margin of the editor. The breakpoint  disappears from the breakpoints view, but does not disappear from the editor.  Scroll the editor around; the breakpoint disappears. Similar situation for  adding breakpoints. Build 1211. Breakpoints don't disappear or reappear automatically in debug perspective normal Debug JDT

description: When creating a jar with .class and .java files, WSWB generates an Null pointer  exception.  Steps to reproduce problem:  1. create a java project named "bug1" 2. extract the attached bug.jar to some temporary directory. 3. copy the java file Person.java and class files Person.class and  Person_Pickler_Vj.class to the project "bug1" directory.  select the bug1  project, and do a refresh from local. 4. do File/Export/Jar on project bug1, you should be able to get a  NullPointerException. p.s. Note that Person_Pickler_Vj.class is IMPORTANT. This class file  does not have corresponding source file.
my_mothod: When creating a jar with .class and .java files, WSWB generates an Null pointer  exception.  Steps to reproduce problem:  1. create a java project named "bug1" 2. extract the attached bug.jar to some temporary directory. 3. copy the java file Person.java and class files Person.class and  Person_Pickler_Vj.class to the project "bug1" directory.  select the bug1  project, and do a refresh from local. 4. do File/Export/Jar on project bug1, you should be able to get a  NullPointerException. p.s. Note that Person_Pickler_Vj.class is IMPORTANT. This class file  does not have corresponding source file. 1GOMQ6H:- NullPointerException when exporting to a jar normal UI JDT

description: Writing a lot of data to the console crashes Eclipse. To replicate, run the following main:  public static void main(String[] args){   File file = new File("c:\\temp\\log.txt");   OutputStream os = null;   PrintStream ps = null;   try {     os = new FileOutputStream(file);     ps = new PrintStream(os);     String alphabet = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";     for(int i = 0; true; ++i){       ps.println(i);       System.out.println(i + " " + alphabet);     }   } catch(IOException e){     e.printStackTrace();   } finally {     if(ps == null){       if(os != null){         try {           os.close();         } catch(IOException e){         }       }     } else {       ps.close();     }   } }  When I ran this test on my machine Eclipse crashed at i=170276.

To replicate, run the following main:  public static void main(String[] args){   File file = new File("c:\\temp\\log.txt");   OutputStream os = null;   PrintStream ps = null;   try {     os = new FileOutputStream(file);     ps = new PrintStream(os);     String alphabet = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";     for(int i = 0; true; ++i){       ps.println(i);       System.out.println(i + " " + alphabet);     }   } catch(IOException e){     e.printStackTrace();   } finally {     if(ps == null){       if(os != null){         try {           os.close();         } catch(IOException e){         }       }     } else {       ps.close();     }   } }  When I ran this test on my machine Eclipse crashed at i=170276. Writing a lot of data to the console crashes Eclipse (console overflow) normal Debug Platform

description: After a hotswap, we should only pop frames that are obsolete. We should be able  to improve our dopping behavior by improving out "obsolete" detection. It might  be possible to compare method byte codes before/after a hotswap (at least on  J9).  Otherwise, we should be able to use fine grained deltas (based on resource  history) to determine which frames to drop.
my_mothod: After a hotswap, we should only pop frames that are obsolete. We should be able  to improve our dopping behavior by improving out "obsolete" detection. It might  be possible to compare method byte codes before/after a hotswap (at least on  J9).  Otherwise, we should be able to use fine grained deltas (based on resource  history) to determine which frames to drop. Smart frame dropping after HCR normal Debug JDT

description: build 20011206  The debugger seems to be leaking huge amounts of memory. When I start a program (SwtStyledTextUseCase) in debug mode the Eclipse memory  load increases by about 8MB. When I quit the debug session the memory load  decreases by less than 1MB. When I do the same in run mode the memory load goes  back to about where it was before. I can repeat this about 12 times until I reach the heap size limit and Eclipse  dies a slow death (see bug 7006). This means I have to restart Eclipse after  about 12 debug sessions.

description: Hi,  In my opinion, the stop-sign icon (the one that denotes problems in the code)  should be clickable.  What i mean is that I, as a user, should be able to click  the stop-sign icon and then see what the problem is, instead of having to look  at the tasks window at the bottom.  Since you have already set it up that  Ctrl+E and Ctrl+Shift+E show you the problem's description in the status bar at  the bottom, it should be so hard to add this functionality to the sign-sign  icon. I personally find it pretty annoying that clicking on the stop-sign creates a  break-point behind it without showing the break-point icon.  If you create a  break-point in that line, you might as well show it to me, right?  Thanks,  Jonathan Amir

I personally find it pretty annoying that clicking on the stop-sign creates a  break-point behind it without showing the break-point icon.  If you create a  break-point in that line, you might as well show it to me, right?  Thanks,  Jonathan Amir Stop icon should be clickable trivial UI Platform

description: build 137  Create a complete (but very simple) plugin, with Project name Foo, say; run it  and observe that it works; decide to experiment with renaming items -- choose to  rename the autogenerated class FooPlugin.java, hit Next, and get the stack trace  below.  Repeatable, and does not depend on the exact new name entered (if you  enter a name which causes a problem, e.g. by collision or violating a  convention, you get the warning panel before the call stack).  The plugin is  left in a working state (i.e., nothing seems to have actually changed).   It may be that this class should never be renamed, but if so, this is an odd way  to signal that! description: Build 2002-01-09 IBM JRE 1.3.0  I was debugging a second instance of Eclipse.  A breakpoint was hit, and when I  pressed F6 to step over, I got an error dialog:  Title: Step over Message: Exceptions occurred attempting to step over frame Reason: Step over failed  Detail: com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException: Thread was not suspended.  occurred retrieving stack frames.  No log file entry was created.  When I hit F6 again after closing the dialog, it  worked fine.  I have not been able to reproduce it yet.

description: An error occurs in the workbench when it tries to open a project file that has  Japanese characters in its name.  To reproduce: 1.	Create a file with Japanese characters in its name in a project  directory 2.	In the Navigator, select the project and choose menu item Refresh From  Local 3.	The file appears in the navigator, but with each Japanese character  replaced with a “?”. 4.	Open the file. A File Not Found error occurs.
my_mothod: An error occurs in the workbench when it tries to open a project file that has  Japanese characters in its name.  To reproduce: 1.	Create a file with Japanese characters in its name in a project  directory 2.	In the Navigator, select the project and choose menu item Refresh From  Local 3.	The file appears in the navigator, but with each Japanese character  replaced with a “?”. 4.	Open the file. A File Not Found error occurs. Cannot open a file that has Japanese characters in its name. normal Resources Platform

description: build 20020115  It is possible to move a package to the project it is already in via drag 'n  drop. The drop should not be allowed. Currently there is a variety of bizarre behavior because the drop is allowed: -if the package is empty this operation results in the package being deleted  without confirmation of any kind -if the package does not contain any Java elements I get an error message "Core  exception: Problems encountered while moving resources" and all resources in  that package are lost -if the package contains at least one Java element a confirmation to overwrite  the existing package pops up. If I select yes, I get the same error as above  and all resources in the package are lost
my_mothod: build 20020115  It is possible to move a package to the project it is already in via drag 'n  drop. The drop should not be allowed. Currently there is a variety of bizarre behavior because the drop is allowed: -if the package is empty this operation results in the package being deleted  without confirmation of any kind -if the package does not contain any Java elements I get an error message "Core  exception: Problems encountered while moving resources" and all resources in  that package are lost -if the package contains at least one Java element a confirmation to overwrite  the existing package pops up. If I select yes, I get the same error as above  and all resources in the package are lost Drag moving a package into same project results in data loss critical UI Platform

description: Build 20020124  Evaluation (inspect or display) isn't working for me at all.  I debug my target application (Eclipse) to a breakpoint. The thread shows as suspended and all stack frames appear. With a stack frame selected, the stepping buttons in the debug view are enabled. If I attempt an evaluation, either by highlighting text in the Java editor or typing it in the Display view and choosing Display or Inspect, I get an error dialog: Title - Error evaluating Message - Thread not suspended, stack frame unavailable  After I dismiss the dialog, the thread and stack frame are still visible in the debug view, but if I select a stack frame the stepping buttons are disabled - only the resume and terminate buttons are enabled. I *can* still step with the thread selected, however, which results in a correct step and the stack frames being returned to normal (stepping enabled).

description: The editor-pane (also editing a template in the preferences) change the color  (from normaly white to gray) of the actual line during writing or scrolling  for a short time (repaint ?). I would mean, thats double-buffering not activated is.  If i move the text-cursor to one end of the viewed text in the editor-pane and they scrolled, then funcionozed the repainting not correctly, on any positions still exists the vertical text-cursor-line. They first cleared, if i write again.  It's exists a focus-problem. If i click into the editor-pane, i can write and so on, but the editor-pane tab don't the focus and also the information in the status-line the old, not the informations from the editor-pane (writable, insert/override, line/column) First a click on the editor-pane tab give the focus correctly and write  the informations in the status-line.  I would like have a another background-color (as white). Is it possible do  change the background-color (for all windows, or just the editor-pane) ? A option in the preferences would like ideal. For me would it okay, if the background-color a light-gray.

description: I'm using Eclipse 20020125 with Team Support plugins and JDK 1.3.1_02.  When trying to update a 10.5MB binary file called "cocoon.war" from a CVS repository, Eclipse gets the file from the server ("Receiving file cocoon.war (10,623K of 10,625K)") but before the "Updating" dialog disappears, Eclipse displays a dialog that says, simply "Internal error".  The cocoon.war file ends up being 0KB (presumably it's just not closed).  The CVS console simply displays:  ? lib/cocoon.war U lib/cocoon.war  without any error messages.
my_mothod: I'm using Eclipse 20020125 with Team Support plugins and JDK 1.3.1_02.  When trying to update a 10.5MB binary file called "cocoon.war" from a CVS repository, Eclipse gets the file from the server ("Receiving file cocoon.war (10,623K of 10,625K)") but before the "Updating" dialog disappears, Eclipse displays a dialog that says, simply "Internal error".  The cocoon.war file ends up being 0KB (presumably it's just not closed).  The CVS console simply displays:  ? lib/cocoon.war U lib/cocoon.war  without any error messages. Internal error when trying to update large file from CVS critical Team Platform

description: This might be a problem for the JDT gang, but it seems to only be appearing in the GTK version.  Open up a java workspace, and select a method (click once).  Left click to bring up the context menu, go down to "References" and search in the workspace or hierarchy or whatever.  If you have just opened the workspace, the program will beep.  I guess signalling  nothing found.    If you double click on the method instead (not quite sure the difference, though I think double clicking causes the method's name to be selected in the editor pane).  Then try finding the references again. It will find them.  The real problem is after a reference has been found-- you usually click twice on it to bring it up in the editor to look at.  Then if you go over to the overview pane again and either (a) click once to select and then right click on a method or (b) just right click on a method, you will instead find that when you search for references again, you will bring up the references that is highlighted in the editor. Quite confusing!

If you double click on the method instead (not quite sure the difference, though I think double clicking causes the method's name to be selected in the editor pane).  Then try finding the references again. It will find them.  The real problem is after a reference has been found-- you usually click twice on it to bring it up in the editor to look at. description: Build 20020129  From the newsgroup, here's an example of a startup problem which could be better handled by eclipse. It should check the jre/jdk version first. Since this can't be done in eclipse.exe, since you have to be running Java in  order to determine the version, we should do it in the workbench on startup.   "Darin Wright" <darin_wright@oti.com> wrote in message news:<a2hv80$fmv$1@rogue.oti.com>... > The error message: > > > 4 org.eclipse.jdt.ui 1 Internal Error > > java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException: > > java.lang.NoSuchMethodError > > indicates to me that you are running Eclipse on a JDK1.2.x VM. You need to > run Eclipse on JDK1.3. Eclipse itself no longer runs on 1.2.x, as we rely on > 1.3 APIs. > > The errors with ProcessView are expected, as the ProcessView has been > removed. Please see the latest Platform Debug Build Notes. > > Darin > > "Michael Moser" <nospam-mmo@zurich.ibm.com-nospam> wrote in message > news:a2htv8$f9f$1@rogue.oti.com... > > Hi folks, > > I just downloaded and installed the last integration build. description: Take the following test case: [public class Test { 	public static final String STRCONST1 =  "1"; 	public static final String STRCONST2 = "2"; 	public static final String MYSTRCONST =  STRCONST2;  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		if (MYSTRCONST == STRCONST1)  { 			System.out.println("STRCONST1"); 		} else if (MYSTRCONST == STRCONST2)  { 			System.out.println("STRCONST2"); 		} else  { 			System.out.println("OTHER"); 		} 	} }]  Compiler it with javac 1.3.1 and run  it: You get: STRCONST2  With Eclipse 20020125, you get: STRCONST1  The right value  is STRCONST2.

description: We have an application that launches a command-line process using  Runtime.exec(), then uses Process.getInputStream() to read what is output on the  console.  It has a loop waiting for the stream to be ready() before actually  trying to read any input.  When running this application from the command line  or from Kawa (our hopefully soon-to-be-previous Java development environment),  this works fine.  However, when running (or debugging) under Eclipse, the call  to ready() never succeeds.  This is done during the startup of our application, so we are completely unable  to run or debug using Eclipse because of this problem.  Here is a small, self-contained example program that illustrates the problem.   If you run or debug this in Eclipse, it will hang on the while(!in.ready())  loop.  If you run from the command line, using the class file compiled by  Eclipse, the program runs to completion.  I am using Eclipse 2.0 latest stable build (01/25/2002) and Sun's JDK 1.3.0.  import java.io.*;  public class BugTest { 	public BugTest() 	{ 		super(); 	}  	public static void main(String[] args) 	{ 		try 		{ 			System.out.println("Running command..."); 			Process p = (Runtime.getRuntime()).exec("command.com /C  ipconfig /all"); 			BufferedReader in = 				new BufferedReader(new  InputStreamReader(p.getInputStream())); 			while (!in.ready()) 			{ 			} 			System.out.println("Will never get here.");  			while (in.ready()) 			{ 				System.out.println(in.readLine()); 			} 			p.destroy(); 		} 		catch (Exception e) 		{ 			System.out.println(e.getMessage()); 			e.printStackTrace(); 		} 	} }

description: 1) Select a method in a type, i.e. all viewers are populated, editor is visible 2) Deactivate linking between active editor and navigator in workbench  preferences 3) Deactivate auto build 3) Prespective>Show View>Navigator 4) Pin Navigator 5) Select the file of the previously selected method 6) Context Menu>Delete -> Method View flushed, Editor closed -> Type still visible in Types View ->Selecting Type possible and results in small red square in Methods View
my_mothod: 1) Select a method in a type, i.e. all viewers are populated, editor is visible 2) Deactivate linking between active editor and navigator in workbench  preferences 3) Deactivate auto build 3) Prespective>Show View>Navigator 4) Pin Navigator 5) Select the file of the previously selected method 6) Context Menu>Delete -> Method View flushed, Editor closed -> Type still visible in Types View ->Selecting Type possible and results in small red square in Methods View [Java Browsing] Types View not updated on deletion normal UI JDT

description: 1) Select a method in a type, i.e. all viewers are populated, editor is visible 2) Deactivate linking between active editor and navigator in workbench  preferences 3) Deactivate auto build 3) Prespective>Show View>Navigator 4) Pin Navigator 5) Select the folder containing the file of the previously selected method 6) Context Menu>Delete -> Editor closed -> Package, type, and method still visible in their views -> Selecting package possible and results in flushing Types View
my_mothod: 1) Select a method in a type, i.e. all viewers are populated, editor is visible 2) Deactivate linking between active editor and navigator in workbench  preferences 3) Deactivate auto build 3) Prespective>Show View>Navigator 4) Pin Navigator 5) Select the folder containing the file of the previously selected method 6) Context Menu>Delete -> Editor closed -> Package, type, and method still visible in their views -> Selecting package possible and results in flushing Types View [Java Browsing]  Views not updated when folder of package is deleted normal UI JDT

description: I switched to it in an empty workspace, generated binary projects using PDE,  opened CVS repository view (Team 2.0), added org.eclipse.ui and example  projects. Nothing appeared. Switch to Java perspective. Things were there and had Java icons. Switched back to Java Browser perspective. The packages appeared, but the projects view was still empty. Closed and reopened Projects view. The projects appeared.

description: change the background color of java editor it has no effect on compare viewers. however, changing foreground (for keywords for instance) colors does  same applies to:  1. code formatter pref page 2. template pref pages and all other views where we show source code  like refactoring error page or NLS wizard  so it's a more general problem
my_mothod: change the background color of java editor it has no effect on compare viewers. however, changing foreground (for keywords for instance) colors does  same applies to:  1. code formatter pref page 2. template pref pages and all other views where we show source code  like refactoring error page or NLS wizard  so it's a more general problem editor background color - no effect on other viewers normal UI JDT

description: Pop up the Search dialog. Select the Help Search tab. Notice under the text box the label reads:   * = any string; ? = any character; "" = phrase; AND, OR, NOT, () = boolean  operators  The label is subtly different from those of the Java Search and Text Search tabs.  They read:   * = any string, ? = any character   * = any string, ? = any character, \ = escape for literals: * ? \  Notice they use commas to separate the individual fields.  (Picky, I know!) Since the list is getting crowded, I'd recommend a 2 line label such as:   * = any string, ? = any character, "" = phrase, \ = escape for literals: * ? \   AND OR NOT () = boolean operators
my_mothod: Pop up the Search dialog. Select the Help Search tab. Notice under the text box the label reads:   * = any string; ? = any character; "" = phrase; AND, OR, NOT, () = boolean  operators  The label is subtly different from those of the Java Search and Text Search tabs.  They read:   * = any string, ? = any character   * = any string, ? = any character, \ = escape for literals: * ? \  Notice they use commas to separate the individual fields.  (Picky, I know!) Since the list is getting crowded, I'd recommend a 2 line label such as:   * = any string, ? = any character, "" = phrase, \ = escape for literals: * ? \   AND OR NOT () = boolean operators Minor label inconsistency in Help Search panel trivial User Assistance Platform

description: Build 20020212  1) Start with following classes:  public class A {   public A(String s) {}   public void foo() {} } public class B {}  2) Open an editor on class B 3) In the content outline, select Override Methods -> foo 4) Now select "Add Constructors From Superclass"  The result is below.  The constructor gets inserted between the method comment  and the method body.  This is probably because "Override Methods" creates  non-javadoc method comments.  	/* 	 * @see A#foo() 	 */ 	/** 	 * Constructor for B. 	 * @param s 	 */ 	public B(String s) { 		super(s); 	} 	public void foo() { 		super.foo(); 	} }

description: Current code is:  public void dispose() {     for (Iterator iter= fRegistry.values().iterator(); iter.hasNext(); ) { 	Image image= (Image)iter.next(); 	image.dispose();     } }  Statement fRegistry.clear() missing after dispose  Current implementation doesn't cause harm since calling dispose on a dispose  image is ignored.  Must be fixed after M3

Must be fixed after M3 ImageDescriptorRegistry must empty hash map in dispose normal UI JDT

description: Let me begin by stating what we're trying to do. Compare With->Repository Contents is an ideal place to reconcile differences  locally. Simple changes are easy, but additions and deletions are problematic.  We would like to be able to copy an addition or deletion right-to-left, save,  and have the resource created or deleted appropriately.  We identify at least two barriers to this:  1. In the addition case (where we have an existing repository node on the  right and a non-existing resource node on the left), setContents() is not  called on the node because, for example, the compare text viewer checks if the  resource exists before calling setContents().  2. In the case of copying a deleted remote file from right-to-left and saving,  we cannot distinguish the empty content case from the deletion case. In both  cases, setContents is passed a zero-byte array. We would like to have some way  to tell the difference between these two cases.  If you have any suggestions about how this can be resolved (either by Compare,  or by us, or both), we'd appreciate it.
my_mothod: Let me begin by stating what we're trying to do. Compare With->Repository Contents is an ideal place to reconcile differences  locally. Simple changes are easy, but additions and deletions are problematic.  We would like to be able to copy an addition or deletion right-to-left, save,  and have the resource created or deleted appropriately.  We identify at least two barriers to this:  1. In the addition case (where we have an existing repository node on the  right and a non-existing resource node on the left), setContents() is not  called on the node because, for example, the compare text viewer checks if the  resource exists before calling setContents().  2. In the case of copying a deleted remote file from right-to-left and saving,  we cannot distinguish the empty content case from the deletion case. In both  cases, setContents is passed a zero-byte array. We would like to have some way  to tell the difference between these two cases.  If you have any suggestions about how this can be resolved (either by Compare,  or by us, or both), we'd appreciate it. Need more support for creating/deleting resources normal Compare Platform

description: Hi,  I am unable to get the Eclipse remote debugger to attach to a running JAVA  process (its a WAS process so this should be important). description: When installing JRockit 3.1.3 (http://www.jrockit.com/download/) as JRE, and  launching Java applications in Eclipse (stable build 20020214), Eclipse never  understands that the JVM is launched. This worked well in the previous stable  build. It also works well with older versions of JRockit.  The problems demonstrates itself in the following ways:  * When pressing the "Running man" button, and starting the run wizard, after  clicking Finish the following happens:  - The program starts  - The run wizard flashes briefly, but stays at the last page. Each press  on "Finish" starts a new instance of the program.  - The program does not show up in the debug view.   * When relaunching a program from the Run History with the JRE set to JRockit  3.1.3, the program starts, but it does not show up in the debug view.  As suggested by Darin Swanson, I tried copying the command line for the working  JRockit 2.2, modifying it for JRockit 3.1.3, and running it with cmd.exe. That  succeeded without problems, after I had "" around the command name due to  spaces in the path, and changed from javaw.exe to java.exe for getting better  feedback. (I've also tried renaming javaw.exe to force Eclipse to use java.exe - - perhaps it should be possible to specify the executable more explicitly in  the JRE settings?) Resulting output for JRockit 2.2:  L:\>"C:\Program Files\JRockit\JRE_1.3.1\bin\java.exe" -classpath C:\Workspace\Sl ask;C:\Workspace\ToolsConsole;C:\Workspace\JUnit;C:\Workspace\ToolsCommon;C:\Wor kspace\Xerces;C:\Workspace\Xerces\xercesImpl.jar;C:\Workspace\Xerces\xmlParserAP Is.jar;C:\Workspace\JFreeChart;C:\Workspace\JavaMail;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\imap. jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\mail.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\mailapi.jar;C:\Workspac e\JavaMail\pop3.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\smtp.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\activat ion.jar net.ihse.test.RunAndQuit JRockit build 2.2.1-EXCELSIOR-20011023-1345, Thin Threads, Generational Concurre nt Garbage Collector, started.   L:\>  Resulting output for JRockit 3.1.3: L:\>"C:\Program Files\JRockit\JRE\1.3.1 noWin\bin\java.exe" -classpath C:\Worksp ace\Slask;C:\Workspace\ToolsConsole;C:\Workspace\JUnit;C:\Workspace\ToolsCommon; C:\Workspace\Xerces;C:\Workspace\Xerces\xercesImpl.jar;C:\Workspace\Xerces\xmlPa rserAPIs.jar;C:\Workspace\JFreeChart;C:\Workspace\JavaMail;C:\Workspace\JavaMail \imap.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\mail.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\mailapi.jar;C:\Wo rkspace\JavaMail\pop3.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\smtp.jar;C:\Workspace\JavaMail\a ctivation.jar net.ihse.test.RunAndQuit JRockit build 3.1.3-CROSIS-20020207-1213, Native Threads, Generational Concurren t Garbage Collector, started.   L:\>

description: I am opening this PR because an older PR containing this problem was just  marked resolved/worksforme, which is not entirely accurate. The older PR is:  http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=3750 It is ok to close the older PR because the menu ordering problem has been  corrected, but the "missing menu items" problem is still very much there.  As of 20020214-Stable build:  Go To -> Type... is missing from the Hierarchy view Open With -> is missing from Class in Packages view Copy Names is missing from the Hierarchy view Cut is missing from CU in Packages view Move is missing from Type in Packages and in Hierarchy view 	(should be able to move the type or the whole CU) Run/Debug is missing from the Hierarchy view But the most important missing thing from any Type is *all* of the TEAM  functions, including the whole Team -> menu, and team items in the Compare  With -> menu, and Replace With -> menu.  I will paste a bitmap of 3 menus side-by-side so that you can easily see where  the gaps are. In this diagram, the menu on the left is the CU menu in the  Packages view, the menu in the middle is the Type menu in the Packages view,  and the menu on the right is the Type menu in the Hierarchy view. Ideally, all  menus on Types and CUs in all perspectives should be analyzed in this visual  manner - I have not used the new VAJ perspective much yet (waiting for the  types to be displayed in a hierarchy) so I did not analyze those menus, but I  suspect strongly that we will discover inconsistencies and gaps if we look.  Please, if you don't do anything else, add team support to Types. This was done  in VAME and it made a huge difference. There is less mental and actual context  switch required. The current implementation in Eclipse reveals that there is a  framework behind everything, and we do not want to let this show. The user  should have a seamless experience without so many context switches. The 90%  case is that the CU/Type ratio is 1:1. In the other 10% case, the tools should  be able to figure out what the user meant, or if it is unclear, then just ask  them.

In this diagram, the menu on the left is the CU menu in the  Packages view, the menu in the middle is the Type menu in the Packages view,  and the menu on the right is the Type menu in the Hierarchy view. Ideally, all  menus on Types and CUs in all perspectives should be analyzed in this visual  manner - I have not used the new VAJ perspective much yet (waiting for the  types to be displayed in a hierarchy) so I did not analyze those menus, but I  suspect strongly that we will discover inconsistencies and gaps if we look.  Please, if you don't do anything else, add team support to Types. This was done  in VAME and it made a huge difference. There is less mental and actual context  switch required. The current implementation in Eclipse reveals that there is a  framework behind everything, and we do not want to let this show. The user  should have a seamless experience without so many context switches. The 90%  case is that the CU/Type ratio is 1:1. In the other 10% case, the tools should  be able to figure out what the user meant, or if it is unclear, then just ask  them. Classes should have the same actions as CU's wherever possible normal UI JDT

description: Reported by Philippe:  "When launching a run of Eclipse in Eclipse, I see the memory usage of my dev  IDE (java VM) jump from 80MB to 130MB, when the target only takes about 32MB. Is there any reason for this to occur ? I would expect no overhead on the dev  side." (Run mode, jdk1.4fcs).

Is there any reason for this to occur ? I would expect no overhead on the dev  side." (Run mode, jdk1.4fcs). memory footprint when launching jdk1.4 normal Debug JDT

description: The 'typecomment' template has the following default value:  /**  * @version 	1.0  * @author  */  The 'filecomment' template has the following default value:  /*  * (c) Copyright 2001 MyCorporation.  * All Rights Reserved.  */  Both of these templates are on by default. This leads to the Java editor adding inappropriate comments to every source file generated.  Recommended behavior: (1) The default 'typecomment' template should be completely empty. (2) The default 'filecomment' template should be completely empty. (3) Both templates should be on by default. With empty templates, bogus class javadoc and file header comments will be not generated.  This means that a user that actually changes these templates to have suitable values will automatically reap the benefits.

This leads to the Java editor adding inappropriate comments to every source file generated.  Recommended behavior: (1) The default 'typecomment' template should be completely empty. (2) The default 'filecomment' template should be completely empty. (3) Both templates should be on by default. With empty templates, bogus class javadoc and file header comments will be not generated.  This means that a user that actually changes these templates to have suitable values will automatically reap the benefits. Do not provide inappropiate default templates normal UI JDT

description: I just upgraded to 20020214 driver and the DebuggerSourceLookupPath is no longer respected. It will only find things in the Java Build Path. If source for something can't be found, a dialog pops up to ask where is the source, but no matter what you set in there, it is ignored and the source can't be found. In my case I dynamically load some classes that are not in the build path (I do it through a classloader classpath) and I know where the source is, but it won't let me get to it.  Here's a simple testcase:  1) Create a java project with src/bin directories. 2) Create a package test.staticguy. 3) In this package place this class:  package test.staticguy;  import java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException; import java.lang.reflect.Method; import java.net.MalformedURLException; import java.net.URL; import java.net.URLClassLoader;  /**  * 1) Export the dynamicFolder to the "C" drive.  * 2) Execute and try to step into the invoke method.  *    It will ask you where is the source, point to  *    the "c:/dynamicFolder/src" directory. In 0125  *    driver this works, in the 0214 driver it does not.  */ public class MainGuy {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		try { 			URL dynamicBinPath = new URL ("file:/c:/dynamicFolder/bin/");  			URLClassLoader cl = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] {  dynamicBinPath }); 			Class testGuyClass = cl.loadClass ("test1.dynamic.TestDynamic");  			Object testGuy = testGuyClass.newInstance(); 			Method method1 = testGuyClass.getMethod("Method1",  null); 			method1.invoke(testGuy, null); 		} catch (Exception e) { 			e.printStackTrace(); 		}  	} }  4) Separately compile (not in the above project) the following class:  package test1.dynamic; /**  * @version 	1.0  * @author  */ public class TestDynamic { 	 	public void Method1() { 		System.out.println("This is method1"); 	}  }  5) Create a directory c:/dynamicFolder/bin and c:/dynamicFolder/src 6) Put the TestDynamic.java into the c:/dynamicFolder/src/test1/dynamic  directory 7) Put the TestDynamic.class into the c:/dynamicFolder/bin/test1/dynamic  directory  8) Finally try debugging MainGuy and step into the invoke method. It will  prompt for src location. In 0125 driver this works in 0214 it does not.  Thank you, Rich Kulp
my_mothod: I just upgraded to 20020214 driver and the DebuggerSourceLookupPath is no longer respected. It will only find things in the Java Build Path. If source for something can't be found, a dialog pops up to ask where is the source, but no matter what you set in there, it is ignored and the source can't be found. In my case I dynamically load some classes that are not in the build path (I do it through a classloader classpath) and I know where the source is, but it won't let me get to it.  Here's a simple testcase:  1) Create a java project with src/bin directories. 2) Create a package test.staticguy. 3) In this package place this class:  package test.staticguy;  import java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException; import java.lang.reflect.Method; import java.net.MalformedURLException; import java.net.URL; import java.net.URLClassLoader;  /**  * 1) Export the dynamicFolder to the "C" drive.  * 2) Execute and try to step into the invoke method.  *    It will ask you where is the source, point to  *    the "c:/dynamicFolder/src" directory. In 0125  *    driver this works, in the 0214 driver it does not.  */ public class MainGuy {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		try { 			URL dynamicBinPath = new URL ("file:/c:/dynamicFolder/bin/");  			URLClassLoader cl = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] {  dynamicBinPath }); 			Class testGuyClass = cl.loadClass ("test1.dynamic.TestDynamic");  			Object testGuy = testGuyClass.newInstance(); 			Method method1 = testGuyClass.getMethod("Method1",  null); 			method1.invoke(testGuy, null); 		} catch (Exception e) { 			e.printStackTrace(); 		}  	} }  4) Separately compile (not in the above project) the following class:  package test1.dynamic; /**  * @version 	1.0  * @author  */ public class TestDynamic { 	 	public void Method1() { 		System.out.println("This is method1"); 	}  }  5) Create a directory c:/dynamicFolder/bin and c:/dynamicFolder/src 6) Put the TestDynamic.java into the c:/dynamicFolder/src/test1/dynamic  directory 7) Put the TestDynamic.class into the c:/dynamicFolder/bin/test1/dynamic  directory  8) Finally try debugging MainGuy and step into the invoke method. It will  prompt for src location. In 0125 driver this works in 0214 it does not.  Thank you, Rich Kulp Debug into non-JavaBuildPath no longer works. critical Debug JDT

description: New class and interface is beeing added in 20020305-I build,  org.eclipse.update.configuration.LocalSystemInfo/ ILocalSystemInfoListener.  These implement methods for obtaining available space, volume labels and types,  plus a listener for notification when file system has changed (removable drives,  media, mount points).  We should support this in the UI as follows:  * install/ update wizard should show available/ required/ to-download space in  the site-selection list (should show as table with "site", "available space",  "install size" and "to download size" as columns, the last 2 are delta size  computation based on the actual site content)  * get volume label, possibly volume type (so we can show different icon) for the   MyComputer tree, and any other place where we may be showing "annotated" local  file paths.  * register local system info change listener ... will be called when things  change ... for now can simply ignore the change and do a global refresh (as when  the refresh action is selected)  NOTE: the base java implementation of the above does not do much of anything  useful, other than providing a default implementation of the apis. The full  function will "come alive" once we add natives. The changes above are enabling  this.
my_mothod: New class and interface is beeing added in 20020305-I build,  org.eclipse.update.configuration.LocalSystemInfo/ ILocalSystemInfoListener.  These implement methods for obtaining available space, volume labels and types,  plus a listener for notification when file system has changed (removable drives,  media, mount points).  We should support this in the UI as follows:  * install/ update wizard should show available/ required/ to-download space in  the site-selection list (should show as table with "site", "available space",  "install size" and "to download size" as columns, the last 2 are delta size  computation based on the actual site content)  * get volume label, possibly volume type (so we can show different icon) for the   MyComputer tree, and any other place where we may be showing "annotated" local  file paths.  * register local system info change listener ... will be called when things  change ... for now can simply ignore the change and do a global refresh (as when  the refresh action is selected)  NOTE: the base java implementation of the above does not do much of anything  useful, other than providing a default implementation of the apis. The full  function will "come alive" once we add natives. The changes above are enabling  this. Add support for native local system info normal Update  (deprecated - use Eclipse>Equinox>p2) Platform

description: As far as I can tell, there is no way for a space to be entered in the VM  arguments section. For example, attempting to add the VM argument:  -Duser.home="C:\My Documents"  Results in a "Could not find the main class. Program will exit!" error since  it's trying to execute the "Documents" portion of the command line (java  thinks that's the class with the main method). I've tried everything to get  spaces to work, including \"", \b, \u0020, etc.  This is a show-stopper folks, and needs to be fixed if we are to use it here  at work.  Thanks...

description: 20020305 Several of us like to work in a single window (the old "MDI" mentality <g>). We switch perspectives by selecting from the vertical toolbar on the left. We also create multiple Java perspectives by selecting "Perspective->Save As..." and creating a new Java perspective called, say, "Java2". "Editor sharing" is nice most of the time, but in the "Java2" perspective, you  do *not* want to share editors. You want a completely separate "Java" context. I realize that the work around for this problem is to open the second Java  perspective in a new window. I am hoping that it would not be too difficult to  maybe add a "share editors" checkbox (default 'yes') to the Perspective- >Customize... dialog, and then to allow single-window perspective changing to  the customized perspectives without sharing editors.
my_mothod: 20020305 Several of us like to work in a single window (the old "MDI" mentality <g>). We switch perspectives by selecting from the vertical toolbar on the left. We also create multiple Java perspectives by selecting "Perspective->Save As..." and creating a new Java perspective called, say, "Java2". "Editor sharing" is nice most of the time, but in the "Java2" perspective, you  do *not* want to share editors. You want a completely separate "Java" context. I realize that the work around for this problem is to open the second Java  perspective in a new window. I am hoping that it would not be too difficult to  maybe add a "share editors" checkbox (default 'yes') to the Perspective- >Customize... dialog, and then to allow single-window perspective changing to  the customized perspectives without sharing editors. [Perspectives] DCR: Would like configurable "per perspective" editor sharing enhancement UI Platform

description: Build 20020312  I had been using this build for most of the day, doing lots of debugging,  setting breakpoints, etc.  I then shut down and tried to restart, but it hung on  startup.  After waiting several minutes, I did Ctrl+Break to get a stack trace,  and it showed the stack below.  This is consistently reproducible on my  workspace now, which I can make available if needed.  I will attach the complete  core dump file.  I wasn't sure where to log the bug, but since the thread was  forked during Debug plugin startup this seemed like the right place. description: We need to support the "arch" tag in the UI.  Also need to actually filter based on the current user environment. The needs to  * by default, only show features that can be installed on the user machine * via check, show all features (regardless of target type)  Core needs to  * by default, only install plugins/ non-plugins that match the user environment * via check (passed from UI or accessed in some other way), for install of all  plugins/ non-plugins regardless of target type)  For 2.0 we do not support "custom selection (ie. only what matches user  environment, or all).  PS: may be useful to have the "matching" check implemented once as core API  (likely on feature, pluginentry, nonpluginentry)

description: If your text is set to White and your backgrounds black (like in Hight Contrast  Black) the title of any of the pages in the plugin.xml editor is hidden in the  white background at the top. Also if the banner font is large the text  overshoots the title area.   The title area size should be calculated based on the fonts used.  STEPS 1) Set your Banner font very large (say 24 points) in the Font Preference Page 2) Set your Windows properties to use High Constrast Black 3) Open a plugin.xml. The Text overshoots the title area and the part in the  title area is not readable.
