Also if the banner font is large the text  overshoots the title area.   The title area size should be calculated based on the fonts used.  STEPS 1) Set your Banner font very large (say 24 points) in the Font Preference Page 2) Set your Windows properties to use High Constrast Black 3) Open a plugin.xml. The Text overshoots the title area and the part in the  title area is not readable. White border at top of plugin.xml editor hides text in High Contrast Black normal UI PDE

description: If your text is set to White and your backgrounds black (like in High Contrast  Black) the title in the Preview page is hidden in the white background at the  top. Also if the banner font is large the text overshoots the title area.   The title area size should be calculated based on the fonts used.  STEPS 1) Set your Header font very large (say 24 points) in the Font Preference Page 2) Set your Windows properties to use High Constrast Black 3) Open a plugin.xml. The Text overshoots the title area and the part in the  title area is not readable.
my_mothod: If your text is set to White and your backgrounds black (like in High Contrast  Black) the title in the Preview page is hidden in the white background at the  top. Also if the banner font is large the text overshoots the title area.   The title area size should be calculated based on the fonts used.  STEPS 1) Set your Header font very large (say 24 points) in the Font Preference Page 2) Set your Windows properties to use High Constrast Black 3) Open a plugin.xml. The Text overshoots the title area and the part in the  title area is not readable. Color problems in the Preview Page normal Update  (deprecated - use Eclipse>Equinox>p2) Platform

description: 3 of the JDT viewers update labels very slowly when they get a  labelProviderChanged event from the DecoratorManager.  using the large workbench provided for Bug 10903 the following ContentViewers  took a large amount of time to process labelProviderChanged for a very simple  decorator (I have one that appends the currentTimeMilliseconds to the label and  does nothing to the image).  ProblemTreeViewer (sometimes upwards of 500 ms) JavaOutlineViewer (around 200 ms) MethodsViewer (around 200ms)  This can potentially cause a large delay in update due to the amount of updates  being sent by the CVS decorator (see Bug 12315).
my_mothod: 3 of the JDT viewers update labels very slowly when they get a  labelProviderChanged event from the DecoratorManager.  using the large workbench provided for Bug 10903 the following ContentViewers  took a large amount of time to process labelProviderChanged for a very simple  decorator (I have one that appends the currentTimeMilliseconds to the label and  does nothing to the image).  ProblemTreeViewer (sometimes upwards of 500 ms) JavaOutlineViewer (around 200 ms) MethodsViewer (around 200ms)  This can potentially cause a large delay in update due to the amount of updates  being sent by the CVS decorator (see Bug 12315). Some Viewers update label decorators very slowly normal UI JDT

description: Build 20020328  The configurations in the launch history don't seem to get updated when you  change the JRE used by the configuration.  This is best explained by showing the  steps I followed.  I don't know if this is intended behaviour, but I found it  quite confusing!  1) Setup a self hosting environment 2) Create a launch config for Runtime Workbench using IBM JRE as the VM 3) Perform a launch (debug mode) using this configuration, then shutdown 4) Use Debug dropdown button, pick "Debug Configurations..." 5) On this page, change the JRE of runtime workbench to J9. 6) Hit apply button, then close this dialog. 7) Now use the debug history to try launching the runtime workbench  It fails to launch (UnsatisfiedLinkError: setClassPathImpl).  I spent quite some  time at this point trying to figure out why it wouldn't launch with J9.   Finally, I stumbled on the answer:  8) Reopen the debug configurations dialog 9) Select the runtime workbench, and hit the "Debug" button  Now it launches.  After launching, the debug launch history now shows two  identical entries for runtime workbench.  One uses J9, and the other uses IBM  JRE, but they are impossible to distinguish.
my_mothod: Build 20020328  The configurations in the launch history don't seem to get updated when you  change the JRE used by the configuration.  This is best explained by showing the  steps I followed.  I don't know if this is intended behaviour, but I found it  quite confusing!  1) Setup a self hosting environment 2) Create a launch config for Runtime Workbench using IBM JRE as the VM 3) Perform a launch (debug mode) using this configuration, then shutdown 4) Use Debug dropdown button, pick "Debug Configurations..." 5) On this page, change the JRE of runtime workbench to J9. 6) Hit apply button, then close this dialog. 7) Now use the debug history to try launching the runtime workbench  It fails to launch (UnsatisfiedLinkError: setClassPathImpl).  I spent quite some  time at this point trying to figure out why it wouldn't launch with J9.   Finally, I stumbled on the answer:  8) Reopen the debug configurations dialog 9) Select the runtime workbench, and hit the "Debug" button  Now it launches.  After launching, the debug launch history now shows two  identical entries for runtime workbench.  One uses J9, and the other uses IBM  JRE, but they are impossible to distinguish. Launch configurations don't handle changed JRE well normal Debug JDT

description: There are a series of problems with the Available Updates page  1) The use of the Light blue colour for the second title is almost unreadable on Linux 2) The widgets are crushed up against each other on Linux and very hard to follow 3) Query Settings has a floating "Available Updates" entry when you expand Query Settings that is not visible on either Linux or Windows 4) The Search Now button is cut of on both platforms 5) The title is unreadable in high contrast black (white text) 6) Spelling errors in main title (heigher should be spelled higher) 7) There is a lot of white space between Last Search and Search Results
my_mothod: There are a series of problems with the Available Updates page  1) The use of the Light blue colour for the second title is almost unreadable on Linux 2) The widgets are crushed up against each other on Linux and very hard to follow 3) Query Settings has a floating "Available Updates" entry when you expand Query Settings that is not visible on either Linux or Windows 4) The Search Now button is cut of on both platforms 5) The title is unreadable in high contrast black (white text) 6) Spelling errors in main title (heigher should be spelled higher) 7) There is a lot of white space between Last Search and Search Results Accessibility: some accessibility issues critical Update  (deprecated - use Eclipse>Equinox>p2) Platform

description: The JavaEditor registers a PaintListener for error indication on it  StyledTextWidget. The following happens on 20020508.  1) open a Java File in the Java editor 2) introduce a temporary problem -> error indication is visible 3) scroll up so that the error indication is scrolled out of the visible area 4) scroll back -> error indication visible 5) scroll down so that the error indication is scrolled out of the visible area 6) scroll back -> error indication is gone Note: The registered paint listener is called in both cases and also draws in  both cases.
my_mothod: The JavaEditor registers a PaintListener for error indication on it  StyledTextWidget. The following happens on 20020508.  1) open a Java File in the Java editor 2) introduce a temporary problem -> error indication is visible 3) scroll up so that the error indication is scrolled out of the visible area 4) scroll back -> error indication visible 5) scroll down so that the error indication is scrolled out of the visible area 6) scroll back -> error indication is gone Note: The registered paint listener is called in both cases and also draws in  both cases. Paint listener result invisible critical UI JDT

description: I am using the Jakarta Avalon open source project.  I checked out jakarta- avalon-excalibur from the apache cvs tree, mounted all source folders in the  project and imported the necessary libraries.    I have a class that needs to use the  org/apache/excalibur/fortress/util/ContextManager class.  When I try to run my  class or the unit test class  org.apache.excalibur.fortress.test.ContainerProfile.java (any class that needs  the ContextManager) I get the following Exception trace:  java.lang.VerifyError: (class:  org/apache/excalibur/fortress/util/ContextManager, method:  initializeLoggerManager signature: ()V) Register 2 contains wrong type 	at  org.apache.excalibur.fortress.test.ContainerProfile.testCompare_ECM_ContainerMan ager_UseageTime(ContainerProfile.java:106) 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) 	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) 	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324) 	at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:166) 	at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:140) 	at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106) 	at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124) 	at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109) 	at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:131) 	at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:173) 	at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:168) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests (RemoteTestRunner.java:319) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run (RemoteTestRunner.java:215) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main (RemoteTestRunner.java:150)  When running the excalibur build file using ant and the jdk1.4 compiler and  then import the generated jar everything seems to work ok,  so I attribute the  error to the eclipse compiler.  I also tried to change the order of the class  path, which didn't help.  I am running latest stable build M5 on Win2k and jdk1.4.  The compiler  compatibility settings are set to jdk1.4.

description: (In the following discussion, all patterns were entered without the  enclosing quote marks.)  The pattern "1 " causes one character of each package name to be  displayed with a single space separator between them.  The pattern " 1 " causes one space to precede the first single-character  package name and two spaces to appear between each one.  Both of the above cases were expected. However, if you set the patttern to  " 1" (i.e. space before, but no space after), no spaces are displayed in the  result.
my_mothod: (In the following discussion, all patterns were entered without the  enclosing quote marks.)  The pattern "1 " causes one character of each package name to be  displayed with a single space separator between them.  The pattern " 1 " causes one space to precede the first single-character  package name and two spaces to appear between each one.  Both of the above cases were expected. However, if you set the patttern to  " 1" (i.e. space before, but no space after), no spaces are displayed in the  result. Preceding space in package compression pattern sometimes ignored trivial UI JDT

description: The ManageBreakpointActionDelegate forces a reconcile of a Java compilation unit  on a selection changed event (see trace below). A reconcile is an expensive  operation for a large compilation unit. It is not clear why it is needed. The  selection change updates the label to either Add/Remove. To do so you should not  have to know which element the selection is at. To reduce the updating cost the  label could just be changed to Toggle Breakpoint.  All references to ActionDelegateHelper.getCurrentMemember should be checked.          at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.WorkingCopy.reconcile(WorkingCopy.java:357)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ActionDelegateHelper.getCurrentMember( ActionDelegateHelper.java:138)         - locked <055BF888> (a org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.WorkingCopy)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.AbstractManageBreakpointActionDelegate .update(AbstractManageBreakpointActionDelegate.java:45)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ManageBreakpointActionDelegate.selecti onChanged(ManageBreakpointActionDelegate.java:179)
my_mothod: The ManageBreakpointActionDelegate forces a reconcile of a Java compilation unit  on a selection changed event (see trace below). A reconcile is an expensive  operation for a large compilation unit. It is not clear why it is needed. The  selection change updates the label to either Add/Remove. To do so you should not  have to know which element the selection is at. To reduce the updating cost the  label could just be changed to Toggle Breakpoint.  All references to ActionDelegateHelper.getCurrentMemember should be checked.          at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.WorkingCopy.reconcile(WorkingCopy.java:357)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ActionDelegateHelper.getCurrentMember( ActionDelegateHelper.java:138)         - locked <055BF888> (a org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.WorkingCopy)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.AbstractManageBreakpointActionDelegate .update(AbstractManageBreakpointActionDelegate.java:45)         at  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ManageBreakpointActionDelegate.selecti onChanged(ManageBreakpointActionDelegate.java:179) ManageBreakpointActionDelegate triggers reconcile on selection change critical Debug JDT

description: Build F1 Indexer and main thread can get different Java Model instances See attached stack traces.  This can lead to a various number of bugs in the UI e.g. Java working sets don't work because the elements are no longer equal (different Java Model instances as parent).
my_mothod: Build F1 Indexer and main thread can get different Java Model instances See attached stack traces.  This can lead to a various number of bugs in the UI e.g. Java working sets don't work because the elements are no longer equal (different Java Model instances as parent). Race condition on startup leads to 2 JavaModel instances critical Core JDT

description: JDT core should register the Java related file types with core so that they are  properly released either as text or binary. This should be done in CORE since  it also has to work headless. Doing so requires adding a pre-req to the team  plugin org.eclipse.team.core. However, this is OK since conceptually the team  plugin is part of the platform CORE.  The following file types should be registered: .java  text .class binary .classpath text .jar binary .properties text ???  The registration is done in XML: <extension point="org.eclipse.team.core.fileTypes">   <fileTypes extension="txt" type="text"/>   <fileTypes extension="java" type="text"/>   <fileTypes extension="properties" type="text"/>   <fileTypes extension="xml" type="text"/>   <fileTypes extension="html" type="text"/>   <fileTypes extension="jpg" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="gif" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="ico" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="bmp" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="tif" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="doc" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="xls" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="ppt" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="zip" type="binary"/>   <fileTypes extension="exe" type="binary"/> </extension>

description: 1) Have a package with A.java and B.java 2) Open A.java in the editor, modify it 3) Select Save As 4) Type B.java 5) OK -> Editor changes to B.java -> B.java is still B.java -> A.java still exists -> Changes in A are lost It seems that things start to go wrong in CopyResourceElementsOperation.updateContent: /** * Updates the content of cu, modifying the type name and/or package * declaration as necessary. * * @return the new source */ private String updatedContent(ICompilationUnit cu, IPackageFragment dest, String newName) throws JavaModelException { String currPackageName = cu.getParent().getElementName(); String destPackageName = dest.getElementName(); if (currPackageName.equals(destPackageName) && newName == null) { return null; //nothing to change } else { String typeName = cu.getElementName(); typeName = typeName.substring(0, typeName.length() - 5); IDOMCompilationUnit cuDOM = null; cuDOM = fFactory.createCompilationUnit(cu.getBuffer ().getCharacters(), typeName); updateTypeName(cu, cuDOM, cu.getElementName(), newName); updatePackageStatement(cuDOM, destPackageName); return cuDOM.getContents(); } } All the way down until cuDOM.getContents() things seem fine. The last statement however returns the content of B.java rather then keeping what has been passed into fFactory.createCompilationUnit.
my_mothod: 1) Have a package with A.java and B.java 2) Open A.java in the editor, modify it 3) Select Save As 4) Type B.java 5) OK -> Editor changes to B.java -> B.java is still B.java -> A.java still exists -> Changes in A are lost It seems that things start to go wrong in CopyResourceElementsOperation.updateContent: /** * Updates the content of cu, modifying the type name and/or package * declaration as necessary. * * @return the new source */ private String updatedContent(ICompilationUnit cu, IPackageFragment dest, String newName) throws JavaModelException { String currPackageName = cu.getParent().getElementName(); String destPackageName = dest.getElementName(); if (currPackageName.equals(destPackageName) && newName == null) { return null; //nothing to change } else { String typeName = cu.getElementName(); typeName = typeName.substring(0, typeName.length() - 5); IDOMCompilationUnit cuDOM = null; cuDOM = fFactory.createCompilationUnit(cu.getBuffer ().getCharacters(), typeName); updateTypeName(cu, cuDOM, cu.getElementName(), newName); updatePackageStatement(cuDOM, destPackageName); return cuDOM.getContents(); } } All the way down until cuDOM.getContents() things seem fine. The last statement however returns the content of B.java rather then keeping what has been passed into fFactory.createCompilationUnit. overwritting exiting file does not work critical UI JDT

description: As of F2, when generating a getters and setters for final fields, a  dialog asks if it's "OK to only create getter".  The options are Yes, Yes to  All, No, and Cancel.  It looks like selecting "Yes to All" actually acts like  No (i.e. the setter gets created), and vice versa.
my_mothod: As of F2, when generating a getters and setters for final fields, a  dialog asks if it's "OK to only create getter".  The options are Yes, Yes to  All, No, and Cancel. description: When a launch configuration type is selected, the message directly under the "Create, manage, and run launch configurations" it says "Select a type of configuration to create, and press the 'New' button, which should probably only be shown if nothing is selected. When I ctrl-click to de-select the type, the message doesn't change.  When I select a launch configuration, the message goes away as expected, but when I de-select the configuration, the message doesn't revert back to "Select a type...".  When I select multiple configurations, the message then says "Select a type..." which is definitely wrong, as I have two selected, and the only thing I can do is delete those.  (I'm running linux-GTK and this is Integration build 20020621)  mike

description: In our project we have a class B in package BP that inherits from class A in package AP. Class A has an protected method M1. Class B has an inner class BIC that calls method AP. description: The class JavaEditor does an == check inside isActivePart().  This means that if  the part is embedded inside another one then the check fails.  Rather than this  can it use .equals instead and dispatch this to the other part that can  specialize accordingly, e.g. instead of the current method  	protected boolean isActivePart() { 		IWorkbenchWindow window= getSite().getWorkbenchWindow(); 		IPartService service= window.getPartService(); 		return (this == service.getActivePart()); 	}  it could have the last line as                 return (service.getActivePart().equals(this));
my_mothod: The class JavaEditor does an == check inside isActivePart().  This means that if  the part is embedded inside another one then the check fails.  Rather than this  can it use .equals instead and dispatch this to the other part that can  specialize accordingly, e.g. instead of the current method  	protected boolean isActivePart() { 		IWorkbenchWindow window= getSite().getWorkbenchWindow(); 		IPartService service= window.getPartService(); 		return (this == service.getActivePart()); 	}  it could have the last line as                 return (service.getActivePart().equals(this)); On JavaEditor dont use == in the isActivePart() method but instead use .equals(Object) critical UI JDT

description: Build I-20020723 VM: J2RE 1.3.1 IBM Windows 32 build cn131-20020403 (JIT enabled: jitc)  - new Java project - new class:  public class Hello {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		System.out.println("Hi"); 		System.out.println("Hi"); 		System.out.println("Hi"); 		System.out.println("Hi"); 		System.out.println("Hi"); 		System.out.println("Hi"); 	}  - set breakpoint on first line - launch under debugger - wait until debugger settles down at breakpoint - hit F6 - nothing happens - wiggle mouse - the step occurs  You may need to wiggle the mouse even to get to the breakpoint (seems to  affect all debug events, not just step).  At first I thought the debugger was just being horrendously slow, but if you  wiggle the mouse immediately after stepping, or while clicking on the step  button, it gets processed quickly.

description: It seems that Eclipse caches the contents of source files that are used during debug  sessions. I have an environment set up as follows:  Project A - Simple Project usings an external ANT builder Project B - Java Project containing JUnit tests  I create a test case in B and then use the Debug perspective to find out why a test may be failing. I then switch to the Resource Perspective where I edit/compile/build my project. This creates some JAR files and a source.zip file so that Eclipse can attach source for JAR files I created (BTW, why does Eclipse insist on a JAR or ZIP file for attaching source? Why can't a filesystem or workspace path be used as well?).  Once I go back to Debug Perspective to verify my changes, I get an old copy of the source files I have just edited that don't align with the debugged JAR files. I have to close all perspectives and restart Eclipse to get back to a state where I can debug. Note that just closing the  perspective or all perspectives does not help. Upon reopen, they still have knowledge of the outdated source files.  This is a painful problem because stopping/restarting Eclipse is not enjoyable. Also, closing all the perspectives and having to recustomize them on restart is painful. I guess I could avoid this by saving my customizations to a new custom perspective, but I am lazy :-)  Thanks for listening,  Rob

Also, closing all the perspectives and having to recustomize them on restart is painful. description: Build 20020924  The javadoc that is generated for NavigatorDragAdapter (look in reference section of online help), looks like this:  void dragFinished(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragFinished does nothing.   void dragSetData(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragSetData does nothing.   void dragStart(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragStart permits the drag operation to    This javadoc is incorrect.  It has been copied from the generic superclass DragSourceAdapter.  I guess we need to override the javadoc for API classes in cases where the implementation differs significantly from the superclass. There are probably many more examples of this throughout the UI.
my_mothod: Build 20020924  The javadoc that is generated for NavigatorDragAdapter (look in reference section of online help), looks like this:  void dragFinished(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragFinished does nothing.   void dragSetData(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragSetData does nothing.   void dragStart(DragSourceEvent event)            This implementation of dragStart permits the drag operation to    This javadoc is incorrect.  It has been copied from the generic superclass DragSourceAdapter.  I guess we need to override the javadoc for API classes in cases where the implementation differs significantly from the superclass. There are probably many more examples of this throughout the UI. [DND] Incorrect javadoc for NavigatorDragAdapter minor UI Platform

description: Note this is a version 1.0.1 problem.  1) Generate a model from Java Anotations.   2) Go back into a source file and change one of the @model directives to now  specify containment.  e.g. containment="true" 3) Re-generate the model (by using the "Reload" command) 4) Notice that the "children" property of the model element is still "false".    Changing it to "true" and then re-generating the MODEL from the genmodel     screen puts everything back into synch.
my_mothod: Note this is a version 1.0.1 problem.  1) Generate a model from Java Anotations.   2) Go back into a source file and change one of the @model directives to now  specify containment.  e.g. containment="true" 3) Re-generate the model (by using the "Reload" command) 4) Notice that the "children" property of the model element is still "false".    Changing it to "true" and then re-generating the MODEL from the genmodel     screen puts everything back into synch. Changing containment state not reflected in model after reload. minor Core EMF

description: I-20021016 linux-gtk:  public class Woo {   static void goo(char c) {     System.out.println("char");   }   static void goo(int i) {     System.out.println("i");   }   static int foo() {     return 'a';   }   public static void main(String[] args) {     goo(foo());   } }  1. execute the class 2. observe the output is "int" 3. inline method foo 4. execute the class 5. observe the output is "char"  characters are implicitely cast to int on return. When the method is inlined, the implicit cast must be made explicit. If there's no ambiguity the cast could  be omitted.  The fix should handle all kind of possible implicit conversions.  There's a similar case:  public class Zoo {   static int foo() {     return 'A';   }   public static void main(String[] args) {     System.out.println("output: " + foo());   } }  Before inlining, the output is '65', after inlining, it's 'A'.  In the past I often got bitten by implicit conversions of characters to int,  which is hard to debug.
my_mothod: I-20021016 linux-gtk:  public class Woo {   static void goo(char c) {     System.out.println("char");   }   static void goo(int i) {     System.out.println("i");   }   static int foo() {     return 'a';   }   public static void main(String[] args) {     goo(foo());   } }  1. execute the class 2. observe the output is "int" 3. inline method foo 4. execute the class 5. observe the output is "char"  characters are implicitely cast to int on return. When the method is inlined, the implicit cast must be made explicit. If there's no ambiguity the cast could  be omitted.  The fix should handle all kind of possible implicit conversions.  There's a similar case:  public class Zoo {   static int foo() {     return 'A';   }   public static void main(String[] args) {     System.out.println("output: " + foo());   } }  Before inlining, the output is '65', after inlining, it's 'A'.  In the past I often got bitten by implicit conversions of characters to int,  which is hard to debug. inline method - doesn't handle implicit cast [refactoring] minor UI JDT

description: The class file editor uses a non-standard modifier order.  For instance,     final public class java.lang.System extends java.lang.Object {         final public static java.io.InputStream in;         native private static void registerNatives();         ... It should instead read:     public final class java.lang.System extends java.lang.Object {         public static final java.io.InputStream in;         private static native void registerNatives();         ...  So says the Java Language Spec: Section 8.1.1 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#21613  "ClassModifier: one of 	public protected private 	abstract static final strictfp  [...] If two or more class modifiers appear in a class declaration, then it is  customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent with  that shown above in the production for ClassModifier."  Section 8.3.1 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#78091  "FieldModifier: one of 	public protected private 	static final transient volatile  [...] If two or more (distinct) field modifiers appear in a field declaration,  it is customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent  with that shown above in the production for FieldModifier."  Section 8.4.3 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#78188  "MethodModifier: one of 	public protected private abstract static 	final synchronized native strictfp  [...] If two or more method modifiers appear in a method declaration, it is  customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent with  that shown above in the production for MethodModifier."
my_mothod: The class file editor uses a non-standard modifier order.  For instance,     final public class java.lang.System extends java.lang.Object {         final public static java.io.InputStream in;         native private static void registerNatives();         ... It should instead read:     public final class java.lang.System extends java.lang.Object {         public static final java.io.InputStream in;         private static native void registerNatives();         ...  So says the Java Language Spec: Section 8.1.1 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#21613  "ClassModifier: one of 	public protected private 	abstract static final strictfp  [...] If two or more class modifiers appear in a class declaration, then it is  customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent with  that shown above in the production for ClassModifier."  Section 8.3.1 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#78091  "FieldModifier: one of 	public protected private 	static final transient volatile  [...] If two or more (distinct) field modifiers appear in a field declaration,  it is customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent  with that shown above in the production for FieldModifier."  Section 8.4.3 http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#78188  "MethodModifier: one of 	public protected private abstract static 	final synchronized native strictfp  [...] If two or more method modifiers appear in a method declaration, it is  customary, though not required, that they appear in the order consistent with  that shown above in the production for MethodModifier." Class file editor uses non-standard modifier order minor Core JDT

description: 200211130841  Check org.eclipse.swt out of the CVS repository. Copy .classpath_win32 to .classpath in the package explorer view. The SWT code is compiled but none of the packages appear in the Package  Explorer view.  To make the packages appear, I had to select the project and in the properties  dialog go to the source folder of the Java build path.  switch back and forth  between "use project as source folder" and "use source folders".  Then save  the "changes".

description: Using M3, the following bug has been reported on EC:  Javac and eclipse compiler don't behave the same on this code:  public class NullOuvert {     public static final boolean VIER_BUBEN = false;     public static final String SPIEL = VIER_BUBEN ? "Grand Hand" : null;     public static void main(String[] args) {         System.out.println(SPIEL == null);         System.out.println(SPIEL.equals(null));         System.out.println(SPIEL);     } }  When running Eclipse compiler bytecodes: false false null   When running javac bytecodes: true Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException         at NullOuvert.main(NullOuvert.java:6)  This is a serious problem.  A workaround seems to be to cast the null literal in a String. Then they behave the same.
my_mothod: Using M3, the following bug has been reported on EC:  Javac and eclipse compiler don't behave the same on this code:  public class NullOuvert {     public static final boolean VIER_BUBEN = false;     public static final String SPIEL = VIER_BUBEN ? "Grand Hand" : null;     public static void main(String[] args) {         System.out.println(SPIEL == null);         System.out.println(SPIEL.equals(null));         System.out.println(SPIEL);     } }  When running Eclipse compiler bytecodes: false false null   When running javac bytecodes: true Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException         at NullOuvert.main(NullOuvert.java:6)  This is a serious problem.  A workaround seems to be to cast the null literal in a String. Then they behave the same. Wrong code generation in conditional expression critical Core JDT

description: If you copy a line of text and paste it into a JavaDoc comment, it automatically prepends '  *' on the front. Copy a line of JavaDoc comment, with a '  *' on already, and the first time you paste it, the * is not generated, but subsequent pastings do contain '  *'  Can a filter be put in so that if a comment begins with <whitespace>* then the <whitespace>* is removed from each line?  /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  Copy the 'copy' line (Ctrl+C/Command+C)  Move the cursor to the start of the line (not the start of the indented comment)  Paste the result in: /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  Now do a 'paste' again /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  *  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  The second (and subsequent) pastes will have <whitespace>*<whitespace>* in. My guess is this is happening because if pasted from the beginning of a line, it's treated as a replacement (so '  *' is not generated), whereas second and subsequent lines the cursor isn't at the start of the line, and so the *  is generated.
my_mothod: If you copy a line of text and paste it into a JavaDoc comment, it automatically prepends '  *' on the front. Copy a line of JavaDoc comment, with a '  *' on already, and the first time you paste it, the * is not generated, but subsequent pastings do contain '  *'  Can a filter be put in so that if a comment begins with <whitespace>* then the <whitespace>* is removed from each line?  /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  Copy the 'copy' line (Ctrl+C/Command+C)  Move the cursor to the start of the line (not the start of the indented comment)  Paste the result in: /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  Now do a 'paste' again /**  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  *  * Copy this entire line from start to finish  */  The second (and subsequent) pastes will have <whitespace>*<whitespace>* in. My guess is this is happening because if pasted from the beginning of a line, it's treated as a replacement (so '  *' is not generated), whereas second and subsequent lines the cursor isn't at the start of the line, and so the *  is generated. Possible to insert JavaDoc comments with "  *" on the front minor Text JDT

description: Eclipse 20021213  With a new installation the welcome editor comes up.  Now using the type  selector open a new file (editorlist for example).  Note the navigator, outline  view and tabs all now display editorlist, but the shown text is that of the  welcome editor.  Repeat with any other file.   With multiple tabs, now select any tab other than the text being displayed.   Note the text does not change.  Now select the tab for the text being  displayed.  Selecting other tabs now works as expected.  If you now open a new  file, the error is once again reproduced.  Only activating the tab for the  shown text clears the issue.  The same behaviour is exhibited if the editors view is used, or the pull-down  is used.
my_mothod: Eclipse 20021213  With a new installation the welcome editor comes up.  Now using the type  selector open a new file (editorlist for example).  Note the navigator, outline  view and tabs all now display editorlist, but the shown text is that of the  welcome editor.  Repeat with any other file.   With multiple tabs, now select any tab other than the text being displayed.   Note the text does not change.  Now select the tab for the text being  displayed.  Selecting other tabs now works as expected.  If you now open a new  file, the error is once again reproduced.  Only activating the tab for the  shown text clears the issue.  The same behaviour is exhibited if the editors view is used, or the pull-down  is used. [Editor Mgmt] Editor pane out of sync with views and tabs blocker SWT Platform

description: In the Java browsing perspective: Create a Java project, with some packages and classes.  Have the editor open  on a couple of classes. Now, expand the project in the project list, and select two or three external  jars.  Press Delete to delete them. Result:  The project appears empty in the Java browsing perspective.  There  are no packages or classes in the lists.  However, if you activate an editor,  you will see the member list populate (looks sort of like a bunch of orphaned  variables and methods).
my_mothod: In the Java browsing perspective: Create a Java project, with some packages and classes.  Have the editor open  on a couple of classes. Now, expand the project in the project list, and select two or three external  jars.  Press Delete to delete them. Result:  The project appears empty in the Java browsing perspective.  There  are no packages or classes in the lists.  However, if you activate an editor,  you will see the member list populate (looks sort of like a bunch of orphaned  variables and methods). Classpath gets lost after deleting an external jar [build path] [ccp] critical UI JDT

description: When project has multiple output folders, debug does not find new version of  compiled class (Hot code replace). It looks like debugger searches only default  output folder and not changed classe's own output folder.  Project properties -> Java build path -> Source -> Source folders on build  path -> Allow output folders per source folder
my_mothod: When project has multiple output folders, debug does not find new version of  compiled class (Hot code replace). It looks like debugger searches only default  output folder and not changed classe's own output folder.  Project properties -> Java build path -> Source -> Source folders on build  path -> Allow output folders per source folder Debug does not honor multiple output folders blocker Debug JDT

Add file "my.txt" to "icons" folder ==> the delta which is sent out looks like: Java Model[*]: {CHILDREN} 	Test[*]: {CHILDREN} 		src/icons/my.txt[+]: {}  There should be a resource delta.

description: When having a reference on another project you "see" all the sources that are  in this referenced projects.  It appears that in projects you can have API sources and CORE sources  (generally in 2 different src folders)  because only the target packaging of  the project defines what is public and what is not in the end. (by external  tool)  I would like to have to possibily in the "Order and export" tab of the project  properties->java build path, to uncheck some of the source folders so that  referencing projects would not see these classes. This can let me hide core  classes and have a clean dependency between projects.  One could say the solution is to create 2 different projects. The problem is  that I need another one to gather both api and core classes for packaging  purposes and it's not possible in Eclipse to have nested projects (is it ??)  Thanks.
my_mothod: When having a reference on another project you "see" all the sources that are  in this referenced projects.  It appears that in projects you can have API sources and CORE sources  (generally in 2 different src folders)  because only the target packaging of  the project defines what is public and what is not in the end. (by external  tool)  I would like to have to possibily in the "Order and export" tab of the project  properties->java build path, to uncheck some of the source folders so that  referencing projects would not see these classes. This can let me hide core  classes and have a clean dependency between projects.  One could say the solution is to create 2 different projects. The problem is  that I need another one to gather both api and core classes for packaging  purposes and it's not possible in Eclipse to have nested projects (is it ??)  Thanks. Source visibility in project dependency enhancement Core JDT

description: Steps to recreate: 0) I used IBM 1.3.1 sr1 and sr3 to recreate.  may happen on other VMs as well. 1) create a Java project using JRE_LIB for rt.jar rather than using class path  containers (this represents a project created using an older version of  Eclipse).  2) load that project into a I20030121  build of Eclipse  3) check out the project properties and note that the JRE_LIB var is not set to  rt.jar but what appears to be just the first element of the default JRE's  classpath container.  In my tests this ended up being some jclSC131.jar.   The net result is that users are unable to open older projects with newer  eclipses.
my_mothod: Steps to recreate: 0) I used IBM 1.3.1 sr1 and sr3 to recreate.  may happen on other VMs as well. 1) create a Java project using JRE_LIB for rt.jar rather than using class path  containers (this represents a project created using an older version of  Eclipse).  2) load that project into a I20030121  build of Eclipse  3) check out the project properties and note that the JRE_LIB var is not set to  rt.jar but what appears to be just the first element of the default JRE's  classpath container.  In my tests this ended up being some jclSC131.jar.   The net result is that users are unable to open older projects with newer  eclipses. JRE_LIB not properly resolved with JRE containers critical Debug JDT

description: OS: RedHat8.0 Eclipse Build: 200212181304 Stable Build (M4) JRE Version: J2RE 1.3.1 IBM build cxia32131-20021102 (JIT enabled: jitc)  Abstract: Cannot wake up IME in the Editor view on Linux  Re-produce steps: 1. Launch eclipse. 2. Open java file via Java Edit or Text Edit. 3. Press Ctrl+Space and try to wake up IME for GB18030 char input.  Expected Result: It should wake up IME using Ctrl+Space in the Edit view.  Execution Result: 1. Cannot wake up IME for GB18030 char input. 2. Cannot switch among several methods by pressing Ctrl+Shift.  Comments: 1. This problem occurs on GTK driver with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0. 2. This problem occurs on Motif driver with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0. 3. We remove the Key Bindings for Ctrl + Space, and the problem still exist.  Please refer to =>RemoveHotKeyBinding.jpg 4. We can wake up IME by pressing Ctrl+Space and switch among several methods by pressing Ctrl+Shift with gEdit,StarOffice and other applications. 5. We can use Ctrl+Space to wake up IME on some panels with GTK build and some  with Motif build, for example: 1) Click Windows->Preference->Application Server, for the "Host name or IP  address" edit box: GTK build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) cannot wake up IME.  Motif build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.  2) Click Search->Java Search, for the "search string" edit box: GTK build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.  Motif build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.  3) Click File->Import->File system, for the "Directory" edit box: GTK build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) cannot wake up IME.  Motif build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.  4) Click Windows->Preference->WorkBench->Path Variables, then click New  button, for the "Variable name" edit box: GTK build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.  Motif build (with both JDK1.3.1 and JDK1.4.0) can wake up IME.

description: AspectJ Compiler 1.1beta4  This program:  public aspect Foo {   pointcut p(int i): call(void f(i)); }  produces these error messages:  negation doesn't allow binding formal unbound in pointcut  2 errors  It should say something like "binding is only allowed in state-based pointcuts", and it should print the file and line number.  --Doug
my_mothod: AspectJ Compiler 1.1beta4  This program:  public aspect Foo {   pointcut p(int i): call(void f(i)); }  produces these error messages:  negation doesn't allow binding formal unbound in pointcut  2 errors  It should say something like "binding is only allowed in state-based pointcuts", and it should print the file and line number.  --Doug lame error message: "negation doesn't allow binding" trivial Compiler AspectJ

description: Using 0129, try the following test case: 1) Create a new Java Project P. 2) In P, create the following interface: public interface Inter {  	int INT = 0; 	int FLOAT = 1; } 3) In P, create the following class: public class A { 	 	public static void main(String[] args) { 		int i = 0; 		switch(i) { 			case Int<cursor here> 						 		} 	}  } Try to use the code assist where <cursor here> is located. You won't have any completion. Now replace: 			case Int<cursor here> with: 			case Inter.INT: 			case Int<cursor here>:  And using the code assist again, you will got some completions. I should be able to get the same completions the first time. This is pretty annoying.  From my perspective, this needs to be fixed for 2.1.
my_mothod: Using 0129, try the following test case: 1) Create a new Java Project P. 2) In P, create the following interface: public interface Inter {  	int INT = 0; 	int FLOAT = 1; } 3) In P, create the following class: public class A { 	 	public static void main(String[] args) { 		int i = 0; 		switch(i) { 			case Int<cursor here> 						 		} 	}  } Try to use the code assist where <cursor here> is located. description: 20030205     Set a long description (> 40 characters) for a preference page.  Notice that the  longer the description, the more vertical space is left blank underneath the  description before the first widget.  The problem seems to be the code in  PreferencePage.doComputeSize() that forces a layout on the description label's  parent.  If this code is removed, the problem goes away.

description: Build 20030214  When an index signature is changed, the index manager will not force it to be  recreated if it thinks it can be trusted.  Offending code seems to be: IndexManager#getIndex(...) which only looks at the state of the index, and  ignore its signature.  When opening the corresponding index, later on, it is too late, an IO Exception  is thrown, but it doesn't end up recreating the index, simply failing the  search action (no match).  Must fix for 2.1
my_mothod: Build 20030214  When an index signature is changed, the index manager will not force it to be  recreated if it thinks it can be trusted.  Offending code seems to be: IndexManager#getIndex(...) which only looks at the state of the index, and  ignore its signature.  When opening the corresponding index, later on, it is too late, an IO Exception  is thrown, but it doesn't end up recreating the index, simply failing the  search action (no match).  Must fix for 2.1 Index signature change isn't honoured any longer critical Core JDT

description: The 'Format' operation is only available when the file editing has unsaved changes. It is disabled when the file has been saved.  I have run into the situation many times where I have saved w/o formatting the code first, and would like to format it after I have saved it. The only way I can do that is by putting a space in the code and deleting it so that the Format action is enabled. As an instructor of Java students, I've seen them doing this many times in the Java editor.  I also found a situation when I had changed the formatting preferences. In order to re-apply the formatting, I had to make changes to every single file and do a format again.  It would therefore be desirable if the dependency between the 'format' action and the 'has unsaved changes' property could be removed. That way, a format could apply to a saved file as well and remove a lot of minor headaches.  Since the purpose of putting this dependency in the first place was presumably because people who had saved their file wouldn't want to format it, it seems that this requirement is false.  Though not a high prority bug for 2.1, it seems such a trivial fix that if this can be done for the 2.1 build, it would be great; otherwise resolve for later.

description: Hello,  You can do the following test :  Create a java class with the following code inside Eclipse :   public class TestConsole { 	public static void main(String[] args) 	{ 		for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) 		{ 			System.out.println("out"); 			System.err.println("err"); 		} 	} }  And then run it, your result should look like this :   err out err out err out err out err outerr  out out out out err err err err out err out err out err .....  As you can see, it seems that there is a sort synchronisation problem between  System.out and Syste.err.  This test works fine in command line mode outside Eclipse.
my_mothod: Hello,  You can do the following test :  Create a java class with the following code inside Eclipse :   public class TestConsole { 	public static void main(String[] args) 	{ 		for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) 		{ 			System.out.println("out"); 			System.err.println("err"); 		} 	} }  And then run it, your result should look like this :   err out err out err out err out err outerr  out out out out err err err err out err out err out err .....  As you can see, it seems that there is a sort synchronisation problem between  System.out and Syste.err.  This test works fine in command line mode outside Eclipse. [console] Synchronisation problem between System.out and System.err in the console normal Debug Platform

description: Although the Java language syntax doesn't require it, it is good practice for automated tools to put 'public abstract' at the front of methods generated in interfaces (such as the Refactor -> PullUp interface)  This allows a developer to either copy-and-paste the method signature in its entirety, or to change the 'interface' keyword to 'abstract class' without errors.  If the interface method is generated without public abstract, then changing either the definition from 'interface' to 'abstract class' or copy-and-pasting the method into another abstract class will result in an error since the method must either have a body/be declared abstract, and will also have package/friendly level scope instead of public.
my_mothod: Although the Java language syntax doesn't require it, it is good practice for automated tools to put 'public abstract' at the front of methods generated in interfaces (such as the Refactor -> PullUp interface)  This allows a developer to either copy-and-paste the method signature in its entirety, or to change the 'interface' keyword to 'abstract class' without errors.  If the interface method is generated without public abstract, then changing either the definition from 'interface' to 'abstract class' or copy-and-pasting the method into another abstract class will result in an error since the method must either have a body/be declared abstract, and will also have package/friendly level scope instead of public. Generation of interface methods should prefix with 'public abstract' trivial UI JDT

description: The jface.action.Separator class inherits the default AbstractGroupMarker  class's isEnabled() method, which is hardwired to return true.  This makes it impossible to use separators in submenus (or top-level menus in  menubars) where you want disabled behavior, i.e., the submenu should be grayed  out and not pop open when pressed.  The problem is, MenuManager.updateMenuItem  looks to see if there are any enabled items within the menu, and if so, forces  the menu to be enabled.  The presence of a Separator within that menu means  there will *always* be an enabled item.  The simplest fix is to just override isEnabled() to return false instead of  true.  An easier fix might be to just change the superclass method  AbstractGroupMarker.isEnabled.  Clearly I can override it myself, which is why  this bug is rated as "trivial".  There is no visible difference to the separator due to this change.  Special note:  this problem is exacerbated by peculiar SWT behavior (which  might itself be a bug):  if you double-click on a disabled menu item in a menu  bar, that menu item will receive an SWT.Shown event (even though the menu has  not been shown).  This causes MenuManager.updateMenuItem to be called, which  leads to the behavior listed in the paragraph at the top of this report.  Thus,  you can disable a menu, but double-clicking on it causes updateMenuItem to be  called, and then the Separator causes it to become enabled, and the status of  your menu has changed, and it's now visible, with all other entries still  disabled!  Wierd!  I hope this write-up is clear.
my_mothod: The jface.action.Separator class inherits the default AbstractGroupMarker  class's isEnabled() method, which is hardwired to return true.  This makes it impossible to use separators in submenus (or top-level menus in  menubars) where you want disabled behavior, i.e., the submenu should be grayed  out and not pop open when pressed.  The problem is, MenuManager.updateMenuItem  looks to see if there are any enabled items within the menu, and if so, forces  the menu to be enabled.  The presence of a Separator within that menu means  there will *always* be an enabled item.  The simplest fix is to just override isEnabled() to return false instead of  true.  An easier fix might be to just change the superclass method  AbstractGroupMarker.isEnabled.  Clearly I can override it myself, which is why  this bug is rated as "trivial".  There is no visible difference to the separator due to this change.  Special note:  this problem is exacerbated by peculiar SWT behavior (which  might itself be a bug):  if you double-click on a disabled menu item in a menu  bar, that menu item will receive an SWT.Shown event (even though the menu has  not been shown).  This causes MenuManager.updateMenuItem to be called, which  leads to the behavior listed in the paragraph at the top of this report.  Thus,  you can disable a menu, but double-clicking on it causes updateMenuItem to be  called, and then the Separator causes it to become enabled, and the status of  your menu has changed, and it's now visible, with all other entries still  disabled!  Wierd!  I hope this write-up is clear. [Contributions] updating: Separator should return isEnabled() == false trivial UI Platform

description: While using conditional breakpoints, I frequently get the following popup message when the breakpoint is hit:  	Conditional breakpoint runtime exception 	 	Reason: com.sun.jdi.ObjectCollectedException occurred retrieving reference type  I have confirmed, and reconfirmed, that the conditional expression is valid. I have received the error in several contexts and in all cases the expression is valid. And I have confirmed that the expression does not throw a runtime exception.  I cannot reproduce this problem in a small testcase, but hopefully there's enough information for you to track down the cause.  The problem started appearing when I updated to 2.1 RC1.

I cannot reproduce this problem in a small testcase, but hopefully there's enough information for you to track down the cause.  The problem started appearing when I updated to 2.1 RC1. description: Eclipse N200303060010 RH 8.0, IBM JDK 1.3.1  I install eclipse and launch a new workspace.  See bug #33987 for the first log generated prior to importing any projects. description: I think that bug is at the end of this method. It returns false if o1 == o2. I  think it should return false if o1 != o2.  public boolean equals(Object object) {     if (object == this) {       return true;     }      if (!(object instanceof List)) {       return false;     }      List list = (List)object;     if (list.size() != size) {       return false;     }      Iterator objects = ((List)object).iterator();     if (useEquals()) {       for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {         Object o1 = data[i];         Object o2 = objects.next();         if (o1 == null ? o2 != null : !o1.equals(o2)) {           return false;         }       }     } else {       for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {         Object o1 = data[i];         Object o2 = objects.next();         if (o1 == o2) {           return false;         }       }     }      return true;   }
my_mothod: I think that bug is at the end of this method. It returns false if o1 == o2. I  think it should return false if o1 != o2.  public boolean equals(Object object) {     if (object == this) {       return true;     }      if (!(object instanceof List)) {       return false;     }      List list = (List)object;     if (list.size() != size) {       return false;     }      Iterator objects = ((List)object).iterator();     if (useEquals()) {       for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {         Object o1 = data[i];         Object o2 = objects.next();         if (o1 == null ? o2 != null : !o1.equals(o2)) {           return false;         }       }     } else {       for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {         Object o1 = data[i];         Object o2 = objects.next();         if (o1 == o2) {           return false;         }       }     }      return true;   } BasicEList.equals method bug blocker Core EMF

description: In the midst of a heavy editing session, I suddenly got this popup window "Save could not be completed. Reason: Update conflict."  This could be a story different from that of bug 19818, as I am using Eclipse pretty much plain out of the box. I'm not even sure what a "pessimistic team" is. That's a notion I'm familiar with with respect to CVS - CVS is _not_ pessimistic. And that's what we use - a CVS pserver, also plain out of the box.   I was going to compare the current file content with CVS HEAD. It took me a moment to switch from "get this file right"-mode to "what's wrong with Eclipse"-mode, so I'm not entirely sure how far along I've got.  Moments later, I got the same popup again. Different file. This time not at all correlated with CVS action, just with a plain save out of the Java editor. Is this a bug or a feature? Did I do anything to deserve such messages?  Can't imagine.  I also checked the .log file in the .metadata - but nothing. That entire eclipse session didn't bother to write a .log.  "If all else fails, read the instructions", as they say. I even tried that:  I search the Eclipse help for "update conflict", but am not the least wiser for it.

That's a notion I'm familiar with with respect to CVS - CVS is _not_ pessimistic. And that's what we use - a CVS pserver, also plain out of the box.   I was going to compare the current file content with CVS HEAD. It took me a moment to switch from "get this file right"-mode to "what's wrong with Eclipse"-mode, so I'm not entirely sure how far along I've got.  Moments later, I got the same popup again. Different file. This time not at all correlated with CVS action, just with a plain save out of the Java editor. Is this a bug or a feature? Did I do anything to deserve such messages?  Can't imagine.  I also checked the .log file in the .metadata - but nothing. That entire eclipse session didn't bother to write a .log.  "If all else fails, read the instructions", as they say. I even tried that:  I search the Eclipse help for "update conflict", but am not the least wiser for it. Popup "Update conflict". critical Text Platform

description: OS: Linux Red Hat 8.0 Motif Build: RC2 with IBM JRE131  Summary:  Cannot input characters in German for motif using the same keystrokes  used to input the same characters in the editor of the OS.  For a German  keyboard, certain keys are designated for certain special chars., such as "["  is used for an "ä" and ";" is used for "ö".  These keys cannot be used to input  characters into a simple file or in the java editor.  Recreate Steps: 1.  Set keyboard to German keyboard. 2.  Launch Eclipse. 3.  Create a new project. 4.  Create a new class or a new file. 5.  Enter special chars using the specific keys.  Expected Result: Special Characters are displayed.  Execution Result: Nothing happens.  No character is entered.  Comments: 1.  The special characters are able to be entered using the corresponding keys  in an editor outside Eclipse, such as gedit. 2.  The specific keys for special characters can be used when creating a new  task. 3.  When text from an editor outside Eclipse is cut and then pasted onto the  editor inside Eclipse, the characters are displayed correctly and can be  correctly echoed to the console. 4.  These same keys can be used properly in gtk for all sections. 5.  Special characters can be entered into the simple file or java editor, but  by using a completely different sequence.  To achieve the "ö", you must type  Alt+[ and then o
my_mothod: OS: Linux Red Hat 8.0 Motif Build: RC2 with IBM JRE131  Summary:  Cannot input characters in German for motif using the same keystrokes  used to input the same characters in the editor of the OS.  For a German  keyboard, certain keys are designated for certain special chars., such as "["  is used for an "ä" and ";" is used for "ö".  These keys cannot be used to input  characters into a simple file or in the java editor.  Recreate Steps: 1.  Set keyboard to German keyboard. 2.  Launch Eclipse. 3.  Create a new project. 4.  Create a new class or a new file. 5.  Enter special chars using the specific keys.  Expected Result: Special Characters are displayed.  Execution Result: Nothing happens.  No character is entered.  Comments: 1.  The special characters are able to be entered using the corresponding keys  in an editor outside Eclipse, such as gedit. 2.  The specific keys for special characters can be used when creating a new  task. 3.  When text from an editor outside Eclipse is cut and then pasted onto the  editor inside Eclipse, the characters are displayed correctly and can be  correctly echoed to the console. 4.  These same keys can be used properly in gtk for all sections. 5.  Special characters can be entered into the simple file or java editor, but  by using a completely different sequence.  To achieve the "ö", you must type  Alt+[ and then o TVT21: Cannot input characters in German for motif critical SWT Platform

description: In 0319, I found what could be inconsistencies between .properties files and nls strings. All these entries are never used to nls a string: ast.variableShouldProvide element.onlyOneJavaModel ast.postIncrShouldProvide ast.missingStatement element.notPresent disassembler.methodtitle option.badFormat variable.badFormat element.classpathCycle element.cannotReconcile configure.noSourceFile eval.needBuiltState disassembler.constructor_method_name ast.compoundPreShouldProvide element.projectDoesNotExist ast.compoundVariableShouldProvide disassembler.parameternameinmethodinvocation  These entries are incorrectly used: abort.againstSourceModel  (a space has been added). convention.classFile.notJavaName should be: convention.classFile.notClassFileName path.nullpath should be: path.nullPath status.defaultPackeReadOnly should be replaced with: status.defaultPackageReadOnly  This is trivial to fix.
my_mothod: In 0319, I found what could be inconsistencies between .properties files and nls strings. All these entries are never used to nls a string: ast.variableShouldProvide element.onlyOneJavaModel ast.postIncrShouldProvide ast.missingStatement element.notPresent disassembler.methodtitle option.badFormat variable.badFormat element.classpathCycle element.cannotReconcile configure.noSourceFile eval.needBuiltState disassembler.constructor_method_name ast.compoundPreShouldProvide element.projectDoesNotExist ast.compoundVariableShouldProvide disassembler.parameternameinmethodinvocation  These entries are incorrectly used: abort.againstSourceModel  (a space has been added). convention.classFile.notJavaName should be: convention.classFile.notClassFileName path.nullpath should be: path.nullPath status.defaultPackeReadOnly should be replaced with: status.defaultPackageReadOnly  This is trivial to fix. [nls] Inconsistencies between properties files and nls strings trivial Core JDT

description: Build: 2.1 RC3  Reported on the newsgroup...  - if you define a "newWizard" whose extension has no "id" attribute, and there is an exception while initializing your wizard, the error message gets lost.  This is because the code in UI fails when trying to create a status object using the ID of the extension.  The Status constructor throws an assertion failure if you try to create a status with null or empty id.  Here is the guilty code in WorkbenchWizardNode (line 101):  statuses[0] =  	new Status( 		IStatus.ERROR,  wizardElement.getConfigurationElement().getDeclaringExtension().getUniqueIdentifier(), 		IStatus.OK,  		e.getMessage(),  		e);	  NOTE: the status constructor argument is supposed to be the plugin Id, not the extension id (which in many cases people don't bother to provide since it's not used anywhere else).  I think the correct code would be:  wizardElement.getConfigurationElement().getDeclaringExtension().getDeclaringPluginDescriptor().getUniqueIdentifier()
my_mothod: Build: 2.1 RC3  Reported on the newsgroup...  - if you define a "newWizard" whose extension has no "id" attribute, and there is an exception while initializing your wizard, the error message gets lost.  This is because the code in UI fails when trying to create a status object using the ID of the extension.  The Status constructor throws an assertion failure if you try to create a status with null or empty id.  Here is the guilty code in WorkbenchWizardNode (line 101):  statuses[0] =  	new Status( 		IStatus.ERROR,  wizardElement.getConfigurationElement().getDeclaringExtension().getUniqueIdentifier(), 		IStatus.OK,  		e.getMessage(),  		e);	  NOTE: the status constructor argument is supposed to be the plugin Id, not the extension id (which in many cases people don't bother to provide since it's not used anywhere else).  I think the correct code would be:  wizardElement.getConfigurationElement().getDeclaringExtension().getDeclaringPluginDescriptor().getUniqueIdentifier() [Wizards] Failure to propagate exception due to missing extension id minor UI Platform

description: The Eclipse compiler generates classes that throw a java.lang.VerifyError when  they are loaded. If Sun's javac or IBM's jikes is used to compile the same  class, no error occurs.  This happens when an inner class accesses a protected field belonging to the  base class of the outer class if the base class and the outer class are in  different packages. (Hope that makes sense!)  java.lang.VerifyError: (class: oranges/Derived$Inner, method: bug signature: () V) Incompatible type for getting or setting field 	at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method) 	at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:140) 	at Main.main(Main.java:4) Exception in thread "main"

(Hope that makes sense!)  java.lang.VerifyError: (class: oranges/Derived$Inner, method: bug signature: () V) Incompatible type for getting or setting field 	at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method) 	at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:140) 	at Main.main(Main.java:4) Exception in thread "main" The Eclipse compiler generates classes that throw a VerifyError critical Core JDT

description: When there are several dirty models in the workbench and the user is exiting  the workbench, there are cases that some of the files will not have the  opportunity to save and will cause loss of data. The failure case occur if one  of the editors with the dirty file attempts to abort the operation for some  reason (eg. unable to save the file).  Below are the steps to demonstrate the problem using text files but this is not  necessarily the only scenario where this problem will occur.  STEPS: 1) Create three text files in order (test1.txt, test2.txt and test3.txt) 2) Dirty all of the editors by typing something for each of them 3) Right-click on test2.txt in the Navigator and select Properties 4) Make the file read-only by checking the Read Only flag 5) Select File->Exit (or File->Close All) 6) Select all files in Save Resources dialog 7) An error dialog appears indicating that test2.txt was read-only  Result: All the editors are gone but only test1.txt will be saved. test2.txt and  test3.txt will not be saved. The user can potentially lose all their work.  Expected Result: The exit (or closing of the editors) should be prevented so that the user has  the opportunity to correct the problem file and save all other files.
my_mothod: When there are several dirty models in the workbench and the user is exiting  the workbench, there are cases that some of the files will not have the  opportunity to save and will cause loss of data. The failure case occur if one  of the editors with the dirty file attempts to abort the operation for some  reason (eg. unable to save the file).  Below are the steps to demonstrate the problem using text files but this is not  necessarily the only scenario where this problem will occur.  STEPS: 1) Create three text files in order (test1.txt, test2.txt and test3.txt) 2) Dirty all of the editors by typing something for each of them 3) Right-click on test2.txt in the Navigator and select Properties 4) Make the file read-only by checking the Read Only flag 5) Select File->Exit (or File->Close All) 6) Select all files in Save Resources dialog 7) An error dialog appears indicating that test2.txt was read-only  Result: All the editors are gone but only test1.txt will be saved. test2.txt and  test3.txt will not be saved. The user can potentially lose all their work.  Expected Result: The exit (or closing of the editors) should be prevented so that the user has  the opportunity to correct the problem file and save all other files. [Editor Mgmt] Exiting Eclipse with a problem file caused loss of data for other files critical UI Platform

description: In a Java code, type "for" <Ctrl+Space> and you get a list of templates  with "for". One of them is titled 'iterate over array w/ temporary variable'.  Although I understood this to be 'with', non-native English speakers may not  understand that abbreviation. I suggest a trivial change to 'with' to solve  this issue.
my_mothod: In a Java code, type "for" <Ctrl+Space> and you get a list of templates  with "for". One of them is titled 'iterate over array w/ temporary variable'.  Although I understood this to be 'with', non-native English speakers may not  understand that abbreviation. I suggest a trivial change to 'with' to solve  this issue. Unneccessary use of 'w/' for 'with' [Quick fix][wording] trivial Text JDT

description: I'm trying to run the final 2.1 release of Eclipse (GTK version) on my Linux system, which is a Red Hat 8.0 system.  My JVM is the 1.4.1 release.  Every time I try to launch Eclipse, it crashes with a NullPointerException.  I tried updating many, many packages (including XFree86, GTK, GNOME, etc.) from Red Hat's Rawhide distribution; it still crashes.  There are several warnings on the screen as well:  Warning: -os not understood. Ignoring. Warning: -ws not understood. Ignoring. Warning: -arch not understood. Ignoring. Warning: -showsplash not understood. Ignoring.  These are followed by a dialog box which says to check the .log file.  After dismissing the dialog, it exits.  The spash screen never appears.  I also tried launching it without a "workspace" directory in case any of the metadata was corrupted; it still crashed.
