description: The problem is initially discovered when we migrate our Javascript Debug  Adapter plugin code base to eclipse 2.1. Stepping over javascript line no  longer updates the top stackframe, the line number doesn't get updated. But it  wasn't a problem in eclipse 2.0.  After further investigation, the problem is narrowed down and can be reproduced  when debugging java code: 1. Set breakpoints at LaunchViewEventHandler line 159 and  LaunchViewEventHandler$ThreadTimer line 414.  (By doing so, we just simply want  to slow down the process a bit, and casue the wasTimeOut flag to be true.) 2. Start debugging runtime workbench. 3. Create a Java project within the runtime workbench, and create some simple  java classes. 4. Debug the Java project, stepping over the java source files in your project. 5. The breakpoints set in step 1 will get hit, just resume. => You will notice that the stack frame label stays at the old line when  stepping over your java source lines.
my_mothod: The problem is initially discovered when we migrate our Javascript Debug  Adapter plugin code base to eclipse 2.1. Stepping over javascript line no  longer updates the top stackframe, the line number doesn't get updated. But it  wasn't a problem in eclipse 2.0.  After further investigation, the problem is narrowed down and can be reproduced  when debugging java code: 1. Set breakpoints at LaunchViewEventHandler line 159 and  LaunchViewEventHandler$ThreadTimer line 414.  (By doing so, we just simply want  to slow down the process a bit, and casue the wasTimeOut flag to be true.) 2. Start debugging runtime workbench. 3. Create a Java project within the runtime workbench, and create some simple  java classes. 4. Debug the Java project, stepping over the java source files in your project. 5. The breakpoints set in step 1 will get hit, just resume. => You will notice that the stack frame label stays at the old line when  stepping over your java source lines. stackframe label not getting updated when stepping over source blocker Debug JDT

description: Text drawn using either the drawString or drawText APIs is not being properly  XOR'ed when setXORMode(true) has been called.  I have attached a simple testcase to illustrate the problem. The first line of  text is drawn with the xor mode set to false. The subsequent two lines are  drawn with xor mode set to true. Additionally, the test draws a rectangle  underneath each text line which is being properly xor'ed.  This bug is causing us to fail a test in the Personal Profile  compliance test suite.  Note that I'm running SWT version 3003.
my_mothod: Text drawn using either the drawString or drawText APIs is not being properly  XOR'ed when setXORMode(true) has been called.  I have attached a simple testcase to illustrate the problem. The first line of  text is drawn with the xor mode set to false. The subsequent two lines are  drawn with xor mode set to true. Additionally, the test draws a rectangle  underneath each text line which is being properly xor'ed.  This bug is causing us to fail a test in the Personal Profile  compliance test suite.  Note that I'm running SWT version 3003. GC.setXORMode() not applying to drawString/Text (BBAWT) critical SWT Platform

description: In the dialog for setting up Java application launch configurations, the Classpath tab shows only the names of JARs that are included. It is impossible, AFAICT, to determine where those JARs are located. The Project classpath tab has this info nicely displayed next to the JAR name - the launch config dialog should likewise display the full location of JARs, or have an option to show details of an included JAR.
my_mothod: In the dialog for setting up Java application launch configurations, the Classpath tab shows only the names of JARs that are included. It is impossible, AFAICT, to determine where those JARs are located. The Project classpath tab has this info nicely displayed next to the JAR name - the launch config dialog should likewise display the full location of JARs, or have an option to show details of an included JAR. Launch config dialog should have some way to determine the full location of JARs that are listed on the classpath enhancement Debug JDT

description: Comments: This is perhaps not a bug. Perhaps this is the wrong place to report this, in  which case my apologies, but since I'm on a character encoding crusade (see  reports 38074 and 38075) I thought I might mention this as well...  Problem: If a null encoding is passed to the org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.JETReader  constructor, character encoding "8859_1" is used instead of the platform  encoding. Source code comments say:         // XXX - longer term, this should really be:         //   System.getProperty("file.encoding", "8859_1");         // but this doesn't work right now, so we stick with ASCII  Solution: 1. I'm not sure why this would not work. Why not use this:       reader = null;       if (encoding == null)        {         reader = new InputStreamReader(iStream); // use platform encoding       }       else       {         reader = new InputStreamReader(iStream, encoding);       }  2. If this would not work for some reason, it might be better to disallow clients passing in a null encoding. I suggest throwing a NullPointerException and documenting this behaviour in the JETReader constructor javadoc.
my_mothod: Comments: This is perhaps not a bug. Perhaps this is the wrong place to report this, in  which case my apologies, but since I'm on a character encoding crusade (see  reports 38074 and 38075) I thought I might mention this as well...  Problem: If a null encoding is passed to the org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.JETReader  constructor, character encoding "8859_1" is used instead of the platform  encoding. Source code comments say:         // XXX - longer term, this should really be:         //   System.getProperty("file.encoding", "8859_1");         // but this doesn't work right now, so we stick with ASCII  Solution: 1. I'm not sure why this would not work. Why not use this:       reader = null;       if (encoding == null)        {         reader = new InputStreamReader(iStream); // use platform encoding       }       else       {         reader = new InputStreamReader(iStream, encoding);       }  2. If this would not work for some reason, it might be better to disallow clients passing in a null encoding. I suggest throwing a NullPointerException and documenting this behaviour in the JETReader constructor javadoc. JETReader should use platform character encoding instead of ISO-8859-1 minor Core EMF

description: When renaming a field, the dialog prompts to rename the getter as appropriate. The dialog says:  Rename getter 'String getName()' to 'getNewName'  The format of the old and new name are different; the type is missing from the front and there are no parenthesis after the method name. I think it should be:  Rename getter 'String getName()' to 'String getNewName()'   or even Rename getter 'getName()' to 'getNewName()'  since it doesn't really matter what the type of the method is; if it does, there should be a 'change field signature' in the same way as a 'change method signature' to modify it.  I suspect that the same is also true for a setter, but I've not seen the  renaming in action for that.
my_mothod: When renaming a field, the dialog prompts to rename the getter as appropriate. The dialog says:  Rename getter 'String getName()' to 'getNewName'  The format of the old and new name are different; the type is missing from the front and there are no parenthesis after the method name. I think it should be:  Rename getter 'String getName()' to 'String getNewName()'   or even Rename getter 'getName()' to 'getNewName()'  since it doesn't really matter what the type of the method is; if it does, there should be a 'change field signature' in the same way as a 'change method signature' to modify it.  I suspect that the same is also true for a setter, but I've not seen the  renaming in action for that. Refactor/Rename field; inconsistent 'getter' format [refactoring] trivial UI JDT

description: As part of the build configuration of one of my projects I have an external  builder which refreshes the project when it is done. I have also disabled  autobuild. I have a .jardesc file which describes the things that need to be  jared up. If I run create jar twice on that .jardesc and a dependant project  rebuilds it tried to refresh the resources. At the same time a pop-up shows  saying that the jar file exists would you like to overwrite. I cannot click on  yes because the refreshing projects dialog is showing. Eclipse remains in this  state indefinately. I think the refreshing resources dialog that shows after an  external build command doesn't close when it should!
my_mothod: As part of the build configuration of one of my projects I have an external  builder which refreshes the project when it is done. I have also disabled  autobuild. I have a .jardesc file which describes the things that need to be  jared up. If I run create jar twice on that .jardesc and a dependant project  rebuilds it tried to refresh the resources. At the same time a pop-up shows  saying that the jar file exists would you like to overwrite. I cannot click on  yes because the refreshing projects dialog is showing. Eclipse remains in this  state indefinately. I think the refreshing resources dialog that shows after an  external build command doesn't close when it should! Deadlock refreshing resources for an external tool when in background critical Ant Platform

description: Language: All DBCS languages OS: RedHat 8.0 Professional  Build driver: 20030604 Reporter: Yin Hong Mei   Test case #: 09.00500   Summary: There is some missing some text and fields on Run panel (under JRE  tab)  Description: on Run panel, under JRE tab, Missing 'Name of java executable  name' and its text field, 'Use default Java executable' and its checkbox. It  also happened on T.Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, but it is OK on SBCS languages Would you please take a look? Thank you for the suggestion.   Steps to recreate problem:  1. click Window -> Open Perspective -> Java.  2. From the main Workbench menu, click Run -> Run.... On the Run panel,  3. in the left box select Java Applet and click New at the bottom.  4. In the right pane, click the JRE tab.  Expected Result:  The panel is displayed correctly with text and two fields.  Execution Result:  Only one field is showing, and there is some missing text.  attached gif file for your reference.

description: I got a problem: _$$_ is legal identifier for class name. Eclipse can run it properly, but there is problem to debug into it.   This is a test case(file name:B_$$_uckets.java).   When put in same package, error message is :""There is no source file attached  to the class file B_$$_uckets.class"  When put in difference packages, error message is :"The source of the  type 'B__$$__uckets' could not be shown as the type was not found".  Examples:      /**  * Counters of random values that fall within each interval.  */ public class B__$$__uckets {     private static final int MAX_BAR_SIZE = 50;      private AlignRight ar = new AlignRight();      /** number of intervals */      private int n;     /** counters per interval */    private int counters[];      /** minimum random value */     private float rMin;     /** maximum random value */     private float rMax;     /** from min to max */          private float width;      /**      * Constructor.      * @param n the number of intervals      */     public B__$$__uckets(int n)     {         this.n = n;         this.counters = new int[n];         clear();     }      /**      * Return the counter value for interval i.      * @param i the value of i      * @return the counter value      */     public int get(int i) { return counters[i]; }      /**      * Set the minimum and maximum random values.      * @param rMin the minimum value      * @param rMax the maximum value      */     public void setLimits(float rMin, float rMax)     {         this.rMin  = rMin;         this.rMax  = rMax;         this.width = (rMax - rMin)/n;     }      /**      * Determine a random value's interval and count it.      * @param r the random value      */     public void put(float r)     {         // Ignore the value if it's out of range.         if ((r < rMin) || (r > rMax)) return;          // Determine its interval and count it.         int i = (int) ((r - rMin)/width);         ++counters[i];     }      /**      * Clear all the interval counters.      */     public void clear()     {         for (int i = 0; i < counters.length; ++i) counters[i] = 0;     }      /**      * Print the counter values as a horizontal bar chart. Scale the      * chart so that the longest bar is MAX_BAR_SIZE.      */     public void print()     {         // Get the longest bar's length.         int maxCount = 0;         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {             maxCount = Math.max(maxCount, counters[i]);         }          // Compute the scaling factor.         float factor = ((float) MAX_BAR_SIZE)/maxCount;          // Loop to print each bar.         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {             int b = counters[i];              // Interval number.             ar.print(i, 2);             ar.print(b, 7);             System.out.print(": ");              // Bar.             int length = Math.round(factor*b);             for (int j = 0; j < length; ++j) System.out.print("*");             System.out.println();         }     } }    I have tried Jbuilder, which can run/debug fine under exact same situation.

Examples:      /**  * Counters of random values that fall within each interval.  */ public class B__$$__uckets {     private static final int MAX_BAR_SIZE = 50;      private AlignRight ar = new AlignRight();      /** number of intervals */      private int n;     /** counters per interval */    private int counters[];      /** minimum random value */     private float rMin;     /** maximum random value */     private float rMax;     /** from min to max */          private float width;      /**      * Constructor.      * @param n the number of intervals      */     public B__$$__uckets(int n)     {         this.n = n;         this.counters = new int[n];         clear();     }      /**      * Return the counter value for interval i.      * @param i the value of i      * @return the counter value      */     public int get(int i) { return counters[i]; }      /**      * Set the minimum and maximum random values.      * @param rMin the minimum value      * @param rMax the maximum value      */     public void setLimits(float rMin, float rMax)     {         this.rMin  = rMin;         this.rMax  = rMax;         this.width = (rMax - rMin)/n;     }      /**      * Determine a random value's interval and count it.      * @param r the random value      */     public void put(float r)     {         // Ignore the value if it's out of range.         if ((r < rMin) || (r > rMax)) return;          // Determine its interval and count it.         int i = (int) ((r - rMin)/width);         ++counters[i];     }      /**      * Clear all the interval counters.      */     public void clear()     {         for (int i = 0; i < counters.length; ++i) counters[i] = 0;     }      /**      * Print the counter values as a horizontal bar chart. Scale the      * chart so that the longest bar is MAX_BAR_SIZE.      */     public void print()     {         // Get the longest bar's length.         int maxCount = 0;         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {             maxCount = Math.max(maxCount, counters[i]);         }          // Compute the scaling factor.         float factor = ((float) MAX_BAR_SIZE)/maxCount;          // Loop to print each bar.         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {             int b = counters[i];              // Interval number.             ar.print(i, 2);             ar.print(b, 7);             System.out.print(": ");              // Bar.             int length = Math.round(factor*b);             for (int j = 0; j < length; ++j) System.out.print("*");             System.out.println();         }     } }    I have tried Jbuilder, which can run/debug fine under exact same situation. can't debug into class if  file/class name identifier  has  _$$_ critical Debug Platform

description: Steps: 1)Create simple file named foo.usr. 2)Open the propertysheet example editor on this file. 3)Select a department (or group or whatever) and go to edit the name of that  object in the propertysheet 4) Shift+SPACE to enter canno input mode. 5) Type "nihongo" and press ENTER  When you press ENTER, the propertysheet receives either a bogus  widgetDefaultSelected event, or a bogus focusLost event.  In either case, the  entered canna text is lost.  This affects anyone who displays a popup celleditor and is interested in the  events mentioned above.  This bug affects multiple GEF clients in WSAD
my_mothod: Steps: 1)Create simple file named foo.usr. 2)Open the propertysheet example editor on this file. 3)Select a department (or group or whatever) and go to edit the name of that  object in the propertysheet 4) Shift+SPACE to enter canno input mode. 5) Type "nihongo" and press ENTER  When you press ENTER, the propertysheet receives either a bogus  widgetDefaultSelected event, or a bogus focusLost event.  In either case, the  entered canna text is lost.  This affects anyone who displays a popup celleditor and is interested in the  events mentioned above.  This bug affects multiple GEF clients in WSAD [CellEditors] [DBCS] canna input mode fires bogus event from Text Control critical UI Platform

description: Here's a simple test case that works just fine on Motif, Windows and OS X, but crashes on GTK.  We do something similar in GEF and it crashes the entire workbench -- I couldn't find anything in the log or console that even showed an error occured.  This test case here shows the following error message in the console:  Gtk-ERROR **: file gtktreestore.c: line 576 (gtk_tree_store_get_path): assertion failed: (G_NODE (iter->user_data)->parent != NULL)   import org.eclipse.swt.SWT; import org.eclipse.swt.events.DisposeEvent; import org.eclipse.swt.events.DisposeListener; import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;  public class TreeTest {  public static void main(String[] args) { 	Shell shell = new Shell(); 	Tree tree = new Tree(shell, SWT.NONE); 	final TreeItem item1 = new TreeItem(tree, SWT.NONE); 	item1.setText("Item 1"); 	item1.addDisposeListener(new DisposeListener() { 		public void widgetDisposed(DisposeEvent e) { 			boolean expanded = item1.getExpanded(); 		} 	}); 	tree.removeAll(); 	shell.open(); 	Display display = Display.getDefault(); 	while (!shell.isDisposed()) 		if (!display.readAndDispatch()) 			display.sleep(); 	display.dispose(); }  }
my_mothod: Here's a simple test case that works just fine on Motif, Windows and OS X, but crashes on GTK.  We do something similar in GEF and it crashes the entire workbench -- I couldn't find anything in the log or console that even showed an error occured.  This test case here shows the following error message in the console:  Gtk-ERROR **: file gtktreestore.c: line 576 (gtk_tree_store_get_path): assertion failed: (G_NODE (iter->user_data)->parent != NULL)   import org.eclipse.swt.SWT; import org.eclipse.swt.events.DisposeEvent; import org.eclipse.swt.events.DisposeListener; import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;  public class TreeTest {  public static void main(String[] args) { 	Shell shell = new Shell(); 	Tree tree = new Tree(shell, SWT.NONE); 	final TreeItem item1 = new TreeItem(tree, SWT.NONE); 	item1.setText("Item 1"); 	item1.addDisposeListener(new DisposeListener() { 		public void widgetDisposed(DisposeEvent e) { 			boolean expanded = item1.getExpanded(); 		} 	}); 	tree.removeAll(); 	shell.open(); 	Display display = Display.getDefault(); 	while (!shell.isDisposed()) 		if (!display.readAndDispatch()) 			display.sleep(); 	display.dispose(); }  } GTK Error calling TreeItem.getExpanded() on a tree item being disposed. major SWT Platform

description: When debugging using a super adapter (debug adapter that wrappers JDT), if the  user disables (or otherwise modifies) a Java breakpoint, the breakpoint changes  do not happen in active debug targets. The problem is that JavaBreakpoint.recreate() gets called, and it only checks  for instanceof JDIDebugTarget, so super debug adapters do not get the Java  breakpoint recreated. recreate() should be calling getAdapter(JDIDebugTarget.class) in order to  determine if this is a debug target that should be acted on.
my_mothod: When debugging using a super adapter (debug adapter that wrappers JDT), if the  user disables (or otherwise modifies) a Java breakpoint, the breakpoint changes  do not happen in active debug targets. The problem is that JavaBreakpoint.recreate() gets called, and it only checks  for instanceof JDIDebugTarget, so super debug adapters do not get the Java  breakpoint recreated. recreate() should be calling getAdapter(JDIDebugTarget.class) in order to  determine if this is a debug target that should be acted on. JavaBreakpoint.recreate() should call getAdapter(IJavaDebugTarget.class) critical Debug JDT

description: This is a documentation issue. The tutorial, "Creating an EMF Model using a Graphical Editor" on page http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/emf-home/docs/glibmod/glibmod_1.html incorrectly advises the user to create a "Simple Project."  This will fail with the model is to be generated.  The "add genmodel" button will throw an exception. Later, the edit and editor projects will be unable to find the simple project and will fail generation.  If the original project is specified as a Java project, everything works.
my_mothod: This is a documentation issue. The tutorial, "Creating an EMF Model using a Graphical Editor" on page http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/emf-home/docs/glibmod/glibmod_1.html incorrectly advises the user to create a "Simple Project."  This will fail with the model is to be generated.  The "add genmodel" button will throw an exception. Later, the edit and editor projects will be unable to find the simple project and will fail generation.  If the original project is specified as a Java project, everything works. Tutorial create graphical project incorrect minor Core EMF

description: I20030710  The Java element delta still informs clients about deleted working copies. Due  to the handle stability the destroyed working copy unit passed around in the  delta answer false for unit.isWorkingCopy(). Hence the listener things a  original was destroyed and in the affected case flushes the undo stack.  The question is: how do I now find out if a working copy got destroyed. Do I  have to check the owner ? Do we need some additional delta describing the  state change to and from a working copy ?
my_mothod: I20030710  The Java element delta still informs clients about deleted working copies. Due  to the handle stability the destroyed working copy unit passed around in the  delta answer false for unit.isWorkingCopy(). Hence the listener things a  original was destroyed and in the affected case flushes the undo stack.  The question is: how do I now find out if a working copy got destroyed. Do I  have to check the owner ? Do we need some additional delta describing the  state change to and from a working copy ? Deltas and deleted working copies critical Core JDT

description: I2030716 + plug-in export  On the Java compiler preference page there are preferences:  "Unsed X i.e. never read"  I see two problems here 1. unused might be dangerous when deleting: an assignment might have side effects. 2. the compiler messages says "...never read..."  I would simplify this to "Never read X"

description: Now you have to be exactly behind a brace to get CTRL-SHIFT-P working. This is  a bit annoying. Can't it just work every where in the file?  then it just searches for the brace i am in and toggles between begin and end. for example:  int foo() {    // code <<< cursor here 1.   if(bar())   {     // code <<< cursor here 2.     // some more code   } }  with cursor here 1 it shows the braces of the complete method with cursor here 2 it shows the braces of the if.

Can't it just work every where in the file?  then it just searches for the brace i am in and toggles between begin and end. for example:  int foo() {    // code <<< cursor here 1.   if(bar())   {     // code <<< cursor here 2.     // some more code   } }  with cursor here 1 it shows the braces of the complete method with cursor here 2 it shows the braces of the if. [navigation] Matching brace (Ctrl+Shift+P) should work anywhere in the file enhancement Text JDT

description: Currently it is possible to pass arguments to the JVM that Eclipse runs in with the -vmargs option on the command line.  The options given, however, aren't used when running a unit test or application; these start in their own JVM.  The JVM's arguments can be set from the "Run..." option.  It would be nice to have a way to configure a default set of arguments to the VM so that they don't have to be configured for every Run configuration individually.  For example, it might be really nice to be able to pass something like this to every Run instance by default:    -DproxySet=true -DproxyHost=foobar -DproxyPort=1080  (rather than having to set those up individually for every Junit class, etc)
my_mothod: Currently it is possible to pass arguments to the JVM that Eclipse runs in with the -vmargs option on the command line.  The options given, however, aren't used when running a unit test or application; these start in their own JVM.  The JVM's arguments can be set from the "Run..." option.  It would be nice to have a way to configure a default set of arguments to the VM so that they don't have to be configured for every Run configuration individually.  For example, it might be really nice to be able to pass something like this to every Run instance by default:    -DproxySet=true -DproxyHost=foobar -DproxyPort=1080  (rather than having to set those up individually for every Junit class, etc) [launching] Launch config  templates enhancement Debug JDT

description: In a Java based project, I sometimes use manual CVS updates and commits and also compile files outside Eclipse. This used to work when I used "Refresh" on the Eclipse side, or deleted the directory bin/ with the compiled Java binaries.  Sometimes I got the error "Save could not be completed. Reason: <projectname> does not exist.". A "Rebuild all" did not produce anything. Usually "Refresh" took care of this and made the error go away - up to now.  I have deleted the project directory, checked it out again from CVS, tried again - still the same. I have deleted the entire workspace (all projects + metadata) - and it still does not work anymore. Now I am lost about what I should do next.  In general I have found that Eclipse is very, very fragile once someone does even simple things such as editing a file outside eclipse. It should be much more stable with respect to that and refresh files automatically (use the time stamp of a directory for a quick check whether anything in it has changed).
my_mothod: In a Java based project, I sometimes use manual CVS updates and commits and also compile files outside Eclipse. This used to work when I used "Refresh" on the Eclipse side, or deleted the directory bin/ with the compiled Java binaries.  Sometimes I got the error "Save could not be completed. Reason: <projectname> does not exist.". A "Rebuild all" did not produce anything. Usually "Refresh" took care of this and made the error go away - up to now.  I have deleted the project directory, checked it out again from CVS, tried again - still the same. I have deleted the entire workspace (all projects + metadata) - and it still does not work anymore. Now I am lost about what I should do next.  In general I have found that Eclipse is very, very fragile once someone does even simple things such as editing a file outside eclipse. It should be much more stable with respect to that and refresh files automatically (use the time stamp of a directory for a quick check whether anything in it has changed). [misc] Eclipse cannot save or compile files in non-Java project anymore critical Core JDT

description: In Solaris,using GNU make 3.80, I create a new Managed C++ executable project. Then right click on the project and add new file called main.cpp. The incremental build kicks in (separate defect) and nothing is produced. The  real problem is when I call Rebuild project, the release directory gets  created, but an empty makefile is created and the error: "Problems occured  building the selected resources" with the details: "java.lang.NoSuchMethodError  encountered while running  org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.GeneratedMakefileBuilder." The .log file points  to the method populateMakefile is not found.  Since the same makefile build process occurs with linux and this is not a  problem in linux, there must be something bad in the cdt build 1.2.0.24.

description: Upon distribution of CDT 1.2, customers will have to create new projects & copy  old files to be able to use the new indexer. As this is unacceptable for many  customers, we'll need a script to change all existing standard  projects' .cdtproject files or if time doesn't permit, at least document the  manual changes a customer must make in order to upgrade their project to use  the new indexer.
my_mothod: Upon distribution of CDT 1.2, customers will have to create new projects & copy  old files to be able to use the new indexer. As this is unacceptable for many  customers, we'll need a script to change all existing standard  projects' .cdtproject files or if time doesn't permit, at least document the  manual changes a customer must make in order to upgrade their project to use  the new indexer. Upgrade old projects to CDT 1.2 critical cdt-core CDT

description: Used Linux, CDT 1.2.0.24, GNU Make version 3.79.1, managed make c executable  project.  When calling make from commandline module.mk doesn't contain main.c in C_SRCS  because main.c wasn't modified. So the linker line in the makefile didn't link  in main.o:  cexe: $(CC_SRCS:$(ROOT)/%.cpp=%.o) $(C_SRCS:$(ROOT)/%.c=%.o) 	g++ -L/home/twolff/cdt/linux/workspaces/ws2/cproj/Release -o $@ $^  The translation that appeared in the command line is g++ -L/home/twolff/cdt/linux/workspaces/ws2/cproj/Release -lcproj -o  cexe ../main.c  ../main.c should be main.o
my_mothod: Used Linux, CDT 1.2.0.24, GNU Make version 3.79.1, managed make c executable  project.  When calling make from commandline module.mk doesn't contain main.c in C_SRCS  because main.c wasn't modified. So the linker line in the makefile didn't link  in main.o:  cexe: $(CC_SRCS:$(ROOT)/%.cpp=%.o) $(C_SRCS:$(ROOT)/%.c=%.o) 	g++ -L/home/twolff/cdt/linux/workspaces/ws2/cproj/Release -o $@ $^  The translation that appeared in the command line is g++ -L/home/twolff/cdt/linux/workspaces/ws2/cproj/Release -lcproj -o  cexe ../main.c  ../main.c should be main.o Incremental builds for managed projects must be implemented critical cdt-core CDT

description: I like black backgrounds.  I've changed my editor accordingly.  However, the declaration view shows a light yellow background.  Colors that show up well on black do not show up on light yellow.  This general assumption throughout JDT that the background for java code should be colorized against and arbitrary background is a consistent reocurring issue.  It's been a problem in diff viewers, various "popups" (and other places, I think).  They should either:  a) use the editor background b) not colorize the java code or c) let me set a background color for that usage explicitly.  In the case of Declaration view, I can certainly see the advantage in having the background NOT be the the same as the editor, so let me set that in the preferences.
my_mothod: I like black backgrounds.  I've changed my editor accordingly.  However, the declaration view shows a light yellow background.  Colors that show up well on black do not show up on light yellow.  This general assumption throughout JDT that the background for java code should be colorized against and arbitrary background is a consistent reocurring issue.  It's been a problem in diff viewers, various "popups" (and other places, I think).  They should either:  a) use the editor background b) not colorize the java code or c) let me set a background color for that usage explicitly.  In the case of Declaration view, I can certainly see the advantage in having the background NOT be the the same as the editor, so let me set that in the preferences. [preferences] Tooltip and info views background color clashes with editor colors enhancement Text JDT

description: Build: 3.0 M3 warm-up VM: Sun 1.4.2  1. Create a Hello, world plug-in project 2. Right-click on the plug-in's build.xml and select 'Create Ant Build File' 3. Right-click on the build.xml from 2. and select Run Ant...   I got a dialog asking me: "The specified Ant runtime classpath does not  include a tools.jar library.  This may affect the ability to use various  tasks.  Ignore this possible problem?" I answered yes. 4. An identical dialog reappeared.  Answered yes. 5. The Ant launch config. dialog appeared. 6. Click on the Classpath tab, the dialog appears again.  If you answer no, an  error overlay appears, and the 'Run' button is disabled. 7. If you repeat 5 and 6 and answer 'no' in 6, you can run, but the following  error appears: "[filename:50]: Unable to find a javac compiler: com.sun.tools.javac.Main is  not on the classpath.  Perhaps JAVA_HOME does not point to the JDK.  I have been using the same JRE for quite some time and always been able to  buils.  What has changed?  My code certainly hasn't.

Create and build a simple HelloWorld executable. 2. Create a Debug configuration (using Cygwin Debugger). 3. Launch the debug configuration. description: I created a plugin/fragment/update site (as described in the Eclipse.org article of late) but could  not find a way to get the local site into update manager.  It's also a pretty horrible file chooser; only shows a tree view of what's on your disk. The standard  Mac file chooser is much better, since it allows you to (a) type a file in, and (b) see it as columnar  view instead (which I much prefer).  Selecting the directory didn't enable the OK button, so I couldn't get to it, but I could if I put the  same directory in my local webserver (and used it as a remote site)  So it appears not to be an issue with the update feature, just that it can't select the directory for a  local update ...
my_mothod: I created a plugin/fragment/update site (as described in the Eclipse.org article of late) but could  not find a way to get the local site into update manager.  It's also a pretty horrible file chooser; only shows a tree view of what's on your disk. The standard  Mac file chooser is much better, since it allows you to (a) type a file in, and (b) see it as columnar  view instead (which I much prefer).  Selecting the directory didn't enable the OK button, so I couldn't get to it, but I could if I put the  same directory in my local webserver (and used it as a remote site)  So it appears not to be an issue with the update feature, just that it can't select the directory for a  local update ... Cannot add new local site in UpdateManager trivial Update  (deprecated - use Eclipse>Equinox>p2) Platform

description: It's possible to select a source folder's parent as the output folder, as described below. This has the majorly annoying side-effect of wiping out your source code. Viz:  Suppose you have a project named MyProject.  - Create a source folder MyDir/src as a source folder. This will set the new default output directory to MyProject/bin.  - Create a class, package com.abs.stc, name Hello, in this directory.  Now change the source folder to /MyDir/src and the output folder to /MyDir as follows:   - Right click on the project and select Properties->Java Build Path->Source. - click on Allow output folders for source folders. Click on Output folder, (expand the source folder MyProject/MyDir/src if necessary), press Edit, click on "Specific Output Folder" and change it to MyDir. Click OK.  - You'll get a message about not being able to nest MyProject/MyDir/src inside MyProject/MyDir. Make this message go away by changing the Default output folder at the bottom of the dialog box from MyProject/bin to MyProject. (This is probably where this bug should get fixed; it shouldn't let you do this.)  - Click OK. You'll get a message box asking if it's OK to remove the old generated sources from the old output folder; click Yes. BOOM! If you're using Eclipse 3.0 or 2.1.1, this will immediately wipe out your source directory.  (If you're using 2.1, you get a reprieve; your source directory won't get wiped until try to run Hello.java when you get an error about the main class not being found.)
my_mothod: It's possible to select a source folder's parent as the output folder, as described below. This has the majorly annoying side-effect of wiping out your source code. Viz:  Suppose you have a project named MyProject.  - Create a source folder MyDir/src as a source folder. This will set the new default output directory to MyProject/bin.  - Create a class, package com.abs.stc, name Hello, in this directory.  Now change the source folder to /MyDir/src and the output folder to /MyDir as follows:   - Right click on the project and select Properties->Java Build Path->Source. - click on Allow output folders for source folders. Click on Output folder, (expand the source folder MyProject/MyDir/src if necessary), press Edit, click on "Specific Output Folder" and change it to MyDir. Click OK.  - You'll get a message about not being able to nest MyProject/MyDir/src inside MyProject/MyDir. Make this message go away by changing the Default output folder at the bottom of the dialog box from MyProject/bin to MyProject. (This is probably where this bug should get fixed; it shouldn't let you do this.)  - Click OK. You'll get a message box asking if it's OK to remove the old generated sources from the old output folder; click Yes. BOOM! If you're using Eclipse 3.0 or 2.1.1, this will immediately wipe out your source directory.  (If you're using 2.1, you get a reprieve; your source directory won't get wiped until try to run Hello.java when you get an error about the main class not being found.) Eclipse allows setting a source folder's parent as output folder, which wipes out source code critical Core JDT

description: Build I20030903 (note that this does not happen using previous build I20030829)  I get an "Error Accessing Compilation Unit" error (reason: Index out of bounds)  while using code assist on a brand new created class.  Scenario to reproduce the problem: 1) Create a class 'X' 2) Modify class 'X' by adding a public method 'foo' 3) Save the modification 4) Create a class 'Y' 5) Modify class 'Y' as follow: public class Y { 	X x; 	public void foo() { 	} } 6) *** DO NOT SAVE *** 7) Now, type 'x.' in method foo and try to get code assist => you get the error

Scenario to reproduce the problem: 1) Create a class 'X' 2) Modify class 'X' by adding a public method 'foo' 3) Save the modification 4) Create a class 'Y' 5) Modify class 'Y' as follow: public class Y { 	X x; 	public void foo() { 	} } 6) *** DO NOT SAVE *** 7) Now, type 'x.' in method foo and try to get code assist => you get the error Error accessing compilation unit while using code assist critical Text JDT

description: I have a .jj file that is processed using JavaCC. If these files are compiled using command line javac (with debug on or off) or within Eclipse using Ant, the program runs correctly. However, when compiled using Eclipse, I get an error like the following:  Exception in thread "main" java.lang.VerifyError: (class: org/rubato/rubettes/denotex/DenotexParser, method: basicModule signature: ()Lorg/rubato/math/module/Module;) Illegal target of jump or branch  Here DenotexParser is the file generated by JavaCC, basicModule is a method generated from a rule in the JavaCC file, that returns an object of class Module.
my_mothod: I have a .jj file that is processed using JavaCC. If these files are compiled using command line javac (with debug on or off) or within Eclipse using Ant, the program runs correctly. However, when compiled using Eclipse, I get an error like the following:  Exception in thread "main" java.lang.VerifyError: (class: org/rubato/rubettes/denotex/DenotexParser, method: basicModule signature: ()Lorg/rubato/math/module/Module;) Illegal target of jump or branch  Here DenotexParser is the file generated by JavaCC, basicModule is a method generated from a rule in the JavaCC file, that returns an object of class Module. JavaCC files cause VerifyError when compiled with Eclipse blocker Core JDT

description: With 1.2.0.40 1. Add code as below into a CPP file. 2. Search for All Occurrences of All Elements named "*". 3. The last 2 lines of the file contain no occurrences. EXPECTED: they should.  class StaticMemberTests{ public: 	int w; 	static int x; };  int StaticMemberTests::x = 3;   void foo() { 	StaticMemberTests s; 	int i=0; 	i += 7; 	s.w = i; // this line breaks the parser 	i += 42; }

description: Using the installer/updater, I updated from build 44 to 45. In addition to  c/c++ development and source tools in the cdt update page, there was an new  package, Managed builder, so I installed that as well. Tried to create a new  c++ project, but there was only standard project and convert to c++ project in  the list of project types in the new project wizard.
my_mothod: Using the installer/updater, I updated from build 44 to 45. In addition to  c/c++ development and source tools in the cdt update page, there was an new  package, Managed builder, so I installed that as well. Tried to create a new  c++ project, but there was only standard project and convert to c++ project in  the list of project types in the new project wizard. Managed c/c++ project types gone from New Project wizard blocker cdt-core CDT

description: Build: I-20030917  I am not able to run any junit plug-in test cases because during the  initialization of the workbench, RoleManager.readRoles() makes the assumption  that the plug-in "org.eclipse.platform" is in the registry.  This plug-in does  not need to be there, as users should be able to test their plug-ins with the  minimal set of plug-ins.  Consequently, RoleManager throws a null pointer  exception at line 76.  To reproduce in a fresh workspace, check out org.eclipse.ui.tests from CVS.   Import into your workspace only the plug-ins required by this plug-in (i.e.  the second option in the ToImport section of the import wizard).  Make sure no  external plug-ins are selected.  Try to run junit plug-in tests and you will  fail with a null pointer.
my_mothod: Build: I-20030917  I am not able to run any junit plug-in test cases because during the  initialization of the workbench, RoleManager.readRoles() makes the assumption  that the plug-in "org.eclipse.platform" is in the registry.  This plug-in does  not need to be there, as users should be able to test their plug-ins with the  minimal set of plug-ins.  Consequently, RoleManager throws a null pointer  exception at line 76.  To reproduce in a fresh workspace, check out org.eclipse.ui.tests from CVS.   Import into your workspace only the plug-ins required by this plug-in (i.e.  the second option in the ToImport section of the import wizard).  Make sure no  external plug-ins are selected.  Try to run junit plug-in tests and you will  fail with a null pointer. readRoles() throws a null pointer critical UI Platform

description: I20030925 + JDT/Core build input for 20030930  The failing test case is MoveTest. Here is what happens:  - we create a Java project with a source folder - the source folder contains   p1 with cus A.java and B.java   p2 with cu C.java - then we move the two cus from p1 to p2 using the following Java/Core API:   getCu().move(getDestinationPackage(), null, newName, true, pm);   Both the cu to move (e.g. call getCu()) and the destination package are   recreated from handles (e.g. strings like "=TestProject1064857227528/src<p1 {A.java"  - after moving the cus a call getChildren() to the package fragment p1 created    in the test returns the two children A.java and B.java.  - checking on the file system reveals that they have been correctly moved to   p2.
my_mothod: I20030925 + JDT/Core build input for 20030930  The failing test case is MoveTest. Here is what happens:  - we create a Java project with a source folder - the source folder contains   p1 with cus A.java and B.java   p2 with cu C.java - then we move the two cus from p1 to p2 using the following Java/Core API:   getCu().move(getDestinationPackage(), null, newName, true, pm);   Both the cu to move (e.g. call getCu()) and the destination package are   recreated from handles (e.g. strings like "=TestProject1064857227528/src<p1 {A.java"  - after moving the cus a call getChildren() to the package fragment p1 created    in the test returns the two children A.java and B.java.  - checking on the file system reveals that they have been correctly moved to   p2. IPackageFragment not updated after CUs have moved critical Core JDT

description: Here is the tested scenario. * the debug view has handled a suspend event, and is trying to open an editor on the associated compilation unit, in the "main thread"  * the test has made changes to the same compilation unit, and is saving the changes (testing HCR), in the "test thread"  * the (saved) changes to the compilation unit, have caused the UISyncronizer to do a sync exec (i.e. waiting on the main thread). description: ZRH build input + JDT/Core v373c  - create fresh workspace - create JUnit project with output folder bin (the output folder   seems to be important. Problem doesn't show up with default   output folder) - load JUnit 3.8.1 (I attach it to the PR) - select TestCase in package explorer and do a search for references  observe:  - you get an dialog informing you about inexact matches. Strange ? - the result only contains parts of the matches. For example all "extends    TestCase" are missing (e.g. SimpleTest, ....)  Refactoring is heavily affected by this problem.

Strange ? - the result only contains parts of the matches. For example all "extends    TestCase" are missing (e.g. SimpleTest, ....)  Refactoring is heavily affected by this problem. Search broken critical Core JDT

description: I just install Eclipse 3.0M4 and configure my project with external source path  (with "link to folder in the file system") and now it's impossible to open my  java file (from package explorer for example). There is a dialog box : "cannot open default editor on name_of_file.java.  Editor could not be initialized". But everything is OK for a project without source in external path (ie: all  sources under 'workspace' folder).  It was OK with Eclipse 3.0M3.

description: Typing :  System.out.println(new String());   select 'new String()' and apply ELV , works.  Typing :  new String()  Select 'new String()' and apply ELV , does not work - error is "An expression must be selected to activate this refactoring"   I'm reasonably sure "new String();" is an expresssion and can serve as an RHS. I even checked with IDEA, and we seem to agree :-)
my_mothod: Typing :  System.out.println(new String());   select 'new String()' and apply ELV , works.  Typing :  new String()  Select 'new String()' and apply ELV , does not work - error is "An expression must be selected to activate this refactoring"   I'm reasonably sure "new String();" is an expresssion and can serve as an RHS. I even checked with IDEA, and we seem to agree :-) Extract Local Variable also on ExpressionStatements [refactoring] minor UI JDT

description: Using Eclipse 2.1.1 to develop Java Applets on Windows 2000 SP4.  Problem noticed when editing the Java Applet parameters in the "Create, manage,  and run configurations" window availabe under the Run/Run menu selection, Java  Applet configuration, Parameters tab.  Removing a parameter does not cause  the "Apply" and "Revert" buttons to become enabled (ungreyed out).  In order to  get the buttons to be enabled, you must either add a new parameter or edit an  existing parameter.  Reproducable:  Always.  To reproduce, create new project, create new class that  extends Applet, select Run/Run to bring up window.  Select Java Applet and  click new button, click on Applet class name that appears, select parameters  tab, click "Add" and create bogus parameter, click Apply.  Then select the  newly created parameter and click remove.  Apply and Revert buttons will not be  available and you cannot save your removal.  Workaround:  Simply create a bogus parameter and immediately remove it in  addition to the parameters that you want to remove.  This will enable both  buttons.
my_mothod: Using Eclipse 2.1.1 to develop Java Applets on Windows 2000 SP4.  Problem noticed when editing the Java Applet parameters in the "Create, manage,  and run configurations" window availabe under the Run/Run menu selection, Java  Applet configuration, Parameters tab.  Removing a parameter does not cause  the "Apply" and "Revert" buttons to become enabled (ungreyed out).  In order to  get the buttons to be enabled, you must either add a new parameter or edit an  existing parameter.  Reproducable:  Always.  To reproduce, create new project, create new class that  extends Applet, select Run/Run to bring up window.  Select Java Applet and  click new button, click on Applet class name that appears, select parameters  tab, click "Add" and create bogus parameter, click Apply.  Then select the  newly created parameter and click remove.  Apply and Revert buttons will not be  available and you cannot save your removal.  Workaround:  Simply create a bogus parameter and immediately remove it in  addition to the parameters that you want to remove.  This will enable both  buttons. Removing parameters in Run/Java Applet does not enable Apply trivial Debug JDT

description: Test case: 1. Create a 'Managed C++ Executable Project' (call it A). 2. Create a 'Managed C++ Static Library Project' (call it B). 3. Add a class to each respective project. 4. Open the project properties for A, select the 'C/C++ Build' item from the  listbox on the left. Click the 'Manage' button and change the 'Make command'  from 'make' to 'make -t'. 5. Do the same for B, but use 'make -s' instead. 6. Build A and B.  Note that the properties of -t and -s are applied to A and B respectively.  6. Open the project properties of A and select 'Project References' from the  listbox on the left.  Make A reference B. 7. Delete the 'Release' directories (created by step 6) under A and B in the  project view. 8. Right click on project A and select 'Rebuild project'.  RESULT:  make -t is used to build both A and B as expected.  The problem is that the build information echoed to the console does not  completely reflect this. (See below)  1  make -t clean all  2  make: Nothing to be done for `clean'. 3  cd C:/eclipse/workspace/B/Release && make clean all 4  make[1]: Entering directory `/cygdrive/c/eclipse/workspace/B/Release' 5  make[1]: Nothing to be done for `clean'. 6  touch B.o 7  touch libB.a 8  make[1]: Nothing to be done for `all'. 9  make[1]: Leaving directory `/cygdrive/c/eclipse/workspace/B/Release' 10 touch A.o 11 touch A.exe 12 Build complete for project A  Line 1 indicates that the 'make -t' command is being issued, but line 3 does  not; however, we know it was used because lines 6 and 7 tell us so.  This may just be a problem with make...
my_mothod: Test case: 1. Create a 'Managed C++ Executable Project' (call it A). 2. Create a 'Managed C++ Static Library Project' (call it B). 3. Add a class to each respective project. 4. Open the project properties for A, select the 'C/C++ Build' item from the  listbox on the left. Click the 'Manage' button and change the 'Make command'  from 'make' to 'make -t'. 5. Do the same for B, but use 'make -s' instead. 6. Build A and B.  Note that the properties of -t and -s are applied to A and B respectively.  6. Open the project properties of A and select 'Project References' from the  listbox on the left.  Make A reference B. 7. Delete the 'Release' directories (created by step 6) under A and B in the  project view. 8. Right click on project A and select 'Rebuild project'.  RESULT:  make -t is used to build both A and B as expected.  The problem is that the build information echoed to the console does not  completely reflect this. (See below)  1  make -t clean all  2  make: Nothing to be done for `clean'. 3  cd C:/eclipse/workspace/B/Release && make clean all 4  make[1]: Entering directory `/cygdrive/c/eclipse/workspace/B/Release' 5  make[1]: Nothing to be done for `clean'. 6  touch B.o 7  touch libB.a 8  make[1]: Nothing to be done for `all'. 9  make[1]: Leaving directory `/cygdrive/c/eclipse/workspace/B/Release' 10 touch A.o 11 touch A.exe 12 Build complete for project A  Line 1 indicates that the 'make -t' command is being issued, but line 3 does  not; however, we know it was used because lines 6 and 7 tell us so.  This may just be a problem with make... make arguments not being echoed to the console minor cdt-core CDT

description: Pop-Up menus do not work on tables per the following code:  import org.eclipse.swt.*; import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;  public class Main {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		Display display = new Display(); 		Shell shell = new Shell(display); 		Table table = new Table(shell, SWT.MULTI | SWT.BORDER |  SWT.FULL_SELECTION); 		table.setLinesVisible(true); 		table.setHeaderVisible(true); 		String[] titles =  { " ", "C", "!", "Description", "Resource", "In Folder", "Location" }; 		for (int i = 0; i < titles.length; i++) { 			TableColumn column = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NULL); 			column.setText(titles[i]); 		} 		int count = 128; 		for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) { 			TableItem item = new TableItem(table, SWT.NULL); 			item.setText(0, "x"); 			item.setText(1, "y"); 			item.setText(2, "!"); 			item.setText(3, "this stuff behaves the way I expect"); 			item.setText(4, "almost everywhere"); 			item.setText(5, "some.folder"); 			item.setText(6, "line " + i + " in nowhere"); 		} 		for (int i = 0; i < titles.length; i++) { 			table.getColumn(i).pack(); 		} 		table.setSize(table.computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, 200));  		Menu menu = new Menu(table); 		MenuItem item = new MenuItem(menu, SWT.CASCADE); 		item.setText("item 1"); 		MenuItem item2 = new MenuItem(menu, SWT.CASCADE); 		item2.setText("item 2"); 		table.setMenu(menu); 		 		 		shell.pack(); 		shell.open(); 		while (!shell.isDisposed()) { 			if (!display.readAndDispatch()) 				display.sleep(); 		} 		display.dispose(); 	} }

description: Disclaimer: Maybe I just don't know how to use the Display view properly, in  which case I apologize in advance for wasting everybody's time.  It seems that you can't perform the Display action in the view unless you  select the full expression and select 'Display' from the context menu or from  the toolbar menu. I would expect that pressing Enter at the end of the line should automatically  invoke the Display action on the expression I just typed. Having to select the full line, which can be potentially be long, is too much.  Another thing I tried was to double-click on the line hoping that it would  highlight the entire expression (much like when you double-click on the URL in  the address bar of a browser).  But double-clicking on the expression in the  Display view selects a segment of the expression which is useless.
my_mothod: Disclaimer: Maybe I just don't know how to use the Display view properly, in  which case I apologize in advance for wasting everybody's time.  It seems that you can't perform the Display action in the view unless you  select the full expression and select 'Display' from the context menu or from  the toolbar menu. I would expect that pressing Enter at the end of the line should automatically  invoke the Display action on the expression I just typed. Having to select the full line, which can be potentially be long, is too much.  Another thing I tried was to double-click on the line hoping that it would  highlight the entire expression (much like when you double-click on the URL in  the address bar of a browser).  But double-clicking on the expression in the  Display view selects a segment of the expression which is useless. Double click to select current line in Display View enhancement Debug JDT

description: When using "Check Out As" on a directory in a CVS repository, the project name  is defaulted to the directory name. Changing the directory name to something  else (the whole point of check out as) and selecting next displays the  workspace location page with the "Use default workspace location" already  checked and the contents of the location edit field disabled, but displaying  the *original* directory name, not the name as just entered on the previous  page. Un-checking and re-checking "Use default workspace location" results in  the correct value being shown.  Note - the correct, new project name is used for the workspace on checkout - it  just appears that it won't be first time through.  Also, the status messages displayed in the status area as checkout is going on  also use the old, incorrect project name.
my_mothod: When using "Check Out As" on a directory in a CVS repository, the project name  is defaulted to the directory name. Changing the directory name to something  else (the whole point of check out as) and selecting next displays the  workspace location page with the "Use default workspace location" already  checked and the contents of the location edit field disabled, but displaying  the *original* directory name, not the name as just entered on the previous  page. Un-checking and re-checking "Use default workspace location" results in  the correct value being shown.  Note - the correct, new project name is used for the workspace on checkout - it  just appears that it won't be first time through.  Also, the status messages displayed in the status area as checkout is going on  also use the old, incorrect project name. (PatchAttached)[Checkout] "Check Out As" shows deceptive default location. minor CVS Platform

description: Some icons in the toolbar are cut-off or obscured.  1.) Open I20031104 on GTK. 2.) Open the Team Synchronizing perspective as a new window. 3.) Reset perspective to defaults.   OBSERVED RESULTS: If the window is 1280x1024, then (almost) all of the icons appear on the toolbar.  If the window is any smaller, then some icons are cut-off or obscured.  The most irritating is that the "mode" icons (out, in, both) don't all show.

OBSERVED RESULTS: If the window is 1280x1024, then (almost) all of the icons appear on the toolbar.  If the window is any smaller, then some icons are cut-off or obscured.  The most irritating is that the "mode" icons (out, in, both) don't all show. [Widgets] Toolbar does not support WRAP style major SWT Platform

description: Since I upgraded from version 2.1.1 to version 3.0M4, I have been getting  ClassCastExceptions intermittently, although I have found a way to reproduce  it. The culprit is the 'isSynchronized' method of FileDocumentProvider in  package org.eclipse.ui.editors.text:  	/* 	 * @see  org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.IDocumentProviderExtension3#isSynchronized (java.lang.Object) 	 * @since 3.0 	 */ 	public boolean isSynchronized(Object element) { 		Object elementInfo= getElementInfo(element); 		if (elementInfo instanceof FileInfo) { 			FileEditorInput input= (FileEditorInput) element; 			IResource resource= input.getFile(); 			return resource.isSynchronized(IResource.DEPTH_ZERO); 		} 		return false; 	}  That cast is not safe, why not use 'instanceof' on 'element' instead  of 'elementInfo' to guard it properly? Why bother getting the 'element into',  whatever that is, at all. It isn't used. Anyways, the solution that you guys  might want is to cast 'element' to 'IFileEditorInput' instead  of 'FileEditorInput'. I have my own editor input that is an 'IFileEditorInput'  but not a 'FileEditorInput', and so I get a ClassCastException.  This would be my rewrite:  	public boolean isSynchronized(Object element) { 		if (element instanceof IFileEditorInput) { 			FileEditorInput input= (FileEditorInput) element; 			IResource resource= input.getFile(); 			return resource.isSynchronized(IResource.DEPTH_ZERO); 		} 		return false; 	}

Why bother getting the 'element into',  whatever that is, at all. It isn't used. Anyways, the solution that you guys  might want is to cast 'element' to 'IFileEditorInput' instead  of 'FileEditorInput'. This would be my rewrite:  	public boolean isSynchronized(Object element) { 		if (element instanceof IFileEditorInput) { 			FileEditorInput input= (FileEditorInput) element; 			IResource resource= input.getFile(); 			return resource.isSynchronized(IResource.DEPTH_ZERO); 		} 		return false; 	} [misc] ClassCastException in isSynchronized of FileDocumentProvider critical Text Platform

description:
Hello Ed, Dan wanted me to open a bugzilla to track this problem. I have one problem when I have an xsd file including/importing another xsd file. The files to reproduce this are any file that includes another file. In my example I have top.xsd including external.xsd with schemaLocation = "external.xsd" We need XSDConstants resolveSchemaLocation(String baseSchemaLocationURI, String namespaceURI, String schemaLocationURI) to return "MSet/external.xsd" when you load top.xsd and this method gets called to resolve external.xsd. Now let me explain what is happening when we use com.ibm.etools.xsd /** * Resolve the namespace and schema location relative to the base schema location. * For example, the expression *
    *  resolveSchemaLocation    *    ("http://www.example.com/A/a.xsd",     *     "http://www.example.com/B",     *     "../B/b.xsd");    *
* would yield *
    *  "http://www.example.com/B/b.xsd"    *
* When no namespace schema location is provided, the namespace itself will be used. * @param baseSchemaLocationURI the location of the schema containing the reference, i.e., {@link com.ibm.etools.xsd.XSDSchema#getSchemaLocation}. * @param namespaceURI the namespace being resolved, i.e., {@link com.ibm.etools.xsd.XSDImport#getNamespace}. * @param schemaLocationURI the suggested location of the namespace being resolved, i.e., {@link com.ibm.etools.xsd.XSDImport#getSchemaLocation}. * @return the resolved schema location. */ public static String resolveSchemaLocation(String baseSchemaLocationURI, String namespaceURI, String schemaLocationURI) { try { if (schemaLocationURI == null) { schemaLocationURI = namespaceURI; } if (schemaLocationURI != null) { URI schemaLocation = URIFactoryRegister.getFactory().makeURI (schemaLocationURI); String schemaLocationFile = schemaLocation.getFile(); IPath schemaLocationPath = new Path(schemaLocationFile); if (!schemaLocationPath.isAbsolute()) { int index = baseSchemaLocationURI.lastIndexOf("/"); baseSchemaLocationURI = baseSchemaLocationURI.substring(0, index); if (index != -1) { if (schemaLocationPath.segmentCount() > 0) { while (schemaLocationPath.segment(0).equals("..")) { int indexOfSlash = baseSchemaLocationURI.lastIndexOf("/"); if (indexOfSlash != -1) { schemaLocationPath = schemaLocationPath.removeFirstSegments (1); baseSchemaLocationURI = baseSchemaLocationURI.substring(0, indexOfSlash); } else { break; } } } String resolvedSchemaLocation = baseSchemaLocationURI + "/" + schemaLocationPath; return resolvedSchemaLocation; } } } } catch (Exception exception) { exception.printStackTrace(); } return schemaLocationURI; } When I load top.xsd the XSDConstants.resolveSchemaLocation() gets called and this is what is passed in baseSchemaLocationURI = MSet/top.mxsd nameSpaceURI = null schemaLocationURI = external.xsd then baseSchemaLocationURI is set the baseSchemaLocationURI but without the file name in it = MSet Then this method returns baseSchemaLocationURI + "/" + schemaLocationPath, which is "MSet/external.xsd" org.eclipse.xsd way /** * Resolve the namespace and schema location relative to the base schema location. * For example, the expression *
    *  resolveSchemaLocation    *    ("http://www.example.com/A/a.xsd",     *     "http://www.example.com/B",     *     "../B/b.xsd");    *
* would yield *
    *  "http://www.example.com/B/b.xsd"    *
* When no namespace schema location is provided, the namespace itself will be used. * @param baseSchemaLocationURI the location of the schema containing the reference, i.e., {@link org.eclipse.xsd.XSDSchema#getSchemaLocation}. * @param namespaceURI the namespace being resolved, i.e., {@link org.eclipse.xsd.XSDImport#getNamespace}. * @param schemaLocationURI the suggested location of the namespace being resolved, i.e., {@link org.eclipse.xsd.XSDImport#getSchemaLocation}. * @return the resolved schema location. */ public static String resolveSchemaLocation(String baseSchemaLocationURI, String namespaceURI, String schemaLocationURI) { try { if (schemaLocationURI == null) { schemaLocationURI = namespaceURI; } if (schemaLocationURI != null) { URI baseSchemaLocation = URI.createURI(baseSchemaLocationURI); URI schemaLocation = URI.createURI(schemaLocationURI); if (baseSchemaLocation.isHierarchical() && ! baseSchemaLocation.isRelative() && schemaLocation.isRelative()) { schemaLocation = schemaLocation.resolve(baseSchemaLocation); } return schemaLocation.toString(); } } catch (Exception exception) { exception.printStackTrace(); } return schemaLocationURI; } When I load top.xsd the XSDConstants.resolveSchemaLocation() gets called and this is what is passed in baseSchemaLocationURI = MSet/top.mxsd nameSpaceURI = null schemaLocationURI = external.xsd This method returns schemaLocation.toString() , which is "external.xsd" because it does not get into the if (baseSchemaLocation.isHierarchical() && ! baseSchemaLocation.isRelative() && schemaLocation.isRelative()) statement. Now when it tries to load external.xsd it can't find it. It needs to be MSet/external.xsd. This is a blocker for us because we break migration if this is not fixed. Lets do the solution we talked about.
my_mothod:

description: Composing workbench parts, including editors, should be easier.  MultiPage  editor is one way to combine editors, but it's really hard to use the class.  The "part pattern" is really useful and could be leveraged more often.  To do  this, JFace could be enhanced to support more than just the single level of  parts it currently supports.  Instead of: + root (the Page)    |=outline    |=navigator    |=editorpart   you could have: + root    |=outline    |=navigator    + editor       |= source editing part       |= visual editing part  The editor becomes a part container similar to PartSashContainer.  When the  focused pane in the editor switches, the editor would indicate this to the  page, and eveyone would be notified that the active part (or more appropriately  a "part path") has changed.  This means views like the outline would flip to  the IOutlinePage corresponding to the source or visual part automatically.   Similarly, keybinding contexts would change, global action handlers would  change, and tons of other things which are currently a nightmare for such  editors.  Not recognizing deeper levels of composition of parts in JFace means that  clients have to re-implement things like outline page-flipping within their own  top-level outline page.  It also means that the part pattern is not reused when  it could be.
my_mothod: Composing workbench parts, including editors, should be easier.  MultiPage  editor is one way to combine editors, but it's really hard to use the class.  The "part pattern" is really useful and could be leveraged more often.  To do  this, JFace could be enhanced to support more than just the single level of  parts it currently supports.  Instead of: + root (the Page)    |=outline    |=navigator    |=editorpart   you could have: + root    |=outline    |=navigator    + editor       |= source editing part       |= visual editing part  The editor becomes a part container similar to PartSashContainer.  When the  focused pane in the editor switches, the editor would indicate this to the  page, and eveyone would be notified that the active part (or more appropriately  a "part path") has changed.  This means views like the outline would flip to  the IOutlinePage corresponding to the source or visual part automatically.   Similarly, keybinding contexts would change, global action handlers would  change, and tons of other things which are currently a nightmare for such  editors.  Not recognizing deeper levels of composition of parts in JFace means that  clients have to re-implement things like outline page-flipping within their own  top-level outline page.  It also means that the part pattern is not reused when  it could be. [Workbench] [Services] Combine, compose, nest workbenchparts and editorparts enhancement UI Platform

description: I just downloaded I20031105 and installed it into a clean directory as a  replacement for I20030917. I run on a dual 933Mhz processor under Sun Java  1.4.2_02 with 1GB of physical memory. I access my workspace via -data.  I brought up Eclipse and after 10 min. of editing I had the file  ICliCommand.java in the state that I attach to ths report. At this point,  starting with the cursor at the end of line 128, I typed the following three  lines.  <newline>     void changeTokenOwner(String oldUser, String newUser)         throw CliCommandException;  I then tried to add a Javadoc comment by positioning the cursor in the method  name and right clicking. I used Source->Javadoc to generate the comment.  Instead of inserting the comment immediately above the new method declaration,  it inserted it at colum 22 of line 128, immediately following the partial  string "DOWN" in the variable declaration "DOWNLOADABLE".  Without doing anything else, I decided to see if I could produce a smaller  test case. First I used the undo command to remove the generated Javadoc  command which worked successfully. I then used the Create Interface wizard  which I accessed from the toolbar to create a new interface called  TestInterface. This was created in the same package as ICliCommand.java and  resulted in the file TestInterface.java which is also attached to this bug  report.  I next used copy and paste to copy lines 109-131 which included the new method  declaration changeTokenOwner into the file TestInterface.java. This succeeded.  My next step was to try and generate a Javadoc comment for the method  declaration for changeTokenOwner in TestInterface.java using the popup menu.  Instead of generating a method Javadoc comment and placing it immediately  ahead of the metod declaration for changeTokenOwner, it generated a  class/interface Javadoc comment and placed it at line 9 of TestInterface.java  immediately ahead of the existing Javadoc comment.  I then decided to check the Eclipse log so I directed Eclipse to shutdown.  Eclipse asked me if I wanted to save the two dirty files ICliCommand.java and  TestInterface.java and I said yes.  Once Eclipse closed (apparently normally) I fould that there was no .log file  at all in the .metadata. I had deleted the previous one so that I could start  with a new file using the new build.  I now restarted Eclipse and I found the following. The 3 lines I had typed in  entering the method declaration for changeTokenOwner had been lost in the file  ICliCommand.java. In the file TestInterface.java all the lines entered via  copy/paste were missing as well as the generated Javadoc comment.  I was able to reproduce this scenario three times in a row with the only  variable being the exact place where the generated Javadoc comment in  ICliCommand.java was mis-placed.

description: The StackFrame is being asked for the local variables even when the Variables  view is not visible.  This happens if the variables view has been visible at sometime during the  workbench session.   The fact that the Variables view has been visible causes  it to service selection events even if it is subsequently hidden.   The  selection event handling causes the view to make a request to get the locals.  It is critical that this be fixed because some platforms have 10000+ locals  and the debugger locks up (takes a long time <minutes> to return) at startup  and on stepping if a request is made to get these variables.   We have been  telling 390 customers that they can avoid the delay by making sure that the  Variables view is not visible.   This bug means that even if the user clicks  on another debug view to make the Variables view hidden the stackframe will  still be asked for local variables.
my_mothod: The StackFrame is being asked for the local variables even when the Variables  view is not visible. It is critical that this be fixed because some platforms have 10000+ locals  and the debugger locks up (takes a long time <minutes> to return) at startup  and on stepping if a request is made to get these variables.   We have been  telling 390 customers that they can avoid the delay by making sure that the  Variables view is not visible.   This bug means that even if the user clicks  on another debug view to make the Variables view hidden the stackframe will  still be asked for local variables. IStackFrame.getVariable() requests when Variables view is not visible blocker Debug Platform

description: I've been working with E3.0-M5 for the past three days and I have experienced a lot of errors when using CVS.  With my previous version, E2.1.0, I had no such problems.      For example, when attempting to do a Override and Update on a folder several times I received this error:  An internal error occurred during: "Performing CVS operation on <XX> resources.". Reason:  An internal error occurred during: "Performing CVS operation on <XX> resources.".    I have attempted to update some of my apache jakarta projects and have received errors like:  Problem creating folder: /jakarta-jetspeed/src/java/org/apache/jetspeed/om/dbpsml/map.  A resource already exists on disk /home/greno/projects/workspace/jakarta-jetspeed/src/java/org/apache/jetspeed/om/dbpsml/map.    I have attempted to repeat the update attempt and everytime I get an error such as above except for a different directory.  I still haven't managed to get a good update run.  Again everything worked fine under E2.1.0.      Again, multiple times while attempting to synchronize some of my projects with the CVS repository I get this error:  An error occured while synchronizing with remote contents.   An error occurred refreshing {0}: {1}/jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war.jsupgradeThe server reported an error while performing the "cvs status" command.     For me, CVS is critical.  I haven't noticed anything else with M5 but then again, I've been spending most of my time dealing with these CVS issues.  Gerry Reno

description: M5.  I created an editor plug-in in Eclipse 2.1.2 using the PDE new project  support.  This simple xml editor does not work in Eclipse 3.0 (class not found  org.eclipse.jface.text.source.SourceViewerConfiguration).  The problem is in InternalPlatform.fixRequiredPlugins().  The newUIPluginIds list refers to "org.eclipse.ui.jface.text".  This is  erroneous and should be "org.eclipse.jface.text".  Once I made this change and  discarded my metadata, the 2.1.2 plug-in worked!
my_mothod: M5.  I created an editor plug-in in Eclipse 2.1.2 using the PDE new project  support.  This simple xml editor does not work in Eclipse 3.0 (class not found  org.eclipse.jface.text.source.SourceViewerConfiguration).  The problem is in InternalPlatform.fixRequiredPlugins().  The newUIPluginIds list refers to "org.eclipse.ui.jface.text".  This is  erroneous and should be "org.eclipse.jface.text".  Once I made this change and  discarded my metadata, the 2.1.2 plug-in worked! 3.0 Compatability support misses jface.text critical Update  (deprecated - use Eclipse>Equinox>p2) Platform

description: 1. open a read-only java class 2. attempt to use auto-complete (Ctrl+Space) somewhere in the file (nothing  happens) 3. change read-only attribute of file using the package explorer 4. attempt to use auto-complete (Ctrl+Space) - result nothing happens  if you skip step 2 then everything works fine! If you close and open the file again then everything works fine
my_mothod: 1. open a read-only java class 2. attempt to use auto-complete (Ctrl+Space) somewhere in the file (nothing  happens) 3. change read-only attribute of file using the package explorer 4. attempt to use auto-complete (Ctrl+Space) - result nothing happens  if you skip step 2 then everything works fine! If you close and open the file again then everything works fine [misc] autocomplete disabled when changing read-only status critical Text JDT

description: Problem -------  A simple spelling mistake where 'launching' is mispelled as 'lunching' in a  Help Error Dialog box.   Procedure ---------  1. Ensure a browser is NOT configured for the workbench.  i.e. Ensure mozilla  or netscape is not in the path indicated under Windows->Preferences and its  Help preferences.  2. Lauch help via main menu.  (Help -> Help Contents)  Expected Results ---------------- Help Error with a description that spells the word, launching, correctly.   Observed Results ---------------- Dialog appears with text as follows...  "An exception occured while lunching help. Refer to the log for more details."
my_mothod: Problem -------  A simple spelling mistake where 'launching' is mispelled as 'lunching' in a  Help Error Dialog box.   Procedure ---------  1. Ensure a browser is NOT configured for the workbench.  i.e. Ensure mozilla  or netscape is not in the path indicated under Windows->Preferences and its  Help preferences.  2. Lauch help via main menu.  (Help -> Help Contents)  Expected Results ---------------- Help Error with a description that spells the word, launching, correctly.
