description: org.eclipse.emf.mapping version 1.1.1  In MappingRootImpl.java setDomain method, it creates a listener for the mapping root to listen model changes.  But it uses the notify method that is no longer in use.   The signature of the notifyChanged method should be changed to  public void notifyChanged(Notification notifier)   i.e. from   mappedObjectListener =          new AdapterImpl()         {           public void notifyChanged(Notifier notifier, int eventType, EObject  feature, Object oldValue, Object newValue, int index)           {             if (feature == MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Inputs() ||  feature == MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Outputs())             {               initializeMappedObjectStates();             }           }         };  to  mappedObjectListener =          new AdapterImpl()         {           public void notifyChanged(Notification notification)           {             if (notification.getFeature()==  MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Inputs() || notification.getFeature()==  MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Outputs())             {               initializeMappedObjectStates();             }           }         };
my_mothod: org.eclipse.emf.mapping version 1.1.1  In MappingRootImpl.java setDomain method, it creates a listener for the mapping root to listen model changes.  But it uses the notify method that is no longer in use.   The signature of the notifyChanged method should be changed to  public void notifyChanged(Notification notifier)   i.e. from   mappedObjectListener =          new AdapterImpl()         {           public void notifyChanged(Notifier notifier, int eventType, EObject  feature, Object oldValue, Object newValue, int index)           {             if (feature == MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Inputs() ||  feature == MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Outputs())             {               initializeMappedObjectStates();             }           }         };  to  mappedObjectListener =          new AdapterImpl()         {           public void notifyChanged(Notification notification)           {             if (notification.getFeature()==  MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Inputs() || notification.getFeature()==  MappingPackage.eINSTANCE.getMapping_Outputs())             {               initializeMappedObjectStates();             }           }         }; notifyChanged method in MappingRootImpl never get called critical Core EMF

description: I am including a sample set of classes that demonstrate the error.  Compiling  these classes on the commandline with Sun's compiler and running Main works (I  have used 1.3, 1.4.1_01, and 1.4.2_02, all on Win2000 and WinXP).  Compiling these classes in Eclipse 3.0M5 and running Main inside the  environment or on the commandline throws an ExceptionInInitializerError because  ClassOne doesn't exist yet.  Please let me know if you need more information.  ****** ClassOne.java ****** public class ClassOne {     static {         StaticCollection.COLLECTION.add(ClassOne.class);     } }  ****** ClassTwo.java ****** public class ClassTwo {     static {         if (!StaticCollection.COLLECTION.contains(ClassOne.class)) {             throw new RuntimeException("ClassOne doesn't exist");         }     } }  ****** StaticCollection.java ****** import java.util.ArrayList; import java.util.Collection;  public class StaticCollection {     public final static Collection COLLECTION = new ArrayList(); }  ****** Main.java ****** public class Main {     public static void main(String[] args) {         System.out.println(new ClassTwo());         System.exit(0);     } }

description: Eclipse 3.0 M5 Build 12/5/2003  This is a hard one to explain, so I will just detail the steps taken to  reproduce it:  1) Have an ANT build script in a project (I have a Java Project). 2) Create an ANT configuration (should be the first one for that script) by  right clicking on the ANT script and hitting "Run Ant". 3) Leave the name of the configuration set to whatever it defaults to. 4) Hit the "Targets" tab and select an ANT target to execute. 5) Hit "Run" to dismiss the dialog and execute the task. NOTE: At this point mousing over the "External tools" button on the toolbar  (the button with the running man and the toolbox behind him) should result in  showing tooltip text with the name of the ANT configuration you just executed  (as expected). 6) Press the "arrow down" part of this toolbar button, and hit "External tools"  (bringing up the "External tools" dialog). 7) Select the ANT configuration you previously executed. 8) Change the name of the configuration to something else. 9) Hit "Close" on the dialog. 10) When prompted to save the configuration hit "Yes". 11) Now mouse over the "External tools" button in the toolbar again, and notice  that the tooltip text has not been updated to reflect the new name given to the  last executed ANT configuration.  I expected the tooltip text to be up to date with the name change of the  configuration.
my_mothod: Eclipse 3.0 M5 Build 12/5/2003  This is a hard one to explain, so I will just detail the steps taken to  reproduce it:  1) Have an ANT build script in a project (I have a Java Project). 2) Create an ANT configuration (should be the first one for that script) by  right clicking on the ANT script and hitting "Run Ant". 3) Leave the name of the configuration set to whatever it defaults to. 4) Hit the "Targets" tab and select an ANT target to execute. 5) Hit "Run" to dismiss the dialog and execute the task. NOTE: At this point mousing over the "External tools" button on the toolbar  (the button with the running man and the toolbox behind him) should result in  showing tooltip text with the name of the ANT configuration you just executed  (as expected). 6) Press the "arrow down" part of this toolbar button, and hit "External tools"  (bringing up the "External tools" dialog). 7) Select the ANT configuration you previously executed. 8) Change the name of the configuration to something else. 9) Hit "Close" on the dialog. 10) When prompted to save the configuration hit "Yes". 11) Now mouse over the "External tools" button in the toolbar again, and notice  that the tooltip text has not been updated to reflect the new name given to the  last executed ANT configuration.  I expected the tooltip text to be up to date with the name change of the  configuration. Tooltip text for "External Tools" toolbar button not updated. trivial Debug Platform

description: Field definitions like 'private int a, b;' are not pulled up correctly.  To reproduce, you need two classes: =================================== 'Superclass.java':   public class Superclass {   }  'Subclass.java':   public class Subclass extends Superclass {     private int a, b;          public int getA() {         return a;     }          public int getB() {         return b;     }    }  Now 'Refactor - Pull up...' and select the field 'a' and the method 'getA()' and 'Finish'.  Result: ======= The field 'b' is missing from Subclass.java resulting in a compilation error.  Expected result: ================   private int a, b;  has to be changed to    private int b;  Remark ====== If you try to pull up only the field, you get an error message saying that pulling up multi-declaration fields is not supported. Indeed, but it should also appear when selecting multi-declaration fields while pulling up something else.
my_mothod: Field definitions like 'private int a, b;' are not pulled up correctly.  To reproduce, you need two classes: =================================== 'Superclass.java':   public class Superclass {   }  'Subclass.java':   public class Subclass extends Superclass {     private int a, b;          public int getA() {         return a;     }          public int getB() {         return b;     }    }  Now 'Refactor - Pull up...' and select the field 'a' and the method 'getA()' and 'Finish'.  Result: ======= The field 'b' is missing from Subclass.java resulting in a compilation error.  Expected result: ================   private int a, b;  has to be changed to    private int b;  Remark ====== If you try to pull up only the field, you get an error message saying that pulling up multi-declaration fields is not supported. Indeed, but it should also appear when selecting multi-declaration fields while pulling up something else. Loss of multi-declaration fields when pulling up method [refactoring] critical UI JDT

description: This is a usability/adoptability bug.  Test case: Try to open a HTML, BAT, XML file in the editor (from the C/C++ Projects  window)  --------------  It is not uncommon for users to have .html files, batch files, .xml files,  perl scripts, etc. in their project directories. Though unlike source files,  (which can be opened in the editor by double clicking them in the C/C++  Projects window), these files "execute" when double clicked.  (.html opens in  IE, batch, perl files execute, etc.) The only way to get them opened in the  editor is to select and drag the file from the C/C++ Projects window into the  editor window.  As a user, this overloading of the double-click operation in the C/C++  Projects window is non-intuitive, inconsistent, and different from other C++  IDEs :)
my_mothod: This is a usability/adoptability bug.  Test case: Try to open a HTML, BAT, XML file in the editor (from the C/C++ Projects  window)  --------------  It is not uncommon for users to have .html files, batch files, .xml files,  perl scripts, etc. in their project directories. Though unlike source files,  (which can be opened in the editor by double clicking them in the C/C++  Projects window), these files "execute" when double clicked.  (.html opens in  IE, batch, perl files execute, etc.) The only way to get them opened in the  editor is to select and drag the file from the C/C++ Projects window into the  editor window.  As a user, this overloading of the double-click operation in the C/C++  Projects window is non-intuitive, inconsistent, and different from other C++  IDEs :) Usability::Cannot 'easily' open .xml, .html, .bat, .pl  files in CDT editor minor cdt-core CDT

description: Unlike JDT, CDT does not offer a convenient method of adding new folders and  files to a specific project location.  Example:  Consider a project with the following directory structure:  Project_Foo | |__Dir_Bar1    |    |__Dir_Bar2       |       |__Dir_Bar3   If this was a JDT project, the user could easily add a file/folder to  directory Dir_Bar3 by right-clicking on the directory name in the Package  Explorer window and selecting New->Folder (or New->File).  The new file/folder  dialog will open and the parent folder for the new file/folder will be pre- populated on the basis of where the user right-clicked.  In CDT, right-clicking on Dir_Bar3 and selecting New->Folder (or New->File)  opens the new file/folder dialog, but the user is then required to navigate  and re-select the parent folder.  This task becomes increasingly tedious and  inefficient as the project directory structure becomes more complex and the  number of projects in the workspace increases.
my_mothod: Unlike JDT, CDT does not offer a convenient method of adding new folders and  files to a specific project location.  Example:  Consider a project with the following directory structure:  Project_Foo | |__Dir_Bar1    |    |__Dir_Bar2       |       |__Dir_Bar3   If this was a JDT project, the user could easily add a file/folder to  directory Dir_Bar3 by right-clicking on the directory name in the Package  Explorer window and selecting New->Folder (or New->File).  The new file/folder  dialog will open and the parent folder for the new file/folder will be pre- populated on the basis of where the user right-clicked.  In CDT, right-clicking on Dir_Bar3 and selecting New->Folder (or New->File)  opens the new file/folder dialog, but the user is then required to navigate  and re-select the parent folder.  This task becomes increasingly tedious and  inefficient as the project directory structure becomes more complex and the  number of projects in the workspace increases. Usability::Adding new files and folders to a specific project location is a chore minor cdt-core CDT

description: build I20031211  When looking at a stack trace, I often want to go to the type and line number  mentioned for a stack frame. Stack traces are typically of the form:  at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.Assert.isLegal(Assert.java:56) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.Assert.isLegal(Assert.java:41) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Status.setMessage(Status.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Status.<init>(Status.java:75) at org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextFileDocumentProvider.executeOperation (TextFileDocumentProvider.java:396) at org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextFileDocumentProvider.validateState (TextFileDocumentProvider.java:812) at org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.AbstractTextEditor.validateState (AbstractTextEditor.java:3035)  It would be nice if I could do: - select a file name and line number, e.g. TextFileDocumentProvider.java:396 - Ctrl+C to copy it - Ctrl+Shift+T to open type - Ctrl+V to paste the file name and line number - Enter to accept  I would expect it to open TextFileDocumentProvider and go to line 396. Currently this requires several steps.  I'll leave this as a JDT feature request for now, since the scenario is Java- specific.  However, I could also imagine adding this support to the Open  Resource dialog since I could imagine that the <fileName>:<lineNumber> format  is not necessarily Java-specific.

description: IWorkbenchActionConstants has M_VIEW but not M_PERSPECTIVE. The M_VIEW comment references the Perspective menu. Also it has M_WORKBENCH which I don't think is used any more. /** * Name of standard Perspective menu (value "view"). */ public static final String M_VIEW = MENU_PREFIX+"view"; //$NON-NLS-1$ /** * Name of standard Workbench menu (value "workbench"). */ public static final String M_WORKBENCH = MENU_PREFIX+"workbench"; // $NON-NLS-1$

description: Breakpoints on exceptions can be filtered on a package basis. This can be done by the properties and going to "filtering".  When a very long filter is being specified the properties page is maximized to  the size of the window and the list widget is not totally visible. To reproduce:  - create a breakpoint on an exception - add all the eclipse package in the filter - close - reopen the filter property page
my_mothod: Breakpoints on exceptions can be filtered on a package basis. This can be done by the properties and going to "filtering".  When a very long filter is being specified the properties page is maximized to  the size of the window and the list widget is not totally visible. To reproduce:  - create a breakpoint on an exception - add all the eclipse package in the filter - close - reopen the filter property page Package filter list not properly displayed when too many items minor Debug JDT

description: This bug affects 1.1.1 but is fixed in CVS HEAD.   The 1.1.1 compiler complains about:  import java.util.logging.Logger;  public aspect InnerShadow {     private Logger Loggable.logger; }  interface Loggable {}  class Foo implements Loggable {     private Logger logger;// = LoggerFactory.getLoggerger("Foo");      class Bar implements Loggable { 	public void baz() { 	    logger.info("test"); 	}     } }          C:\devel\test\scope>ajc InnerShadow.aj C:\devel\test\scope\InnerShadow.aj:14 The field logger is defined in an  inherited type and an enclosing scope logger.info("test"); ^^^^^^  1 error
my_mothod: This bug affects 1.1.1 but is fixed in CVS HEAD.   The 1.1.1 compiler complains about:  import java.util.logging.Logger;  public aspect InnerShadow {     private Logger Loggable.logger; }  interface Loggable {}  class Foo implements Loggable {     private Logger logger;// = LoggerFactory.getLoggerger("Foo");      class Bar implements Loggable { 	public void baz() { 	    logger.info("test"); 	}     } }          C:\devel\test\scope>ajc InnerShadow.aj C:\devel\test\scope\InnerShadow.aj:14 The field logger is defined in an  inherited type and an enclosing scope logger.info("test"); ^^^^^^  1 error ITD in inner class shadowing (already fixed in HEAD) major Compiler AspectJ

description: I extracted a long method from a long code sequence in a finally block. The extracted seems to be correct and will be called  at its original place, but after the method call  a return statement was inserted. In my case the return statement did not cause a logical error, but it is superflous and I do not want to have it.  best regards  Thorsten van Ellen
my_mothod: I extracted a long method from a long code sequence in a finally block. The extracted seems to be correct and will be called  at its original place, but after the method call  a return statement was inserted. In my case the return statement did not cause a logical error, but it is superflous and I do not want to have it.  best regards  Thorsten van Ellen [extract method] superfluous return statement normal UI JDT

description: 3.0 M6  While using the Plugin Registry view, i noticed that some extension points  showed up with non-localized names.  Perhaps missing resource translations  should be logged to the platform log, as it indicates the programmer has  forgotten to translate something.  I got htis list by logging MREs in the  BundelModel class.  Here is a list of all the missing resource keys (and their plugin) that i could  find: org.eclipse.core.variables	%valueVariablesExtensionPointName org.eclipse.core.variables	%dynamicVariablesExtensionPointName  org.eclipse.debug.core	%logicalStructureTypesExtensionPointName  org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui	%vmInstallTypePage  org.eclipse.jdt.ui	%deleteProcessorExtensionPoint  org.eclipse.team.ui	%ActionSet.description  org.eclipse.ui	%ExtPoint.actionSetPartAssociations org.eclipse.ui	%ExtPoint.elementFactories  org.eclipse.ui.editors	%ExtPoint.documentProviders org.eclipse.ui.editors	%ExtPoint.markerUpdaters  org.eclipse.ui.workbench.texteditor	%category.textEditor.description

Here is a list of all the missing resource keys (and their plugin) that i could  find: org.eclipse.core.variables	%valueVariablesExtensionPointName org.eclipse.core.variables	%dynamicVariablesExtensionPointName  org.eclipse.debug.core	%logicalStructureTypesExtensionPointName  org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui	%vmInstallTypePage  org.eclipse.jdt.ui	%deleteProcessorExtensionPoint  org.eclipse.team.ui	%ActionSet.description  org.eclipse.ui	%ExtPoint.actionSetPartAssociations org.eclipse.ui	%ExtPoint.elementFactories  org.eclipse.ui.editors	%ExtPoint.documentProviders org.eclipse.ui.editors	%ExtPoint.markerUpdaters  org.eclipse.ui.workbench.texteditor	%category.textEditor.description Missing localizations for extension point names trivial UI Platform

description: Using the new release of EMF 2.0, we were unable to correctly generate the model code for OMG's Common Warehouse Metamodel (CWM) Rational Rose Model. This model is located at http://www.omg.org/cgi-bin/doc?ad/02-05-04.  One of the more important relationships in the model is that between a namespace and an ownedElement. A namespace contains a set of 1-many owned elements of type ModelElement and all derived elements will behave in the same fashion. These relationships are defined in the ObjectCore metamodel of the CWM.  EMF 1.X correctly generated these relationships for this same model while EMF 2.X creates a 1-1 relationship between the namespace and the ownedElement.  I am unsure if any other relationships have been incorrectly generated, but the namespace-ownedElement relationship is probably the most important in the CWM. The fix right now is to revert to EMF 1.X and Eclipse 2.X but would like to be able to use both the new features of Eclipse and the new features of EMF 2.0  To summarize:  EMF 2.X generates an incorrect set of model code for the above Rational Rose model while EMF 1.X generated the code correctly.  Thanks for taking a look!  Ray Harrison
my_mothod: Using the new release of EMF 2.0, we were unable to correctly generate the model code for OMG's Common Warehouse Metamodel (CWM) Rational Rose Model. This model is located at http://www.omg.org/cgi-bin/doc?ad/02-05-04.  One of the more important relationships in the model is that between a namespace and an ownedElement. A namespace contains a set of 1-many owned elements of type ModelElement and all derived elements will behave in the same fashion. These relationships are defined in the ObjectCore metamodel of the CWM.  EMF 1.X correctly generated these relationships for this same model while EMF 2.X creates a 1-1 relationship between the namespace and the ownedElement.  I am unsure if any other relationships have been incorrectly generated, but the namespace-ownedElement relationship is probably the most important in the CWM. The fix right now is to revert to EMF 1.X and Eclipse 2.X but would like to be able to use both the new features of Eclipse and the new features of EMF 2.0  To summarize:  EMF 2.X generates an incorrect set of model code for the above Rational Rose model while EMF 1.X generated the code correctly.  Thanks for taking a look!  Ray Harrison EMF 2.0 doesn't create correct relationships with Rose models critical Core EMF

description: I20040120  I am not 100% sure whether this is really caused by this new sticky hover in the lower left corner but since I first got this in perspective A (Debug perspective) it now always switches to perspective A whenever in another perspective a job is run and this sticky hover must be shown.  This is very distracting since this now happens on every save (with auto-build on) and there's no way to disable that sticky hover. This makes the build unusable for me.
my_mothod: I20040120  I am not 100% sure whether this is really caused by this new sticky hover in the lower left corner but since I first got this in perspective A (Debug perspective) it now always switches to perspective A whenever in another perspective a job is run and this sticky hover must be shown.  This is very distracting since this now happens on every save (with auto-build on) and there's no way to disable that sticky hover. This makes the build unusable for me. [Jobs] New sticky (job?) hover forces perspective change critical UI Platform

description: Not sure if this is core, but I will contact the IBM jre folks too.  I'm using Eclipse M6, stable build 1218, and IBM J2RE 1.4.1 windows 32 build  cn1411-20030930 (JIT enabled: jitc)).  When I'm switching perspectives it Eclipse hangs and I have to kill the IDE  with the task manager. This does not happen using the Sun jre, nor Eclipse M5.   The simple steps to reproduce are: 1. Start Eclipse,  2. Open java perspective, 3. switch to resource and back to java perspective several times (between 4 and  7 times). Eclipse hangs.   Reproducible on 3 W2K machines. Switching, opening, closing perspectives all do  the trick too. It seems to be the lower number of switches if there are  projects in the workspace.

description: I'm creating an RCP (Rich Client Platform) application.  I want to be able to view the error log view (for serviceability and while debugging).  However I notice the   error log's id is in the pde.runtime package.  I do not wish to include the PDE in my runtime.  Can the error log be moved to the platform level?

description: Edit a text. Hit ctrl-f. Search for "import". Hit enter. Text is found. Give focus to editor. Hit ctrl-f again. Enter "java" (without looking). All occurences of "import" are replaced with empty string.  Focus is given to "Find:" text box shortly (it flashes), but then transfers to the "Find" button.   This is quite annoying. When used blindly, lots of text can be replaced all  over the input file. Combined with a broken ctrl-z history (unrelated bug) this  makes it hard to recover sometimes.  This has been broken for at least since Jan 15 build (when I first spotted it). Jan. 29 build has same problem.
my_mothod: Edit a text. Hit ctrl-f. Search for "import". Hit enter. Text is found. Give focus to editor. Hit ctrl-f again. Enter "java" (without looking). All occurences of "import" are replaced with empty string.  Focus is given to "Find:" text box shortly (it flashes), but then transfers to the "Find" button.   This is quite annoying. When used blindly, lots of text can be replaced all  over the input file. Combined with a broken ctrl-z history (unrelated bug) this  makes it hard to recover sometimes.  This has been broken for at least since Jan 15 build (when I first spotted it). Jan. 29 build has same problem. [find/replace] Text Editor search focus problem critical Text Platform

description: Many classes have constants defined as public static final or protected  staticd final with name in all caps. You don't really need getter and setter  (since it is final) for the constants. They should not be displayed by default  when you go to Generate getter and setter dialog since they are taking real  esteate and make it difficult to find real class attributes.
my_mothod: Many classes have constants defined as public static final or protected  staticd final with name in all caps. You don't really need getter and setter  (since it is final) for the constants. They should not be displayed by default  when you go to Generate getter and setter dialog since they are taking real  esteate and make it difficult to find real class attributes. [content assist] should filter setters for final fields normal Text JDT

description: Open a few editors;  Make them all dirty.  Open Switch to Editor dialog.  Select several editors.  Click on "Close Selected Editors"  You now have to confirm every save individually.  There should be a way to "Save All".
my_mothod: Open a few editors;  Make them all dirty.  Open Switch to Editor dialog.  Select several editors.  Click on "Close Selected Editors"  You now have to confirm every save individually.  There should be a way to "Save All". [EditorMgmt] 'Switch to Editor' dialog prompts for each dirty editor individually instead of batching them minor UI Platform

description: See bug # https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=50448  The <?eclipse version="3.0"?> line without having "runtime compatibility" as a required plugin can cause your GEFPlugin class to try to be instantiated with default ctor, which you don't have. This causes stack traces and the GEFPlugin will not be initialized.  As you can see from the bug referenced above, unless you are going to be a full-blown OSGi bundle, it is best to simply remove the version=3.0 line.  The way this occurred for me was I was accessing a class in my plugin that inherited from a GEF class. Upon the load of the GEF class it tried to start the GEFPlugin up as an OSGi bundle in new mode, and not in old mode. And it threw an exception.
my_mothod: See bug # https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=50448  The <?eclipse version="3.0"?> line without having "runtime compatibility" as a required plugin can cause your GEFPlugin class to try to be instantiated with default ctor, which you don't have. This causes stack traces and the GEFPlugin will not be initialized.  As you can see from the bug referenced above, unless you are going to be a full-blown OSGi bundle, it is best to simply remove the version=3.0 line.  The way this occurred for me was I was accessing a class in my plugin that inherited from a GEF class. Upon the load of the GEF class it tried to start the GEFPlugin up as an OSGi bundle in new mode, and not in old mode. And it threw an exception. Remove 3.0 specification from plugin.xmls blocker GEF-Legacy GEF (MVC) GEF

description: Eclipse Platform  Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200402102000  The progress floating window is not positioned correctly. It is located higher  than its desired position (which is for the progress' top left corner to be at  the top right corner of the "cigarette").  Steps: 1- Open the CVS Repository Exploring. 2- Check out a project, and the progress floating window appears.
my_mothod: Eclipse Platform  Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200402102000  The progress floating window is not positioned correctly. It is located higher  than its desired position (which is for the progress' top left corner to be at  the top right corner of the "cigarette").  Steps: 1- Open the CVS Repository Exploring. 2- Check out a project, and the progress floating window appears. The progress floating window is not located at the top right corner of the progress "cigarette" minor UI Platform

description: 20040211  In the following code in the 'see' tag, the SimpleName 'java' (part of the qualified name 'java.util.Vector') has a ITypeBinding to 'java.util.Vector'. Should only have a package binding.  package pack;  import java.util.Vector;  /**  * @see java.util.Vector  */ public interface IOpenable { 		 }  This bug is the cause for bug 51497. I'd be happy if you could fix this for M7 otherwise Orgamize import adds lots of unneeded imports.
my_mothod: 20040211  In the following code in the 'see' tag, the SimpleName 'java' (part of the qualified name 'java.util.Vector') has a ITypeBinding to 'java.util.Vector'. Should only have a package binding.  package pack;  import java.util.Vector;  /**  * @see java.util.Vector  */ public interface IOpenable { 		 }  This bug is the cause for bug 51497. I'd be happy if you could fix this for M7 otherwise Orgamize import adds lots of unneeded imports. Javadoc AST Node: wrong binding on qualified name part critical Core JDT

description: Eclipse 3.0M6 CDT Build 2.0.0.0031 Sun JDK 1.4.2_02  Test case: 1. Create a managed make C++ project, call it MgdParserTest (for example) 2. Add a file, call it main.cpp. 3. Insert the following code into main.cpp: 	class CFoo { 	  public: 		CFoo() {}; 		void CFoo::barroo() { return; } // ** (A) ** 	}; 	 	int 	main(int argc, char **argv) { 		CFoo *foo = new CFoo(); 		foo->[^SPC] // ** (B) ** 	} 4. Execute Content Assist on line (B) using "foo->" as your prefix.  Result: "CFoo::barroo()" is inserted.  Expected: Only "barroo()" should be inserted as "foo->CFoo::barroo();" will generate a compile error.  ** Search does not identify line (A) as a reference to class CFoo.
my_mothod: Eclipse 3.0M6 CDT Build 2.0.0.0031 Sun JDK 1.4.2_02  Test case: 1. Create a managed make C++ project, call it MgdParserTest (for example) 2. Add a file, call it main.cpp. 3. Insert the following code into main.cpp: 	class CFoo { 	  public: 		CFoo() {}; 		void CFoo::barroo() { return; } // ** (A) ** 	}; 	 	int 	main(int argc, char **argv) { 		CFoo *foo = new CFoo(); 		foo->[^SPC] // ** (B) ** 	} 4. Execute Content Assist on line (B) using "foo->" as your prefix.  Result: "CFoo::barroo()" is inserted.  Expected: Only "barroo()" should be inserted as "foo->CFoo::barroo();" will generate a compile error.  ** Search does not identify line (A) as a reference to class CFoo. [Content Assist] Parser does not strip class qualifier from method name in class declarations minor cdt-parser CDT

description: Enter "command line CVS" in the Help search field. The first hit is labeled "Running the command-line CVS client with Eclipse", whereas the title of the  page it brings up is "Running the CVS command-line client outside of Eclipse". "with Eclipse" and "outside of Eclipse" are rather different things. (Also "CVS" and "command-line" are swapped.)
my_mothod: Enter "command line CVS" in the Help search field. The first hit is labeled "Running the command-line CVS client with Eclipse", whereas the title of the  page it brings up is "Running the CVS command-line client outside of Eclipse". "with Eclipse" and "outside of Eclipse" are rather different things. (Also "CVS" and "command-line" are swapped.) inconsistent titles for help page "Running the CVS command-line client outside of Eclipse" trivial Doc Platform

description: I20040226  On moving to 20040226, I can no longer use my workspace that I was developing  with using I20040219. It happens that my workspace has projects that are using both Jdk 1.4 and Jdk  1.5.  John W and I have been looking at it and there is a ton of SimpleWordSets  allocated and staying in memory (82000ish). As these are being allocated out of  the AddJarFileToIndex.execute class the Out of Memory occurs.  It would appear that the MemoryIndex is not getting totalled cleaned up?  This is in the log: !SESSION Feb 26, 2004 15:12:22.560 --------------------------------------------- java.version=1.4.1-rc java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -data c:\1119 -showlocation !ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 4 Feb 26, 2004 15:12:22.560 !MESSAGE Background Indexer Crash Recovery !STACK 0 java.lang.OutOfMemoryError !ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 4 Feb 26, 2004 15:12:25.504 !MESSAGE Background Indexer Crash Recovery !STACK 0 java.lang.OutOfMemoryError
my_mothod: I20040226  On moving to 20040226, I can no longer use my workspace that I was developing  with using I20040219. It happens that my workspace has projects that are using both Jdk 1.4 and Jdk  1.5.  John W and I have been looking at it and there is a ton of SimpleWordSets  allocated and staying in memory (82000ish). As these are being allocated out of  the AddJarFileToIndex.execute class the Out of Memory occurs.  It would appear that the MemoryIndex is not getting totalled cleaned up?  This is in the log: !SESSION Feb 26, 2004 15:12:22.560 --------------------------------------------- java.version=1.4.1-rc java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -data c:\1119 -showlocation !ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 4 Feb 26, 2004 15:12:22.560 !MESSAGE Background Indexer Crash Recovery !STACK 0 java.lang.OutOfMemoryError !ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 4 Feb 26, 2004 15:12:25.504 !MESSAGE Background Indexer Crash Recovery !STACK 0 java.lang.OutOfMemoryError Consitent Out of Memory problems indexing (with multiple Java libraries) critical Core JDT

description: There are way to many selection change events being sent. Since much of the UI  is based on responding to selection changes any optimizations in this code  path will have a significant benefit.   To recreate:   Start with the "Hello World" example but write something to the console on  every selection change event.   Launch the example and activate the action set.   Start clicking around in the UI and notice:  In several views you get multiple selection change events being processed for  single clicks.   REALLY IMPORTANT: Try extending selection in an editor and notice that you get  tons of events.
my_mothod: There are way to many selection change events being sent. Since much of the UI  is based on responding to selection changes any optimizations in this code  path will have a significant benefit.   To recreate:   Start with the "Hello World" example but write something to the console on  every selection change event.   Launch the example and activate the action set.   Start clicking around in the UI and notice:  In several views you get multiple selection change events being processed for  single clicks.   REALLY IMPORTANT: Try extending selection in an editor and notice that you get  tons of events. [Workbench] Way too many selection change events are being fired major UI Platform

description: Code Formatter: There should be a way to set up the behaviour for every single Javadoc tag.  E.g. "blank line before @return", "no blank line between tags of the same kind  (as between @param and @param)", "blank line between different tags (as  between @param and @return)", etc.
my_mothod: Code Formatter: There should be a way to set up the behaviour for every single Javadoc tag.  E.g. "blank line before @return", "no blank line between tags of the same kind  (as between @param and @param)", "blank line between different tags (as  between @param and @return)", etc. [formatter] Blank lines between Javadoc tags enhancement Core JDT

description: The contextual launch contribution sets adaptable=true (see below). This means the selection is always converted to an IResource. This results in  a loss of information, since then the enablement can only be expressed in  terms of IResource and not in terms of the original type.  For exampe, the JUnit contextual launch needs to support launching an  individual IMethod.  It should be up to the enablement expression to do the adaptation.       <extension          point="org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus">       <objectContribution             objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IResource"             adaptable="true"             id="org.eclipse.debug.ui.contextualLaunch">         <action                label="%LaunchMenu.label"                style="pulldown"                 class="org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.actions.ContextualLaunchObjectActionDelega te"                menubarPath="additions"                enablesFor="1"                id="org.eclipse.debug.ui.contextualLaunch.submenu">          </action>       </objectContribution> 	</extension>
my_mothod: The contextual launch contribution sets adaptable=true (see below). This means the selection is always converted to an IResource. This results in  a loss of information, since then the enablement can only be expressed in  terms of IResource and not in terms of the original type.  For exampe, the JUnit contextual launch needs to support launching an  individual IMethod.  It should be up to the enablement expression to do the adaptation.       <extension          point="org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus">       <objectContribution             objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IResource"             adaptable="true"             id="org.eclipse.debug.ui.contextualLaunch">         <action                label="%LaunchMenu.label"                style="pulldown"                 class="org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.actions.ContextualLaunchObjectActionDelega te"                menubarPath="additions"                enablesFor="1"                id="org.eclipse.debug.ui.contextualLaunch.submenu">          </action>       </objectContribution> 	</extension> Contextual launch contribution should not set adaptable=true normal Debug Platform

description: If you are in code debugging, and you select a variable that has not yet been  defined and inspect you get a nice Inspect popup telling you the "variable"  cannot be resolved.  Displaying the same variable, gets you a nasty little error dialog.  I propose display could be the same as inspect.
my_mothod: If you are in code debugging, and you select a variable that has not yet been  defined and inspect you get a nice Inspect popup telling you the "variable"  cannot be resolved.  Displaying the same variable, gets you a nasty little error dialog.  I propose display could be the same as inspect. Differences between Display and Inspect when var cannot be resolved minor Debug JDT

description: OS:		windows 2003, RHEL 3.0, SLES 9 Beta3.5  Language:	Japanese Build level: 	I20040422-200404231600 JDK version:  IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #:            Steps to recreate problem: 1-on Eclipse Windows2003 (default encoding MS932), check out a project on RHEL  made by Eclipse Linux-gtk (default encoding EUC-JP) 2-change encoding to EUC-JP at the project properties Info page   3-  ....  Error:  come up many errors after/befor changing the encoding of project  Expected Result:  no erros come up.  it seems that the compilation works fine when the EUC-JP project  includes .encoding file that content is :EUC-JP, I find it can be generated by  setting EUC-JP at Other combobox of Project propertiess Info page. I'd like to know whetehr it's an expected behavior.
my_mothod: OS:		windows 2003, RHEL 3.0, SLES 9 Beta3.5  Language:	Japanese Build level: 	I20040422-200404231600 JDK version:  IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #:            Steps to recreate problem: 1-on Eclipse Windows2003 (default encoding MS932), check out a project on RHEL  made by Eclipse Linux-gtk (default encoding EUC-JP) 2-change encoding to EUC-JP at the project properties Info page   3-  ....  Error:  come up many errors after/befor changing the encoding of project  Expected Result:  no erros come up.  it seems that the compilation works fine when the EUC-JP project  includes .encoding file that content is :EUC-JP, I find it can be generated by  setting EUC-JP at Other combobox of Project propertiess Info page. I'd like to know whetehr it's an expected behavior. Encoding changes need to notify clients critical Resources Platform

description: I20040428  new workspace/autobuild off 1. Create a plugin project A 2. Create a plugin project B 3. Go to preferences -> build order. you will see A before B (either order is possible - you must edit B's  plugin.xml if B is before A) 4. Go to A's plugin.xml 5. Add a dependency on B. (make sure you save the file) 6. Go to preferences -> build order you will see A before B (still).  B should now be prior to A.  On build you will get an error on A: The project cannot be built until its  prerequisite B is rebuilt...  This error should not occur; the build order should be B then A.  bug 57181 depends on this one.
my_mothod: I20040428  new workspace/autobuild off 1. Create a plugin project A 2. Create a plugin project B 3. Go to preferences -> build order. you will see A before B (either order is possible - you must edit B's  plugin.xml if B is before A) 4. Go to A's plugin.xml 5. Add a dependency on B. (make sure you save the file) 6. Go to preferences -> build order you will see A before B (still).  B should now be prior to A.  On build you will get an error on A: The project cannot be built until its  prerequisite B is rebuilt...  This error should not occur; the build order should be B then A.  bug 57181 depends on this one. dynamic project references not maintained critical Core JDT

description: Using last integration build I200404281424.  Scenario is still the same than bug 55207, 55289: merge JDK_1_5 branch with  HEAD.  I now use "Copy All non-conflicting changes from right to left" for all files  which are in conflict. When there's no line of code in conflict (the light is  blue on left upper corner...), it's the faster way I found to update changes.  Everything was fine until this last integration build. Unfortunately, this  button is no longer working as when I push on it, all output changes are  destroyed and replaced by HEAD contents!  You have to know that I make this merge every 2 days and the average of  conflicting changes is around 100 files. Sometimes (quite often), some of this  conflict may have more than hundred changes to get from HEAD to 1_5 stream. I  cannot imagine getting them one by one...  If it would possible to have a patch asap it would be really helpful thanks
my_mothod: Using last integration build I200404281424.  Scenario is still the same than bug 55207, 55289: merge JDK_1_5 branch with  HEAD.  I now use "Copy All non-conflicting changes from right to left" for all files  which are in conflict. When there's no line of code in conflict (the light is  blue on left upper corner...), it's the faster way I found to update changes.  Everything was fine until this last integration build. Unfortunately, this  button is no longer working as when I push on it, all output changes are  destroyed and replaced by HEAD contents!  You have to know that I make this merge every 2 days and the average of  conflicting changes is around 100 files. Sometimes (quite often), some of this  conflict may have more than hundred changes to get from HEAD to 1_5 stream. I  cannot imagine getting them one by one...  If it would possible to have a patch asap it would be really helpful thanks Copy All non-conflicting changes from right-to-left erase left-to-right changes!!! major Compare Platform

description: Tested on Redhat ver 3.0, build 27 April IES build  - Create Simple project, Name it with An Arabic name. - Create a simple file, and change the keyboard layout to Arabic and insert  text into the file - Press Ctrl+ S to save the file  - The file is not saved, shorcut keys are not working with Arabic keyboard  NB: Same problem appears with Alt+e that opens the Edit menu
my_mothod: Tested on Redhat ver 3.0, build 27 April IES build  - Create Simple project, Name it with An Arabic name. - Create a simple file, and change the keyboard layout to Arabic and insert  text into the file - Press Ctrl+ S to save the file  - The file is not saved, shorcut keys are not working with Arabic keyboard  NB: Same problem appears with Alt+e that opens the Edit menu [Bidi] Shortcut keys doesn't work with Arabic and other non-English keyboard major SWT Platform

description: I20040517-1219  1) Checkout org.eclipse.swt and whatever native fragment for the given platform 2) Open StyledText.java 3) Ctrl+A (select all) 4) Ctrl+/ (toggle comment)  -> OutOfMemoryError  If you allocate a very big Java heap, it might only occur after step 5)  5) Ctrl+/ (toggle comment again)  According to Windows taskmanager, memory usage before step 4) is 145MB. At the time of OutOfMemoryError Windows is reporting 570MB used. It seems to require over 300MB of RAM to comment this file.  Reproducible on Windows with Sidecar and Sun 1.4.1, and on MacOSX with latest Sun VM.

description: I like to use the CVS "update" feature, with CVS Console output turned on. That way I can quickly see the changes merges and it does not require a lot of clicking like sync does.  However this feature is limited useful on my 3.0M9 (possibly earlier, too), since the console seems to repaint too much of the lower message area. Even if I do not have the "console" tab with CVS output in the foreground, I can see heavy repaint fickering of the tabs and the status bar, if a lot of red "cvs update:" messages are printed.
my_mothod: I like to use the CVS "update" feature, with CVS Console output turned on. That way I can quickly see the changes merges and it does not require a lot of clicking like sync does.  However this feature is limited useful on my 3.0M9 (possibly earlier, too), since the console seems to repaint too much of the lower message area. Even if I do not have the "console" tab with CVS output in the foreground, I can see heavy repaint fickering of the tabs and the status bar, if a lot of red "cvs update:" messages are printed. [Presentations] DefaultPartPresentation#childPropertyChanged() causes too much view pane flickering minor UI Platform

description: RC1 test candidate A background synchronize was running and I went to edit a file. The user operation is waiting dialog appeared. I let the synchronize complete, the afterwards the user operation remained in the dialog. The name of the user operation is the name of my workbench window (I don't know why this is the case) but when I pressed the cancel button for the user operation nothing happened.  Eclipse is frozen because the user operation waiting dialog can't be closed. Should there at least be a close button? Or some way of getting rid of it?  Here is the stack dump after everything was completed and the dialog wasn't able to be closed. Doesn't look like a deadlock but instead looks like the modal dialog is unresponsive. description: RC1  - lock workspace in background operation - open installed JREs - add a JRE - press OK  observe: nothing happens.   There should be a blocking dialog informing me about the conflict with the  background operation. What is dangerous in this scenario is the fact that I  can cancel the dialog and starting another operation which basically stacks  operations.

description: I200406082000  1) start with an empty workspace 2) create a simple project A 3) create a file f.txt in A 4) tranfer focus to the Navigator 5) modify f.txt externally 6) activate Eclipse without changing the active part 7) press close box of editor open for f.txt  -> A file changed dialog is posted by the editor. While the modal dialog is  open, the editor gets closed. (see stack trace below)  8) press No in the dialog 9) double click on f.txt to open it again  -> nothing happens, no editor is opened (This is also the case when you have  more files in the workspace and try to open an editor on some other file.)  Observation:  I see that the editor is created and its init method is called. I also see  that its createPartControl method is not called. I haven't seen any thrown  exception in the process of opening the editor.   Stack trace of how the original editor on f.txt gets disposed. I'd suspect  that the problem is related to the fact the part is closed while its  activation event is being processed. (see stack trace below)  8) press No in the dialog 9) double click on f.txt to open it again  -> nothing happens, no editor is opened (This is also the case when you have  more files in the workspace and try to open an editor on some other file.)  Observation:  I see that the editor is created and its init method is called. I also see  that its createPartControl method is not called. I haven't seen any thrown  exception in the process of opening the editor.   Stack trace of how the original editor on f.txt gets disposed. I'd suspect  that the problem is related to the fact the part is closed while its  activation event is being processed. description: Version 3.0.rc1.  When you put tasks in the background and these tasks do not complete normally, you get an error icon in the bottom right corner of the main window. Each time you click on the icon, the "Error Occured" dialog comes up. After you click ok, you have to keep on clicking on the icon over and over to see all of the errors.   This is quite tedious, especially considering that there is no indication of when the error happened or what initial UI operation caused the error (for example, menu item Team/Commit..." on resource "Foo"). Sure, you can guess, but it should not be  that hard.  My requests are:  - Add a timestamp indicating when the error occurred. - Add a description of the user action that caused the task to be invoked.  Then either: - Add a "Next..." button that gives the user the next error in the stack Or: - Change the dialog when >1 error occured to contain a list box at the top and the description at the bottom. The user can then quickly look over the error or dimiss the whole lot in one swoop.  Thank you. Eclipse rules.
my_mothod: Version 3.0.rc1.  When you put tasks in the background and these tasks do not complete normally, you get an error icon in the bottom right corner of the main window. Each time you click on the icon, the "Error Occured" dialog comes up. After you click ok, you have to keep on clicking on the icon over and over to see all of the errors.   This is quite tedious, especially considering that there is no indication of when the error happened or what initial UI operation caused the error (for example, menu item Team/Commit..." on resource "Foo"). Sure, you can guess, but it should not be  that hard.  My requests are:  - Add a timestamp indicating when the error occurred. - Add a description of the user action that caused the task to be invoked.  Then either: - Add a "Next..." button that gives the user the next error in the stack Or: - Change the dialog when >1 error occured to contain a list box at the top and the description at the bottom. The user can then quickly look over the error or dimiss the whole lot in one swoop.  Thank you. Eclipse rules. [Progress] "Error Occured " needs a better UI minor UI Platform

description: This occurs intermittently on Eclipse 3.0 RC2.  In the Java text editor, cut and copy sometimes don't work and at other times lock up the Eclipse GUI (need to kill Eclipse to continue).  I have tested several scenarios and have seen the problem about half a dozen times (I only started using RC2 today) but I have been unable to figure out how to reliably reproduce the problem. (It may have something to do with the import block but I cannot be certain.)  Sorry to be so vague.
my_mothod: This occurs intermittently on Eclipse 3.0 RC2.  In the Java text editor, cut and copy sometimes don't work and at other times lock up the Eclipse GUI (need to kill Eclipse to continue).  I have tested several scenarios and have seen the problem about half a dozen times (I only started using RC2 today) but I have been unable to figure out how to reliably reproduce the problem. (It may have something to do with the import block but I cannot be certain.)  Sorry to be so vague. cut, copy locks up critical Text JDT

description: Eclipse build number: 200406111814 CDT build number: 200406140300  Test case: P.S.: Launch eclipse under "C:/Program Files" (because this bug occurs when  the workspace has a space in the path) 1. Create a 'Managed C++ Executable Project' (call it A). 2. Create a 'Managed C++ Static Library Project' (call it B). 3. Add a class to each respective project. 4. Open the project properties for A, select the 'C/C++ Build' item from the  listbox on the left. Click the 'Manage' button and change the 'Make command'  from 'make' to 'make -t'. 5. Do the same for B, but use 'make -s' instead. 6. Open the project properties of A and select 'Project References' from the  listbox on the left.  Make A reference B. 7. Right click on project A and select 'Rebuild project'.  The problem is that a file C:/Program gets created. Here is what the console  shows after "Rebuild":  **** Full rebuild of configuration Debug for project A ****  make -t clean all        4 [main] make 2460 handle_exceptions: Exception: STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION     894 [main] make 2460 open_stackdumpfile: Dumping stack trace to  make.exe.stackdump make: Nothing to be done for `clean'. touch FooA.o touch C:/Program Build complete for project A  The line "touch C:/Program" above creates a file "Program". This "Program"  file blocks all the actions on eclipse. Basically nothing can be done on  eclipse after this. Restart eclipse and creating a new project gives an error.  See attachment for the screenshot of the error. This is what the console shows after kicking off a build on a project:  **** Full rebuild of configuration Debug for project M ****  Build error (Exec error:Access is denied. )  So projects can't be built either. If the file C:/Program is deleted and eclipse is restarted, then everything  works fine.   Thanks, Pixy.

Do the same for B, but use 'make -s' instead. 6. Open the project properties of A and select 'Project References' from the  listbox on the left.  Make A reference B. 7. Right click on project A and select 'Rebuild project'.  The problem is that a file C:/Program gets created. Here is what the console  shows after "Rebuild":  **** Full rebuild of configuration Debug for project A ****  make -t clean all        4 [main] make 2460 handle_exceptions: Exception: STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION     894 [main] make 2460 open_stackdumpfile: Dumping stack trace to  make.exe.stackdump make: Nothing to be done for `clean'. touch FooA.o touch C:/Program Build complete for project A  The line "touch C:/Program" above creates a file "Program". This "Program"  file blocks all the actions on eclipse. Basically nothing can be done on  eclipse after this. Restart eclipse and creating a new project gives an error.  See attachment for the screenshot of the error. This is what the console shows after kicking off a build on a project:  **** Full rebuild of configuration Debug for project M ****  Build error (Exec error:Access is denied. )  So projects can't be built either. If the file C:/Program is deleted and eclipse is restarted, then everything  works fine.   Thanks, Pixy. [Managed build]: All the actions on eclipse result in an error after performing "Rebuild" on a project referencing another project in a workspace with space in it's path. critical cdt-core CDT

description: RC3  The regression was introduced by a fix we put in into M5. The bug number is 45062. However this problem was already raised against 2.1 and we fixed it for  2.1.1 since we considered it major there.  The problem appears in situations where clients create a folder insides a  source folder with a non package name (for example a-b) and source folder ==  output folder.  We havent't seen this since Eclipse developement setup is src and output  folder bin.   Test cases:  - create normal Java project - select project  - New->Folder - enter name a-b  observe: folder doesn't show-up.
my_mothod: RC3  The regression was introduced by a fix we put in into M5. The bug number is 45062. However this problem was already raised against 2.1 and we fixed it for  2.1.1 since we considered it major there.  The problem appears in situations where clients create a folder insides a  source folder with a non package name (for example a-b) and source folder ==  output folder.  We havent't seen this since Eclipse developement setup is src and output  folder bin.   Test cases:  - create normal Java project - select project  - New->Folder - enter name a-b  observe: folder doesn't show-up. Regression: package explorer doesn't show folders with non package names anymore critical UI JDT

description: 3.0 RC3  Eclipse hangs when I start eclipse with my existing workspace, the hit ctrl-shift-F4 or click "Close All" from the menu.  There is nothing written to the .log file.  I demonstrated the problem to Doug.  I created a 30workspace.zip of my workspace - it is on the local network in my accounts directory.
my_mothod: 3.0 RC3  Eclipse hangs when I start eclipse with my existing workspace, the hit ctrl-shift-F4 or click "Close All" from the menu.  There is nothing written to the .log file.  I demonstrated the problem to Doug.  I created a 30workspace.zip of my workspace - it is on the local network in my accounts directory. Eclipse hangs on "Close All" (ctrl-shift-F4 or menu item) critical Ant Platform

description: A bug where a key binding appears to have been created, but doesn't activate I have an editor plugin based on the text-editor.  I declare commands and key-bindings in plugin.xml I create actions, assign definition IDs to them (matching them to the commands) and add them to some menus in a sub-class of BasicTextEditorActionContributor.  The commands and key-bindings appear in the key-bindings preference page. The actions appear in the menus, and work normally. Moreover, the menu entries show both the action label and the correct key-binding  (eg. "Sample Action   Ctrl-Q"). However actually pressing the key-sequence does nothing.  If I declare the actions in plugin.xml as part of an action-set, then the key-sequences *do* work. However this is not a suitable workaround, as I need access to the active-editor.
my_mothod: A bug where a key binding appears to have been created, but doesn't activate I have an editor plugin based on the text-editor.  I declare commands and key-bindings in plugin.xml I create actions, assign definition IDs to them (matching them to the commands) and add them to some menus in a sub-class of BasicTextEditorActionContributor.  The commands and key-bindings appear in the key-bindings preference page. The actions appear in the menus, and work normally. Moreover, the menu entries show both the action label and the correct key-binding  (eg. "Sample Action   Ctrl-Q"). However actually pressing the key-sequence does nothing.  If I declare the actions in plugin.xml as part of an action-set, then the key-sequences *do* work. However this is not a suitable workaround, as I need access to the active-editor. [KeyBindings] doc: New key bindings fail to work in text editor trivial UI Platform

description: We have a project build that consists of  1. Run ANT build target X (pre-compile) 2. Run Java Builder 2. Run ANT build target Y (post-compile)  Under 2.1, all ran in order, all was well.  Under 3.0, the execution order (confirmed by watching build dialog) is 1, 3,  2.  Build fails miserably.    ?
my_mothod: We have a project build that consists of  1. Run ANT build target X (pre-compile) 2. Run Java Builder 2. Run ANT build target Y (post-compile)  Under 2.1, all ran in order, all was well.  Under 3.0, the execution order (confirmed by watching build dialog) is 1, 3,  2.  Build fails miserably.    ? Project builders do not execute in specified order. blocker Ant Platform

description: In most cases, the default width of the Workspace Launcher provides a decent amount of space to display the full path to a workspace.  However, in the case that the path is exceptionally long, shouldn't the Workspace Launcher remain at a constant width or have a maximum width that it will expand?  It currently expands to a width such that the full path of the selected workspace will be displayed.  Steps to reproduce: 1) Select a workspace with path that is very long in the Workspace Launcher. 2) Start Eclipse with that workspace. 3) Restart Eclipse and notice the width of the Workspace Launcher Dialog.
my_mothod: In most cases, the default width of the Workspace Launcher provides a decent amount of space to display the full path to a workspace.  However, in the case that the path is exceptionally long, shouldn't the Workspace Launcher remain at a constant width or have a maximum width that it will expand?  It currently expands to a width such that the full path of the selected workspace will be displayed.  Steps to reproduce: 1) Select a workspace with path that is very long in the Workspace Launcher. 2) Start Eclipse with that workspace. 3) Restart Eclipse and notice the width of the Workspace Launcher Dialog. [WorkbenchLauncher] Workspace Launcher Dialog grows in width for long paths minor UI Platform

description: There are several places in the GUI where user create a "info pop-up" dialog.   Unfortunately, as it is now, these dialogs are written from scratch and share  little common code.  A utility class for creating such dialogs would reduce  code, and help to ensure a common look & feel.    These are the characteristics I see as being common to these dialogs:  + Background colour  + Always on top  + Does not appear in the window list  + Deactivating the shell closes it  + Resizable; remembers size    There might be others as well.
my_mothod: There are several places in the GUI where user create a "info pop-up" dialog.   Unfortunately, as it is now, these dialogs are written from scratch and share  little common code.  A utility class for creating such dialogs would reduce  code, and help to ensure a common look & feel.    These are the characteristics I see as being common to these dialogs:  + Background colour  + Always on top  + Does not appear in the window list  + Deactivating the shell closes it  + Resizable; remembers size    There might be others as well. [Dialogs] Provide a generic info pop dialog enhancement UI Platform

description: I200409140800  The popup table that helps me with multi-stroke keyboard shortcuts is displaced. It hangs out of the lower-right border of the workbench window. This is especially annoying when working in full-screen mode, since the popup is cut off then.  The Ctrl+Shift+L popup has the same problem (Dani mentioned it in bug 72161 comment 2).
my_mothod: I200409140800  The popup table that helps me with multi-stroke keyboard shortcuts is displaced. It hangs out of the lower-right border of the workbench window. This is especially annoying when working in full-screen mode, since the popup is cut off then.  The Ctrl+Shift+L popup has the same problem (Dani mentioned it in bug 72161 comment 2). [KeyBindings] Multi-stroke shortcut helper popup displaced minor UI Platform

description: I am seeing very slow project creation because it seems that all files must  be statted and identified prior to interacting with the project.  Similarly  starting up Eclipse is slowed down as all files must be statted during startup.    This problem is made even worse over NFS or MVFS.    I propose 'lazy' resource discovery.  When a project is created or Eclipse is   started just put a placeholder in place for the project.  Put the process of  getting directory listings in a background thread, queued by directory   depth (ie list and stat for top level directories for projects before  beginning decent into subdirs).  User opening of a project or directory  in a project adds priority to that projects or directories listings.  In   the event that a User has drilled down a listing not yet filled  in use the same "Pending..." that the CVS folks use to let the user  know things are coming.    The goal is to give the illusion that a project (or Eclipse as a whole) is  immediately available, and then conspire to makes sure that whenever a  developer is looking for information it is already present.

When a project is created or Eclipse is   started just put a placeholder in place for the project.  Put the process of  getting directory listings in a background thread, queued by directory   depth (ie list and stat for top level directories for projects before  beginning decent into subdirs).  User opening of a project or directory  in a project adds priority to that projects or directories listings.  In   the event that a User has drilled down a listing not yet filled  in use the same "Pending..." that the CVS folks use to let the user  know things are coming.    The goal is to give the illusion that a project (or Eclipse as a whole) is  immediately available, and then conspire to makes sure that whenever a  developer is looking for information it is already present. Slow project creation due to stating many files enhancement Resources Platform

description: Version: 3.1.0 Build id: 200412070800  Copy in Emacs is "Alt-W", the shortcut works perfectly but all the menus in Eclipse show "Ctrl-c" as the copy shortcut, which has other semantics in the Emacs configuration.  Similarly, the standard shortcuts to cut and paste text are "Ctrl-w" and "Ctrl-y", but the menus indicate "Shift-Delete" and "Shift-Insert" instead, which work as well but are more difficult to perform and probably less common.

description: I20050112-1200  On Ctrl+Click and 'Navigate > Open (F3)', the Properties File editor starts a lengthy search for references to the selected property key. This is a fairly unusual action, and it is confusing for the user that a seemingly quick command needs so much time when invoked in the Properties File editor. The Java Editor always jumps to the declaration of the current item, which is always a fast operation.  The right command for this 'property key reference search' would be 'Search > References > Workspace'. This would also solve the problem of displaying multiple targets; the Search view is perfect for this.
my_mothod: I20050112-1200  On Ctrl+Click and 'Navigate > Open (F3)', the Properties File editor starts a lengthy search for references to the selected property key. This is a fairly unusual action, and it is confusing for the user that a seemingly quick command needs so much time when invoked in the Properties File editor. The Java Editor always jumps to the declaration of the current item, which is always a fast operation.  The right command for this 'property key reference search' would be 'Search > References > Workspace'. This would also solve the problem of displaying multiple targets; the Search view is perfect for this. [nls tooling] Ctrl+Click and 'Navigate > Open' should not start a search enhancement Text JDT

description: If you have a service or an application that is listening on a specific port,  e.g. 8888, and if you try to attach the java debugger to that port using the  Remote Java Application launch, the Launching process will neither timeout nor  complete.   By checking into the code, this is what I found: >> When trying to attach to a debuggable JVM, JDT issues a call to  SocketTransportImpl.attach(String hostname, int port) >> which creates a new Socket, and then >> makes a call to PerformHandshake() >> Within PerformHandshake(), since the SO_TIMEOUT option has never being set  to a non-zero value, a default of 0 is used, a read() call on the InputStream  associated with this Socket will block forever until the read() is complete. >> which results in the call to in.readFully(handshakeInput) (insdie  PerformHandshake()) never return because the read cannot be complete.  The finding of this problem is a result from the investigation of a customer  PMR, where the customer was trying to debug a web application in a WAS server.  The WAS server got started in debug mode, but our debugger never got attached.  The customer had some service running and listening on port 7777, which is the  default debug port WAS is using when in debug mode.
my_mothod: If you have a service or an application that is listening on a specific port,  e.g. 8888, and if you try to attach the java debugger to that port using the  Remote Java Application launch, the Launching process will neither timeout nor  complete.   By checking into the code, this is what I found: >> When trying to attach to a debuggable JVM, JDT issues a call to  SocketTransportImpl.attach(String hostname, int port) >> which creates a new Socket, and then >> makes a call to PerformHandshake() >> Within PerformHandshake(), since the SO_TIMEOUT option has never being set  to a non-zero value, a default of 0 is used, a read() call on the InputStream  associated with this Socket will block forever until the read() is complete. >> which results in the call to in.readFully(handshakeInput) (insdie  PerformHandshake()) never return because the read cannot be complete.  The finding of this problem is a result from the investigation of a customer  PMR, where the customer was trying to debug a web application in a WAS server.  The WAS server got started in debug mode, but our debugger never got attached.  The customer had some service running and listening on port 7777, which is the  default debug port WAS is using when in debug mode. Unable to timeout when attaching to a bogus debug port critical Debug JDT

description: I20050217-2000  Steps to reproduce: - Create simple project with files "dummy1.txt" and "dummy2.txt" - Open both files in text editor - Perform "Save As" on dummy2.txt, overwrite dummy1.txt, confirm yes on replace -> Warning message apprears: "Save could not be completed. not the same  document"  -> If the editor showing dummy1.txt is not dirty, there is no reason for this  message, since the replacement has already been confirmed -> If the editor is dirty, the error message should mention that the file  which gets overwritten is already open in an editor and contains unsaved  changes
my_mothod: I20050217-2000  Steps to reproduce: - Create simple project with files "dummy1.txt" and "dummy2.txt" - Open both files in text editor - Perform "Save As" on dummy2.txt, overwrite dummy1.txt, confirm yes on replace -> Warning message apprears: "Save could not be completed. not the same  document"  -> If the editor showing dummy1.txt is not dirty, there is no reason for this  message, since the replacement has already been confirmed -> If the editor is dirty, the error message should mention that the file  which gets overwritten is already open in an editor and contains unsaved  changes [wording] Unclear error message when performing "Save As" overwriting file already open in editor trivial Text Platform

description: I20050315-1100  Preferences > Installed JREs > Edit..., uncheck "Use default system libraries".  Doubleclicking on a Source attachment / Javadoc location tree item should open the appropriate editing dialog. The "Edit" button should be called "Edit...".
my_mothod: I20050315-1100  Preferences > Installed JREs > Edit..., uncheck "Use default system libraries".  Doubleclicking on a Source attachment / Javadoc location tree item should open the appropriate editing dialog. The "Edit" button should be called "Edit...". Edit JRE Dialog: Doubleclick should edit source att. / javadoc loc. dialogs trivial Debug JDT

my_mothod: Eclipse 3.1 M6  Open the General -> Editors -> Text Editor page in the Preference dialog.  The data entry fields are too far away from their descriptions.  The label should align with the field to  make more sense. [preferences] Text Editor preference page badly aligned trivial Text Platform

description: With a simple Java application, set a breakpoint somewhere. Open the Display View.  Hide the Display View by bringing the Console view to  the top.    Start the debug session.  When the debug session is suspended, the Display view  is brought to the top unexpectedly.  It was expected that the Console view  would stay on top.
my_mothod: With a simple Java application, set a breakpoint somewhere. Open the Display View.  Hide the Display View by bringing the Console view to  the top.    Start the debug session.  When the debug session is suspended, the Display view  is brought to the top unexpectedly.  It was expected that the Console view  would stay on top. Display View unexpectedly brought to top when debug session is suspended trivial Debug Platform

description: Snippet from Testcase:         System.out.println("Enter something.");        try {         int a;         String str = new String();         a = System.in.read();         str += (char)a;         System.out.println(str);     } catch (IOException e) {         e.printStackTrace();     }   In the launch config common tab, turn off "Capture Output" for both Console and  File. (i.e. the output is not captured anywhere.)  Run the debug session.  The Process Console is not opened.  As a result, I  cannot enter any input to my testcase to finish running my testcase.
my_mothod: Snippet from Testcase:         System.out.println("Enter something.");        try {         int a;         String str = new String();         a = System.in.read();         str += (char)a;         System.out.println(str);     } catch (IOException e) {         e.printStackTrace();     }   In the launch config common tab, turn off "Capture Output" for both Console and  File. (i.e. the output is not captured anywhere.)  Run the debug session.  The Process Console is not opened.  As a result, I  cannot enter any input to my testcase to finish running my testcase. [polish] [Console] Process Console not opened if output is not captured anywhere trivial Debug Platform

description: I ran out of disk space while editing files in Eclipse.  I saved all the files I was working on, and no error was reported.  However I started getting errors that Eclipse couldn't save project metadata.  The error kept popping up, and (because I still didn't know I was out of disk space) I just assumed Eclipse was in a weird state.  I closed Eclipse and re-opened it.  Some of my files were empty or truncated, and I was still getting the problems with metadata save errors.  I checked the logs and found the "No space left on device" errors.  Unfortunately, by this time I had lost a large amount of work, because the files I had saved were either empty or truncated.  So the problems are: - Saving reported no warning or error when there was no space left, but simply truncated the file (sometimes at byte 0). - The errors in saving metadata gave no information about the underlying exception (No space left on device). description: 3.1-RC1 test pass  - Have the two CU's below - Both open in a java editor - Refactor>Move the enum 'Natural' from SubType to SuperType  Note: the move operation is correctly executed  Expected: Edit>Undo is enabled und undoes the move operation  Actual. Undo is disabled. If the editors had non-empty undo histories before the operation, undo is still enabled and will execute weird changes on the editors, as the undos seem to not have noticed the changes by the move operation.  -------- SuperType.java ---------- package com.move;  public class SuperType { } -------- SubType.java ------------ package com.move;  public class SubType extends SuperType { 	protected static enum Natural {ONE, TWO, THREE} } ----------------------------------
my_mothod: 3.1-RC1 test pass  - Have the two CU's below - Both open in a java editor - Refactor>Move the enum 'Natural' from SubType to SuperType  Note: the move operation is correctly executed  Expected: Edit>Undo is enabled und undoes the move operation  Actual. Undo is disabled. If the editors had non-empty undo histories before the operation, undo is still enabled and will execute weird changes on the editors, as the undos seem to not have noticed the changes by the move operation.  -------- SuperType.java ---------- package com.move;  public class SuperType { } -------- SubType.java ------------ package com.move;  public class SubType extends SuperType { 	protected static enum Natural {ONE, TWO, THREE} } ---------------------------------- [undo/redo] move enum leaves undo stack in corrupt state critical UI JDT

description: RC1  The Java - Editor - Code assist preference page has a link to the access rules  - we should be consistent on terms: On the build path page we call it 'Access rules', the error/warning page also uses this term  - the link should reveal the corresponding section (pass a Map as data to the page: map.put(ProblemSeveritiesPreferencePage.DATA_SELECT_OPTION_KEY, JavaCore.COMPILER_PB_FORBIDDEN_REFERENCE); map.put(ProblemSeveritiesPreferencePage.DATA_SELECT_OPTION_QUALIFIER, JavaCore.PLUGIN_ID);  - even better might be to show some information hover explaining that you can add access rules on build path entries
my_mothod: RC1  The Java - Editor - Code assist preference page has a link to the access rules  - we should be consistent on terms: On the build path page we call it 'Access rules', the error/warning page also uses this term  - the link should reveal the corresponding section (pass a Map as data to the page: map.put(ProblemSeveritiesPreferencePage.DATA_SELECT_OPTION_KEY, JavaCore.COMPILER_PB_FORBIDDEN_REFERENCE); map.put(ProblemSeveritiesPreferencePage.DATA_SELECT_OPTION_QUALIFIER, JavaCore.PLUGIN_ID);  - even better might be to show some information hover explaining that you can add access rules on build path entries [preferences] Access restriction link should open correct section trivial Text JDT
