description: A client of the Transaction API may find it useful to know when post-commit notifications are the result of an undo/redo of a command.  Undo/redo transactions are distinguished currently by not implementing the usual data integrity mechanisms, because they merely transition from one known good state to another.  However, there are other reasons why these transaction options may be applied, and a client that does additional work on command execution may need a more reliable means of identifying changes resulting from undo or redo.  This can most conveniently be done by adding a new boolean-valued OPTION_IS_UNDO_REDO to the undo/redo transaction.
my_mothod: A client of the Transaction API may find it useful to know when post-commit notifications are the result of an undo/redo of a command.  Undo/redo transactions are distinguished currently by not implementing the usual data integrity mechanisms, because they merely transition from one known good state to another.  However, there are other reasons why these transaction options may be applied, and a client that does additional work on command execution may need a more reliable means of identifying changes resulting from undo or redo.  This can most conveniently be done by adding a new boolean-valued OPTION_IS_UNDO_REDO to the undo/redo transaction. Transactions should indicate if they were the result of an undo/redo operation enhancement Transaction EMF Services

description: Currently if I have to use a http proxy I've to enter it manually in every workspace. This is not very useable for various reasons. Most programs use the system settings for the proxy (available on all OS). Eclipse should have the possibility to do the same, so an "use system settings" opton should be the default. If the user wants to specify the proxy manually he could choose "specify proxy" and enter the data as ususal.
my_mothod: Currently if I have to use a http proxy I've to enter it manually in every workspace. This is not very useable for various reasons. Most programs use the system settings for the proxy (available on all OS). Eclipse should have the possibility to do the same, so an "use system settings" opton should be the default. If the user wants to specify the proxy manually he could choose "specify proxy" and enter the data as ususal. [Proxy] Use system values for proxy settings enhancement Team Platform

description: Build ID: I20070323-1616  The first of the layout problems is that the selection buttons have unnecessary space on the right: 1. CheckedTreeSelectionDialog#createSelectionButtons(Composite) configures the buttonComposite it creates with a GridLayout that initially starts with 2 numColumns. 2. Later it uses Dialog#createButton(Composite,int,String,boolean) to create the buttons "Selection All" and "Deselect All" with their parent set to buttonComposite. Because the method in question retrieves the layout of the specified parent (i.e. buttonComposite) and increases its numColumns for each created Button, the GridLayout of buttonComposite ends up with numColumns set to 4 while there are only 2 Buttons. 3. So buttonComposite is left with unintended space on the right which is easily visible when buttonComposite is aligned to the right.  The second of the layout problems is that the selection buttons are aligned to the left: 1. CheckedTreeSelectionDialog#createSelectionButtons(Composite) creates a GridData with GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_END|GridData.GRAB_HORIZONTAL which I think is intended to align buttonComposite to the right like ListSelectionDialog has the buttons "Select All" and "Deselect All" to the right. However, the GridData in question is not attached to any control with setLayoutData(Object) but is remembered in the argument composite using setData(Object) and doesn't seem to be retrieved later on. 2. So buttonComposite is left aligned to the left which is in contrast to the right-aligned buttons of ListSelectionDialog.  More information: I think CheckedTreeSelectionDialog and ListSelectionDialog should be consistent and align the selection buttons to the same side.

CheckedTreeSelectionDialog#createSelectionButtons(Composite) configures the buttonComposite it creates with a GridLayout that initially starts with 2 numColumns. 2. Later it uses Dialog#createButton(Composite,int,String,boolean) to create the buttons "Selection All" and "Deselect All" with their parent set to buttonComposite. Because the method in question retrieves the layout of the specified parent (i.e. buttonComposite) and increases its numColumns for each created Button, the GridLayout of buttonComposite ends up with numColumns set to 4 while there are only 2 Buttons. 3. So buttonComposite is left with unintended space on the right which is easily visible when buttonComposite is aligned to the right.  The second of the layout problems is that the selection buttons are aligned to the left: 1. CheckedTreeSelectionDialog#createSelectionButtons(Composite) creates a GridData with GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_END|GridData.GRAB_HORIZONTAL which I think is intended to align buttonComposite to the right like ListSelectionDialog has the buttons "Select All" and "Deselect All" to the right. However, the GridData in question is not attached to any control with setLayoutData(Object) but is remembered in the argument composite using setData(Object) and doesn't seem to be retrieved later on. 2. So buttonComposite is left aligned to the left which is in contrast to the right-aligned buttons of ListSelectionDialog.  More information: I think CheckedTreeSelectionDialog and ListSelectionDialog should be consistent and align the selection buttons to the same side. [Dialogs] CheckedTreeSelectionDialog#createSelectionButtons(Composite) fails to align the selection buttons to the right trivial UI Platform

description: Next to shampoo-and-conditioner 2-in-1, the JDT classpath container is arguably the best invention of the last 100 years.  One limitation that exists though is the inability to resolve the container to a classpath entry that directly references a class folder in the file system.    see bug 109137 for one such use case that would benefit from this support.  There are certainly more that could benefit from it.  PDE is not the only client that uses classpath containers (but it is certainly the coolest).  To recap comments from bug 109137, some seem to refer to 'linked folders' as the answer to this problem, but linked folders in this case have several problems/limitations:  Problem #1: Linked folders cannot be created during a POST_CHANGE event when the resource tree is locked (bug 64340 comment 18)  Workaround for problem #1: during a POST_CHANGE event, create a classpath entry and have it reference a non-existent linked folder linking to the class folder on disk.  Then during a PRE_BUILD event, right before jdt/core validates the classpath, you get a chance to create the linked folder that you referenced earlier.  This would allow the compilation to proceed normally without JDT being aware of the trick that was done.  Problem #2: Linked folders dirty shared .project files with non-sharable data.  We don't want to relive another episode of bug 46668.  This one is a deal breaker.  The .project file must not get dirty and must remain true to the dynamic nature of the container.  Problem #3: The classpath container client needs to keep track of linked folders since he would have to remove any folders he created should the dependency on the corresponding plug-in goes away.  Problem #4: Creating linked folders in every project that needs them may result in a large number of links being created.  Is the client expected to create a special place where he can pool/recycle linked folders?  These are the problems that have come up so far.    Expecting clients of classpath containers to address and/or work around all these issues on their own is a big burden on them.  Each will have to come up with their own creative/hackish solution.  That's not in our JDT contract, so to speak.  We need to come up with a solution that will allow a client to resolve a classpath container to a classpath entry that references an external folder with the same ease that they currently can reference an external JAR.  Interestingly, if you read the entertaining bug 46668, you will see a previous crisis that is circumstantially very similar to this one, but with a happy ending.  I am confident we can do the same here.

description: Build ID: I20070323-1616  I'd like to propose an optimization to MutableActivityManager#setEnabledActivityIds().  In the method MutableActivityManager#updateIdentifier(Identifier identifier) change the following:  boolean matchesAtLeastOneEnabled = false; boolean matchesAtLeastOneDisabled = false; for (Iterator iterator = definedActivityIds.iterator();      iterator.hasNext();) {     ... }  To:  boolean matchesAtLeastOneEnabled = false; boolean matchesAtLeastOneDisabled = false; for (Iterator iterator = definedActivityIds.iterator();      !matchesAtLeastOneEnabled && iterator.hasNext();) {     ... }  Since the largest chunk of time when setting activities is taken up within this for loop by checking the activity patterns, this could skip on average a large number of pattern matches.
my_mothod: Build ID: I20070323-1616  I'd like to propose an optimization to MutableActivityManager#setEnabledActivityIds().  In the method MutableActivityManager#updateIdentifier(Identifier identifier) change the following:  boolean matchesAtLeastOneEnabled = false; boolean matchesAtLeastOneDisabled = false; for (Iterator iterator = definedActivityIds.iterator();      iterator.hasNext();) {     ... }  To:  boolean matchesAtLeastOneEnabled = false; boolean matchesAtLeastOneDisabled = false; for (Iterator iterator = definedActivityIds.iterator();      !matchesAtLeastOneEnabled && iterator.hasNext();) {     ... }  Since the largest chunk of time when setting activities is taken up within this for loop by checking the activity patterns, this could skip on average a large number of pattern matches. [ActivityMgmt] Optimize performance of MutableActivityManager#setEnabledActivityIds() minor UI Platform

description: 3.3 RC2:  If you type Ctrl+3 to open the new commands window, type something, and type Home/End to move the cursor to the beginning/end of string, this is handled by the editor instead of the popup.  Unfortunatelly the cursor is not shown, so so can see the effect by testing using Shift+Home/End, and the line on editor will be selected, instead of the popup textbox.  Strange to see that is happens on Java editor, but it doesn't on Mylar task editor (perhaps something related to generic text editor itself?).

description: Entity-groups in the new JSF common metadata framework is meant to simplify metadata creation by allowing the definition of a set of 'entities' and 'traits' that can be applied to N-number of entities.  These are designed to apply after merging of all metadata and then merged in at the "include" position.   If an entity or trait with the same id already exists, then the entity-group's entity or trait would NOT be merged.    The design problem is that it was not intended to recurse through the group's entities to check to see if those existed in the merged metadata, or not.  Initially it was thought that if an entity already existed, that metadata item's contained traits and entities should not be merged from the entity-group.  If for example, a TAG entity has a child entity of A, and also an included entity-group that defines, say, ATTRIBUTE entities B and C, then the merged TAG entity will have child entities of A, B, and C where all of the traits and entities of A come from the TAG/A entity, and all of the entities and traits of B and C come from the included group.   If TAG had A and B plus the include, all B metadata would come from TAG/B and not the include.  Unfortunately this has a very bad side effect that requires how the entity-group metadata is merged.   If a 3rd party provides metadata for TAG/C, as an example, to support a new behaviour or tool, then currently all of the metadata that was inside the included C entity will not be merged.   This means that a 3rd party could unintentionally break existing code, and that is clearly not a good thing.  The proposed patch will fix this flaw by recursing through the entity-group and adding its entities and traits to the merged model, if that entity or trait is not already present.   In other words, we will look beyond the first level of entities and traits of the entity-group when merging.     This fix is necessary but does have some risks since we do not know if there are adopters using this feature.  It could affect them negatively, but ultimately it must be done.
my_mothod: Entity-groups in the new JSF common metadata framework is meant to simplify metadata creation by allowing the definition of a set of 'entities' and 'traits' that can be applied to N-number of entities.  These are designed to apply after merging of all metadata and then merged in at the "include" position.   If an entity or trait with the same id already exists, then the entity-group's entity or trait would NOT be merged.    The design problem is that it was not intended to recurse through the group's entities to check to see if those existed in the merged metadata, or not.  Initially it was thought that if an entity already existed, that metadata item's contained traits and entities should not be merged from the entity-group.  If for example, a TAG entity has a child entity of A, and also an included entity-group that defines, say, ATTRIBUTE entities B and C, then the merged TAG entity will have child entities of A, B, and C where all of the traits and entities of A come from the TAG/A entity, and all of the entities and traits of B and C come from the included group.   If TAG had A and B plus the include, all B metadata would come from TAG/B and not the include.  Unfortunately this has a very bad side effect that requires how the entity-group metadata is merged.   If a 3rd party provides metadata for TAG/C, as an example, to support a new behaviour or tool, then currently all of the metadata that was inside the included C entity will not be merged.   This means that a 3rd party could unintentionally break existing code, and that is clearly not a good thing.  The proposed patch will fix this flaw by recursing through the entity-group and adding its entities and traits to the merged model, if that entity or trait is not already present.   In other words, we will look beyond the first level of entities and traits of the entity-group when merging.     This fix is necessary but does have some risks since we do not know if there are adopters using this feature.  It could affect them negatively, but ultimately it must be done. Design flaw in metadata 'include-entity-group' functionality major Core Java Server Faces

description: Build ID: 3.3 RC4  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open Workspace "C:/tmp/deleteme", close Eclipse 2. Open Workspace "c:/tmp/deleteme", close Eclipse 3. Open Eclipse, check number of recent workspaces.   More information: It's really a nuisance, but the overall issue is that C: and c: are treated as being different on windows, which is incorrect and leads to false assumptions (in my case that one workspace is two).

More information: It's really a nuisance, but the overall issue is that C: and c: are treated as being different on windows, which is incorrect and leads to false assumptions (in my case that one workspace is two). description: Observed:  When Hunk.doPatch applies a deletion, it looks for a subsequence of lines within the fuzz range that match the before state of the hunk.  Expected:  Hunk.doPatch looks for a set of lines within the fuzz range that match the before state exactly.   Consequence:  If a hunk starts with an easily-matched line such as the deletion of a closing brace and the user is using a big fuzz factor, then the patcher could end up deleting any closing brace in the file - not necessarily the particular closing brace that is part of the intended hunk.   I will attach a patch and some files that demonstrate the problem. Marking as critical due to user data loss.
my_mothod: Observed:  When Hunk.doPatch applies a deletion, it looks for a subsequence of lines within the fuzz range that match the before state of the hunk.  Expected:  Hunk.doPatch looks for a set of lines within the fuzz range that match the before state exactly.   Consequence:  If a hunk starts with an easily-matched line such as the deletion of a closing brace and the user is using a big fuzz factor, then the patcher could end up deleting any closing brace in the file - not necessarily the particular closing brace that is part of the intended hunk.   I will attach a patch and some files that demonstrate the problem. Marking as critical due to user data loss. [Patch] Eclipse patcher does not require deletions or context lines to be contiguous critical Compare Platform

description: WorkspaceSynchronizer.processDelta() : Resource resource = getEditingDomain().getResourceSet().getResource(URI.createPlatformResourceURI(delta.getFullPath().toString()), false);  in this method WorkspaceSynchronizer is trying to get resource using URI created without encoding. (using .createPlatformResourceURI(String pathName)) As a result this uri can not be correctly matched with the encoded URI of resource existing in the ResourceSet (if any).  We definitely should support both shemas of URI creation in a WorkspaceSynchronizer. I can see two possibilities to fix this problem:  1. Create encoded URI and try getting correspondiong resource from the ResourceSet if first attempt to achieve resource using non-encoded URI fails.  or 2. Assume that each ResourceSet (and WorkspaceSynchronizer) has own URI loading scheme (either "encode" or "not") and create corresponding boolean parameter in WorkspaceSynchronizer constructor. URIs will be created in accordance with this parameter later on.
my_mothod: WorkspaceSynchronizer.processDelta() : Resource resource = getEditingDomain().getResourceSet().getResource(URI.createPlatformResourceURI(delta.getFullPath().toString()), false);  in this method WorkspaceSynchronizer is trying to get resource using URI created without encoding. (using .createPlatformResourceURI(String pathName)) As a result this uri can not be correctly matched with the encoded URI of resource existing in the ResourceSet (if any).  We definitely should support both shemas of URI creation in a WorkspaceSynchronizer. I can see two possibilities to fix this problem:  1. Create encoded URI and try getting correspondiong resource from the ResourceSet if first attempt to achieve resource using non-encoded URI fails.  or 2. Assume that each ResourceSet (and WorkspaceSynchronizer) has own URI loading scheme (either "encode" or "not") and create corresponding boolean parameter in WorkspaceSynchronizer constructor. URIs will be created in accordance with this parameter later on. Support encoded resource URIs in WorkspaceSynchronizer major Transaction EMF Services

description: Currently there are many actions and dialogs being used to work with breakpoint working sets.  There is a generic select working set dialog that has check boxes and options that are not used by breakpoint working sets.  This could be simplified.  A single action in the view drop down called "Working Sets..." or "Breakpoint Working Sets..." could open a dialog allowing the user to create, edit, and delete working sets.  It would also allow setting of the default working set.  The context menu actions on working sets could stay the same.
my_mothod: Currently there are many actions and dialogs being used to work with breakpoint working sets.  There is a generic select working set dialog that has check boxes and options that are not used by breakpoint working sets.  This could be simplified.  A single action in the view drop down called "Working Sets..." or "Breakpoint Working Sets..." could open a dialog allowing the user to create, edit, and delete working sets.  It would also allow setting of the default working set.  The context menu actions on working sets could stay the same. Improve UI for breakpoint working sets minor Debug Platform

description: ResourceUndoContexts representing the resources that are affected during a write transaction are not added to operations that are executed while a composite operation is open on the operation history. The GMF diagram editor's undo action depends on the ResourceUndoContext.  The WorkspaceCommandStackImpl$DomainListener loses track of the affected resources when a nested operation completes before the transaction is committed.
my_mothod: ResourceUndoContexts representing the resources that are affected during a write transaction are not added to operations that are executed while a composite operation is open on the operation history. The GMF diagram editor's undo action depends on the ResourceUndoContext.  The WorkspaceCommandStackImpl$DomainListener loses track of the affected resources when a nested operation completes before the transaction is committed. Can't undo composite transactional operations opened on the operation history enhancement Transaction EMF Services

description: Created attachment 79548 Show incorrect terminal painting  The latest Terminal update (1.0.1) really broke the Terminal view on OSX.  I am attaching a screenshot where if you look at the command line part you will see large sections do not show their content correctly.  If you resize the view a little bit it fixes the problem (until you type something else).  It seems to work OK on Windows but this is a major regression on OSX.
my_mothod: Created attachment 79548 Show incorrect terminal painting  The latest Terminal update (1.0.1) really broke the Terminal view on OSX.  I am attaching a screenshot where if you look at the command line part you will see large sections do not show their content correctly.  If you resize the view a little bit it fixes the problem (until you type something else).  It seems to work OK on Windows but this is a major regression on OSX. [regression][mac] SSH Terminal does not paint correctly on OSX critical Terminal Target Management

description: using wtp 3.0 m3 i build  1. open the attached wsdl file on the design page 2. click on designPortType2's "output" and drag and drop it so that it's before "input" 3. switch to source page 4. format 5. get the attached stringindexoutofboundsexception  I have not been able to reproduce this on other files, but it seems to always happen with this specific file and following this specific procedure, so I wanted to document it.
my_mothod: using wtp 3.0 m3 i build  1. open the attached wsdl file on the design page 2. click on designPortType2's "output" and drag and drop it so that it's before "input" 3. switch to source page 4. format 5. get the attached stringindexoutofboundsexception  I have not been able to reproduce this on other files, but it seems to always happen with this specific file and following this specific procedure, so I wanted to document it. java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException when format a specific wsdl file minor wst.xml WTP Source Editing

description: As per bug 44107 comment 20:  Symbolic links are an important concept of UNIX-linke file systems, and since Eclipse 3.3 the EFS file system is able to detect them. Especially for legacy projects, it is often very important to know what resources are actually a symbolic link.  Eclipse IDE should provide visual feedback for the user, to see what resources are symbolic links. An overlay icon is suggested for this. Moreover, when looking at the Property page for a resource that's actually a symbolic link, the link target should be displayed in that property page.  In order to accomplish the overlay icon with sufficient performance, it will be necessary to fix bug 44107 before this one can be fixed, since the attribute information whether a resource is a symbolic link or not needs to be cached.
my_mothod: As per bug 44107 comment 20:  Symbolic links are an important concept of UNIX-linke file systems, and since Eclipse 3.3 the EFS file system is able to detect them. Especially for legacy projects, it is often very important to know what resources are actually a symbolic link.  Eclipse IDE should provide visual feedback for the user, to see what resources are symbolic links. An overlay icon is suggested for this. Moreover, when looking at the Property page for a resource that's actually a symbolic link, the link target should be displayed in that property page.  In order to accomplish the overlay icon with sufficient performance, it will be necessary to fix bug 44107 before this one can be fixed, since the attribute information whether a resource is a symbolic link or not needs to be cached. [Decorators] Request an overlay icon for symbolic links in the file system enhancement IDE Platform

description: Build ID: I20071101-2000  Steps To Reproduce: 1.Create java Class as follows  public class Test {  	private void test() 	{ 		 	} }  2. Add APT processor to the Java project (I used APTDemo processor from here --> http://www.eclipse.org/jdt/apt/index.html)  3. Change "private" to "public" in method declaration above  On this change ElementChangedEvent is fired. When I get delta by calling IJavaElementDelta delta = event.getDelta();  I expect the array of affected children in this delta to be non-empty, however IT IS empty.  If I remove annotation processor from the Java project, behavior is back to expected.  This happens to ALL the deltas for all the changes that I tried. This is a BIG problem, since as far as I can see, when the APT processor is enabled on Java project, the delta is pretty much looses it's meaning.     More information:
my_mothod: Build ID: I20071101-2000  Steps To Reproduce: 1.Create java Class as follows  public class Test {  	private void test() 	{ 		 	} }  2. When I get delta by calling IJavaElementDelta delta = event.getDelta();  I expect the array of affected children in this delta to be non-empty, however IT IS empty.  If I remove annotation processor from the Java project, behavior is back to expected.  This happens to ALL the deltas for all the changes that I tried. This is a BIG problem, since as far as I can see, when the APT processor is enabled on Java project, the delta is pretty much looses it's meaning.     More information: IJavaElementDelta contains wrong data after APT processor is enabled critical Core JDT

description: This bug is result of two newsgroup posts: - subject: "uml2ecore, ecore attributes marked as volatile" http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2/msg01540.html - subject: "Generalization of an Aggregation" http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/newsLists/news.eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2/msg01632.html  To implement association generalizations in EMF, the use of properties redefinitions is needed. The implementation of this redefinitions may have some defects that could be fixed.  The bug has to do with the following attributes of redefined/redefining properties:  - names (redefined name equal/different to the redefining one)  - multiplicities  - derived   3 test cases (3 different models):  For the 3 test cases there is a base model with two generalizations AParent             <|---         AChild BParent             <|---         BChild  1. (add 4 properties and 2 associations to the base model) AParent.refB[0..*]  redefinedBy   AChild.refB[0..1] BParent.refA[0..1]  redefinedBy   BChild.refA[1]  2. (add 4 properties and 2 associations to the base model) AParent.refB[0..*]  redefinedBy   AChild.refBChild[0..1] BParent.refA[0..1]  redefinedBy   BChild.refAChild[1]  3. (add 4 properties and 2 associations to the base model) AParent.refB[0..*]  redefinedBy   AChild.refBChild[0..1] BParent.refA[0..1]  redefinedBy   BChild.refA[1]  Possible issues:  Test case 1. (I cannot see the answer from the generated code)  - Do "AChild.getRefB():EList" and "BChild.getRefA():EList" limit the number of elements? These methods override the parents' ones using the parents' fields (ELists). Although the parent's fields are used, the returned lists NEED to internally limit the number of elements. (Note that in this test case there are no methods: "AChild.getRefBChild():BChild" neither "BChild.getRefAChild():AChild")  Test case 2.  - Four get methods need to be created in the children: "AChild.getRefB():EList", "BChild.getRefA():EList", "AChild.getRefBChild():BChild", and "BChild.getRefAChild():AChild". The question for test case 1 is applicable to the methods returning EList which override the parents' ones (the returned lists NEED to internally limit the number of elements).  Test case 3.  - Three get methods need to be created "AChild.getRefBChild():BChild", "AChild.getRefB():EList", and "BChild.getRefA():EList". If I remember correctly the three methods need to be implemented, some generated code could be done though. But the generated code should be aware of the potential issue of the previous test cases.  - Yes, my question was whether a field in AChild called refBChild of type BChild could be created. This field must be an end of an association and should behave as such. This is a tentative implementation, there could be others, as using the field (of type EList) of the parent BUT limiting the size.   Notice I described here potential issues for the get methods but there could be similar issues for the *set* and *isSet* methods.  I noticed as well some issues happening when the property to be redefined or/and the property redefining were derived. This caused generated code of derived properties to have an associated field, what I do not consider correct.  - redefined derived, redefining not derived  - redefined not derived, redefining derived  - redefined not derived, redefining not derived I cannot precise right now which of the 3 cases was wrong.

description: When I do Compare With Base Revision, my workspace file is on the left and the repository file is on the right. This is a bit counter-intuitive for some people, and differs from similar tools such as P4.  Essentially, this should be configurable via user preference and have a button next to the 'change copy' buttons to switch on the fly.
my_mothod: When I do Compare With Base Revision, my workspace file is on the left and the repository file is on the right. This is a bit counter-intuitive for some people, and differs from similar tools such as P4.  Essentially, this should be configurable via user preference and have a button next to the 'change copy' buttons to switch on the fly. Compare With direction should be configurable enhancement Compare Platform

description: It is (currently) not appropriate for companies to have company names in Eclipse project user interfaces. Thus the Help > Polarion... menu must be removed from the org.eclipse.subversive.ui plug-in.  We may, at some future time, have a policy that companies providing significant development resources for Eclipse projects be allowed to advertise in their plug-in's user interface. Currently, however, that is not allowed.
my_mothod: It is (currently) not appropriate for companies to have company names in Eclipse project user interfaces. Thus the Help > Polarion... menu must be removed from the org.eclipse.subversive.ui plug-in.  We may, at some future time, have a policy that companies providing significant development resources for Eclipse projects be allowed to advertise in their plug-in's user interface. Currently, however, that is not allowed. Remove the "Help > Polarion" menu critical UI Subversive

description: Build ID: M20071023-1652  Steps To Reproduce: When there's a build path problem that prevents a project from being built, I think that Eclipse doesn't highlight the problem enough.  After almost three years of working every day with Eclipse, it happens, from time to time, that some co-workers of mine ask me why some strange behaviour occurs... behaviours that often take some minutes to make me realize that they're due to build path problems on one of the projects in the dependency chain...  It may often happen that a project of youers has some code that doesn't compile, but you don't bother because you actually don't need that code at a certain point. But then, the white small "X" on red background on the icon of the project doesn't tell you enough information if there's also a build path problem. If you don't open the "Problems" view, or if this view is hidden, you won't be able to find out when a build path problem is affecting your project or one of those it depends on (missing library, missing required project, missing code indirectly needed by a JAR in the build path, file system permissions problems and so on...).  So, my request is this: it would help a lot if Eclipse could mark a project in some way (maybe with a new icon or a new symbol over the existing icon) when that project has any build path problem that prevents it from being built.

So, my request is this: it would help a lot if Eclipse could mark a project in some way (maybe with a new icon or a new symbol over the existing icon) when that project has any build path problem that prevents it from being built. [render] Mark projects that have build path problems enhancement UI JDT

description: Using task editor context menu you can move the task to another category, but you can't remove it to no category.  This is particularly annoying if the task was just marked complete and you task list is filtering them. Since the only way to do it is from task list context menu, you have to copy to task id, paste them on find box, and them invoke "Remove from Category".
my_mothod: Using task editor context menu you can move the task to another category, but you can't remove it to no category.  This is particularly annoying if the task was just marked complete and you task list is filtering them. Since the only way to do it is from task list context menu, you have to copy to task id, paste them on find box, and them invoke "Remove from Category". Need a "Remove from Category" action in task editor context menu trivial UI Mylyn

description: N20080320-2000  I can't tell exactly what I did, but here are some hints: A backup was running in the bg, taking away much of the hard disk performance. I clicked into a breadcrumb dropdown button, and when the dropdown didn't show up after a second, I clicked again (a few times). In the end, the main thread was using most of the CPU and Eclipse only reacted on UI events after 20s or more.  The event loop in BreadcrumbItemDropDown.showMenu(BreadcrumbItemDropDown.java:340) looks suspicious. I guess it should include another break condition to ensure that showMenu(..) cannot be called recursively. description: We need to use the Progress Monitor capability during the report generation. The classes ReportEngine and UnAndRenderTask doesn't contain method to set  a IProgressMonitor object. Thanks.
my_mothod: We need to use the Progress Monitor capability during the report generation. The classes ReportEngine and UnAndRenderTask doesn't contain method to set  a IProgressMonitor object. Thanks. Take account the Eclipse Progress Monitor critical Report Engine BIRT

description: Our web application(Birt viewer) is based on eclipse Jetty and use axis to deploy web service. Now we are trying to depend on orbit axis plugin and not include axis related jars internally again.  After done test, we met a block issues as following: ClassNotFoundExcepiton occured when initialized AxisServlet. Our servlets extend the AxisServlet( this class extends HttpServlet ) and when try to register this servlet in Jetty plugin, it threw ClassNotFoundException. It seems axis plugin didn't import javax.servlet and javax.servlet.http package. After change MANIFEST.MF file in axis plugin to import these packages, this issue is gone.  Could you please add them in MANIFEST.MF? Thanks.
my_mothod: Our web application(Birt viewer) is based on eclipse Jetty and use axis to deploy web service. Now we are trying to depend on orbit axis plugin and not include axis related jars internally again.  After done test, we met a block issues as following: ClassNotFoundExcepiton occured when initialized AxisServlet. Our servlets extend the AxisServlet( this class extends HttpServlet ) and when try to register this servlet in Jetty plugin, it threw ClassNotFoundException. It seems axis plugin didn't import javax.servlet and javax.servlet.http package. After change MANIFEST.MF file in axis plugin to import these packages, this issue is gone.  Could you please add them in MANIFEST.MF? Thanks. HttpServlet ClassNotFoundException occured in axis plugin when try to register servlet using eclipse Jetty blocker bundles Orbit

description: Build ID: M20080221-1800  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create new Dynamic Web Project 2. Create new JSP File with Expression Language in it 3. add <%@ page isELIgnored="true" %> to the file 4. Now eclipse marks the isELIgnored attribute as 'Undefined attribute name', but it's an valid attribute and works on tomcat for me  More information: I think the attribute is just missing in the library.

description: Build ID: org.eclipse.uml2_2.2.0.v200803311230  Steps To Reproduce: the UML runtime feature dependencies on JDT core, Eclipse IDE, EMF Codegen, etc. and includes ecore importer, exporter and codegen plugins that are unnecessary for those clients that want only to use the EMF model and its associated edit code to manipulate UML models at runtime.  There needs to be a smaller feature that deploys only those portions of the UML API necessary for creating and manipulating instances of the EMF model and serializing/deserializing them, without the importer, exporter, editor, and codegen related plugins  More information:
my_mothod: Build ID: org.eclipse.uml2_2.2.0.v200803311230  Steps To Reproduce: the UML runtime feature dependencies on JDT core, Eclipse IDE, EMF Codegen, etc. and includes ecore importer, exporter and codegen plugins that are unnecessary for those clients that want only to use the EMF model and its associated edit code to manipulate UML models at runtime.  There needs to be a smaller feature that deploys only those portions of the UML API necessary for creating and manipulating instances of the EMF model and serializing/deserializing them, without the importer, exporter, editor, and codegen related plugins  More information: UML2 runtime feature has many dependencies and includes too many unnecessary plugins for clients wanting only to use UML API to create/manipulate UML models enhancement Core MDT.UML2

description: If anyone contributes a new mode like 'coverage' they need to subclass RelaunchLastAction to provide a menu item to relaunch the last item. It is already used by all the existing modes like run,debug,profile as RunLastAction, ProfileLastAction, DebugLastAction.  However since it is an internal class, other plugins cannot make use of it. It needs to be moved out for public access.
my_mothod: If anyone contributes a new mode like 'coverage' they need to subclass RelaunchLastAction to provide a menu item to relaunch the last item. It is already used by all the existing modes like run,debug,profile as RunLastAction, ProfileLastAction, DebugLastAction.  However since it is an internal class, other plugins cannot make use of it. It needs to be moved out for public access. [launch] RelaunchLastAction should *not* be internal enhancement Debug Platform

description: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29  Some sections of this doc explain the possible values for a particular eclipselink property by listing the static variable names of the corresponding eclipselink interface.  This is useful if you are adding the properties using toplink code, but not if you are defining them in the persistence.xml file where you would want the actual value String.  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29#How_to_Use_the_Persistence_Unit_Properties_for_Caching In this section it points to CacheType and gives the corresponding static strings.  In this case those static variable names also match the actual String value.  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29#Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_for_Schema_Generation In this section the actual values strings are listed, but the PersistenceUnitProperties interface is mentioned.  This led to much confusion on my part as to when the actual String was being mentioned in the docs and when the variable name for that string was being mentioned.    Some of this needs to be cleared up at the model level and then just reflected in the dcos.  I entered bug 228459 and bug 228456 for the underlying issues.
my_mothod: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29  Some sections of this doc explain the possible values for a particular eclipselink property by listing the static variable names of the corresponding eclipselink interface.  This is useful if you are adding the properties using toplink code, but not if you are defining them in the persistence.xml file where you would want the actual value String.  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29#How_to_Use_the_Persistence_Unit_Properties_for_Caching In this section it points to CacheType and gives the corresponding static strings.  In this case those static variable names also match the actual String value.  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_%28ELUG%29#Using_EclipseLink_JPA_Extensions_for_Schema_Generation In this section the actual values strings are listed, but the PersistenceUnitProperties interface is mentioned.  This led to much confusion on my part as to when the actual String was being mentioned in the docs and when the variable name for that string was being mentioned.    Some of this needs to be cleared up at the model level and then just reflected in the dcos.  I entered bug 228459 and bug 228456 for the underlying issues. inconsistencies in property name/value descriptions in the persistence.xml docs trivial Documentation EclipseLink

description: Build ID: I20080330-1350  I have a console pattern matcher with a IHyperlink.  Left clicking on a hyperlink in the console behaves as expected.  However, when I right click on a  hyperlink created and select "Open Link" nothing happens.  This is because the TextConsoleViewer receives a mouseExit call which in turn calls linkExited on the selected hyperlink before the hyperlink is activated.  Next the enablement of the action is checked and since TextConsoleViewer set the link to null, the action is not executed.  To fix this, I suggest populating FollowHyperlinkAction with the hyperlink to activate at creation.  The enablement could then be hyperlink != null.  FollowHyperLinkAction.java: public class FollowHyperlinkAction extends Action {  	private TextConsoleViewer viewer;         private IHyperLink hyperlink;      /** 	 * Constructs a follow link action 	 */ 	public FollowHyperlinkAction(TextConsoleViewer consoleViewer) { 	    super(ConsoleMessages.FollowHyperlinkAction_0);  		setToolTipText(ConsoleMessages.FollowHyperlinkAction_1);  		PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getHelpSystem().setHelp(this, IConsoleHelpContextIds.CONSOLE_OPEN_LINK_ACTION); 		this.viewer = consoleViewer;                 this.hyperlink = consoleViewer.getHyperLink(); 	}      /* (non-Javadoc)      * @see org.eclipse.jface.action.IAction#isEnabled()      */     public boolean isEnabled() {         return hyperlink != null;     } 	     /*      *  (non-Javadoc)      * @see org.eclipse.jface.action.IAction#run()      */ 	public void run() { 		if (hyperlink != null) { 			hyperlink .linkActivated(); 		} 	}  }
my_mothod: Build ID: I20080330-1350  I have a console pattern matcher with a IHyperlink.  Left clicking on a hyperlink in the console behaves as expected.  However, when I right click on a  hyperlink created and select "Open Link" nothing happens.  This is because the TextConsoleViewer receives a mouseExit call which in turn calls linkExited on the selected hyperlink before the hyperlink is activated.  Next the enablement of the action is checked and since TextConsoleViewer set the link to null, the action is not executed.  To fix this, I suggest populating FollowHyperlinkAction with the hyperlink to activate at creation.  The enablement could then be hyperlink != null.  FollowHyperLinkAction.java: public class FollowHyperlinkAction extends Action {  	private TextConsoleViewer viewer;         private IHyperLink hyperlink;      /** 	 * Constructs a follow link action 	 */ 	public FollowHyperlinkAction(TextConsoleViewer consoleViewer) { 	    super(ConsoleMessages.FollowHyperlinkAction_0);  		setToolTipText(ConsoleMessages.FollowHyperlinkAction_1);  		PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getHelpSystem().setHelp(this, IConsoleHelpContextIds.CONSOLE_OPEN_LINK_ACTION); 		this.viewer = consoleViewer;                 this.hyperlink = consoleViewer.getHyperLink(); 	}      /* (non-Javadoc)      * @see org.eclipse.jface.action.IAction#isEnabled()      */     public boolean isEnabled() {         return hyperlink != null;     } 	     /*      *  (non-Javadoc)      * @see org.eclipse.jface.action.IAction#run()      */ 	public void run() { 		if (hyperlink != null) { 			hyperlink .linkActivated(); 		} 	}  } [console] Open Link in Console Context Menu Gets Disabled When Activating normal Debug Platform

description: Originally - http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.tools.buckminster/msg00104.html  In the Eclipse STP build, I need to materialize two versions of the javax.wsdl plugin from Orbit - 1.5.1 for STP and 1.4.0 for parts of WTP upon which STP depends.  Watching the build log, I see:  [java] javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.5.0,1.6.0)#OSGi: Found match 1.5.1.v200803061910  a little later I see  [java] WARN:  Component request javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.5.0,1.6.0)#OSGi is inconflict with request javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.4.0,1.5.0)#OSGi  and finally, I get compilation failures in the STP code that uses javax.wsdl.  When I check the workspace/plugins, I see an exploded javax.wsdl directory, which contains the 1.4.0 jar only.  I'm using the eclipse.import reader to pull the orbit bundles map file.  Build system is at http://dev.eclipse.org/svnroot/stp/build/trunk/buckminster/ Short, and possibly incomplete, build instructions at http://wiki.eclipse.org/STP/Build/Build_101
my_mothod: Originally - http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.tools.buckminster/msg00104.html  In the Eclipse STP build, I need to materialize two versions of the javax.wsdl plugin from Orbit - 1.5.1 for STP and 1.4.0 for parts of WTP upon which STP depends.  Watching the build log, I see:  [java] javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.5.0,1.6.0)#OSGi: Found match 1.5.1.v200803061910  a little later I see  [java] WARN:  Component request javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.5.0,1.6.0)#OSGi is inconflict with request javax.wsdl:osgi.bundle/[1.4.0,1.5.0)#OSGi  and finally, I get compilation failures in the STP code that uses javax.wsdl.  When I check the workspace/plugins, I see an exploded javax.wsdl directory, which contains the 1.4.0 jar only.  I'm using the eclipse.import reader to pull the orbit bundles map file.  Build system is at http://dev.eclipse.org/svnroot/stp/build/trunk/buckminster/ Short, and possibly incomplete, build instructions at http://wiki.eclipse.org/STP/Build/Build_101 Buckminster has an unwanted limitation where it can only materialize one version of a plugin enhancement Buckminster z_Archived

description: It won't cause a problem for cross-project links precisely because a workspace-relative path includes the project name. For links from project-contained files to files outside the workspace (e.g. include files like LexerTemplate.gi), a filesystem-absolute path makes sense.  Luckily, one can distinguish between workspace-relative and filesystem-absolute paths by checking whether the path prefix matches the workspace location.  In the LPG IDE, we do have cross-file references, but we don't currently have cross-project references. That will almost certainly change once we improve the preferences support for LPG, since for language inheritance the derived grammar file needs to refer to the base grammar, which will probably be located in the base language plugin (in a separate project).
my_mothod: It won't cause a problem for cross-project links precisely because a workspace-relative path includes the project name. For links from project-contained files to files outside the workspace (e.g. include files like LexerTemplate.gi), a filesystem-absolute path makes sense.  Luckily, one can distinguish between workspace-relative and filesystem-absolute paths by checking whether the path prefix matches the workspace location.  In the LPG IDE, we do have cross-file references, but we don't currently have cross-project references. That will almost certainly change once we improve the preferences support for LPG, since for language inheritance the derived grammar file needs to refer to the base grammar, which will probably be located in the base language plugin (in a separate project). Hyperlinking in grammar files fails to find target file blocker IMP z_Archived

description: I was working on wizards and templates for the new tree model builder and label provider and testing the ability of these to support an outline view.  I got things to where the outline showed up properly but when I navigated from the outline into the text, only the text corresponding to the first token represented by the outline item was selected (e.g., only the opening brace of a block).  I traced the problem into the Node Locator:  the starting offset of the node is calculated as the starting offset of the left token (which seems right), but the ending offset of the node is calculated as the ending offset of the left token (rather than of the right token, which is what I would have expected).  Using the right token in the ending-offset case does indeed give you whole blocks, whole statements, and so on.  I would just go ahead and change the ending-offset calculation to refer to the right node, but I don't know how or why it may have been changed to the left node.  If I don't get any complaints about making the change I'll go ahead and do that.
my_mothod: I was working on wizards and templates for the new tree model builder and label provider and testing the ability of these to support an outline view.  I got things to where the outline showed up properly but when I navigated from the outline into the text, only the text corresponding to the first token represented by the outline item was selected (e.g., only the opening brace of a block).  I traced the problem into the Node Locator:  the starting offset of the node is calculated as the starting offset of the left token (which seems right), but the ending offset of the node is calculated as the ending offset of the left token (rather than of the right token, which is what I would have expected).  Using the right token in the ending-offset case does indeed give you whole blocks, whole statements, and so on.  I would just go ahead and change the ending-offset calculation to refer to the right node, but I don't know how or why it may have been changed to the left node.  If I don't get any complaints about making the change I'll go ahead and do that. ASTNodeLocator miscalculates end offsets (?) minor IMP z_Archived

description: Occasionally (maybe even very occasionally), when a source file is brought up  in an editor, the corresponding outline view does not appear.  I don't know  how long this has been a problem.  I've only noticed it recently when I've  been working with both source folding and outlining, and the problem may be  related to the combination of these services.  The problem is not language specific (I've noticed it at least for Jsdiv and  X10, and I should predict that it would occur for JikesPG as well).  It could  be related to recent changes in the outliner to address other problematic  interactions with the folding updater, but I don't think it relates to those  changes specifically.  It may relate just to the fact that there are  interactions between the folding updater and the outliner (changes in folding  trigger calls to update the outline).  In any case, before an outline tree is drawn, there are a number of conditions  that have to be satisfied:  parse controller is not null, outline tree is not  null, AST root is not null, no errors in the parse controller, and significant  changes to the AST.  If any of these is not satisfied, then the outline will  not be (re)drawn.  It may not be unusual to violate one or more of these  conditions.  For instance, when the source file is being edited, the AST will  be changing and the parse controller will often be in an erroneous state.  If one of these conditions is not satisfied at some time after the outline has  been drawn once, then it may not be obvious to the user that a failure to  redraw has occurred, since the previous outline will remain in the view.   However, if one of these conditions is not satisfied at the time the outline  would be drawn for the first time, then it will be obvious that drawing has  failed because no outline will appear.  I don't know why one of the conditions might not be satisfied on the initial  opening of an editor in a small percentage of cases, but a number of things  happen when an editor is opened, and I can imagine that some might sometimes  interfere with the drawing of an outline.  For instance, an initial set of  folding annotations has to be created, and perhaps some interaction between  the folding updater and outliner at startup may have an effect on some  occasions.  Anyway, the problem is not persistent in a session.  Some editing to the file,  or the folding or unfolding of a region of text, will triger a redrawing of  the outline, which will then appear and (apparently) operate normally from  that point forward.  I have tried tracking down more specific information about the conditions  under which the outline fails to appear, but it seems that the closer I look  the less frequently the problem happens.
my_mothod: Occasionally (maybe even very occasionally), when a source file is brought up  in an editor, the corresponding outline view does not appear.  I don't know  how long this has been a problem.  I've only noticed it recently when I've  been working with both source folding and outlining, and the problem may be  related to the combination of these services.  The problem is not language specific (I've noticed it at least for Jsdiv and  X10, and I should predict that it would occur for JikesPG as well).  It could  be related to recent changes in the outliner to address other problematic  interactions with the folding updater, but I don't think it relates to those  changes specifically.  It may relate just to the fact that there are  interactions between the folding updater and the outliner (changes in folding  trigger calls to update the outline).  In any case, before an outline tree is drawn, there are a number of conditions  that have to be satisfied:  parse controller is not null, outline tree is not  null, AST root is not null, no errors in the parse controller, and significant  changes to the AST.  If any of these is not satisfied, then the outline will  not be (re)drawn.  It may not be unusual to violate one or more of these  conditions.  For instance, when the source file is being edited, the AST will  be changing and the parse controller will often be in an erroneous state.  If one of these conditions is not satisfied at some time after the outline has  been drawn once, then it may not be obvious to the user that a failure to  redraw has occurred, since the previous outline will remain in the view.   However, if one of these conditions is not satisfied at the time the outline  would be drawn for the first time, then it will be obvious that drawing has  failed because no outline will appear.  I don't know why one of the conditions might not be satisfied on the initial  opening of an editor in a small percentage of cases, but a number of things  happen when an editor is opened, and I can imagine that some might sometimes  interfere with the drawing of an outline.  For instance, an initial set of  folding annotations has to be created, and perhaps some interaction between  the folding updater and outliner at startup may have an effect on some  occasions.  Anyway, the problem is not persistent in a session.  Some editing to the file,  or the folding or unfolding of a region of text, will triger a redrawing of  the outline, which will then appear and (apparently) operate normally from  that point forward.  I have tried tracking down more specific information about the conditions  under which the outline fails to appear, but it seems that the closer I look  the less frequently the problem happens. Outline views don't always appear when editor opens minor IMP z_Archived

description: Apparently some markers have no CHAR_START or CHAR_END attributes, causing NPEs in code that attempts to get their values.
my_mothod: Apparently some markers have no CHAR_START or CHAR_END attributes, causing NPEs in code that attempts to get their values. UniversalEditor.findParseAnnotationForMarker() causes NPEs minor IMP z_Archived

description: The UniversalEditor class has no removeModelListener() method corresponding to addModelListener(). As the result, there seems no way of uninstalling ModelListeners once installed.
my_mothod: The UniversalEditor class has no removeModelListener() method corresponding to addModelListener(). As the result, there seems no way of uninstalling ModelListeners once installed. UniversalEditor has no removeModelListener() minor IMP z_Archived

description: I created a new plug-in project named "TestLang" with target platform=3.1 and "Create an OSGi bundle manifest" option of the "New Plug-in Project" wizard  checked.  When I run the "Programing Language" wizard immedeatly after creation of the  project, it declared "singleton:=true" twice in Bundle-SymbolicName. This causes no build errors, but a warning.  It can be manually fixed by editing  MANIFEST.MF.  The contents of MANIFEST.MF before running the wizard was as follows: 	Manifest-Version: 1.0 	Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 	Bundle-Name: TestLang Plug-in 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang 	Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 	Bundle-Activator: testLang.TestLangPlugin 	Bundle-Localization: plugin 	Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui, 	 org.eclipse.core.runtime 	Eclipse-AutoStart: true and after the wizard run: 	Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui, 	 org.eclipse.core.runtime, 	 org.eclipse.core.resources, 	 org.eclipse.uide.runtime 	Bundle-Activator: testLang.TestLangPlugin 	Manifest-Version: 1.0 	Bundle-Name: TestLang Plug-in 	Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 	Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 	Eclipse-AutoStart: true 	Bundle-Localization: plugin 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true; singleton=true  I fixed the dup. manually, 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true and run the "JikesPG Grammar and Parser" wizard with all options kept default, then it reproduced the same dup. 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true; singleton=true  Probably, these wizards share the same code for modifying MANIFEST.MF?
my_mothod: I created a new plug-in project named "TestLang" with target platform=3.1 and "Create an OSGi bundle manifest" option of the "New Plug-in Project" wizard  checked.  When I run the "Programing Language" wizard immedeatly after creation of the  project, it declared "singleton:=true" twice in Bundle-SymbolicName. This causes no build errors, but a warning.  It can be manually fixed by editing  MANIFEST.MF.  The contents of MANIFEST.MF before running the wizard was as follows: 	Manifest-Version: 1.0 	Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 	Bundle-Name: TestLang Plug-in 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang 	Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 	Bundle-Activator: testLang.TestLangPlugin 	Bundle-Localization: plugin 	Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui, 	 org.eclipse.core.runtime 	Eclipse-AutoStart: true and after the wizard run: 	Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui, 	 org.eclipse.core.runtime, 	 org.eclipse.core.resources, 	 org.eclipse.uide.runtime 	Bundle-Activator: testLang.TestLangPlugin 	Manifest-Version: 1.0 	Bundle-Name: TestLang Plug-in 	Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 	Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 	Eclipse-AutoStart: true 	Bundle-Localization: plugin 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true; singleton=true  I fixed the dup. manually, 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true and run the "JikesPG Grammar and Parser" wizard with all options kept default, then it reproduced the same dup. 	Bundle-SymbolicName: TestLang; singleton:=true; singleton=true  Probably, these wizards share the same code for modifying MANIFEST.MF? "New Programing Language" and "JikesPG" wizards make duplicated declaration in MANIFEST.MF trivial IMP z_Archived

description: This can happen if one:   1) deletes files/folders from the Package Explorer when SAFARI editors are open on those files being deleted, and  2) Eclipse is restarted without first closing these editors.  Perhaps UniversalEditor should listen for resource changes to detect that it's editing a file that got deleted.
my_mothod: This can happen if one:   1) deletes files/folders from the Package Explorer when SAFARI editors are open on those files being deleted, and  2) Eclipse is restarted without first closing these editors.  Perhaps UniversalEditor should listen for resource changes to detect that it's editing a file that got deleted. UniversalEditor et al. throws exception when asked to open a non-existent file minor IMP z_Archived

description: When a language _begining with a capital letter_, say "MyLang", is defined via  the language descriptor wizard, two packages are generated: "MyLang" and  "MyLang.preferences".  On defining a parsing service, however, the Parser wizard proposes, as the  default package name for parser classes, "myLang.safari.parser", i.e. the first  char of the package name is lowerCase()'ed. Following this default proposal results in failure of auto-generating package/ sources, with the error "Could not add extension points" whose stack trace is: org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: A resource exists with a  different case: /LatexMath/src/TypeDecl. 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource. checkDoesNotExist(Resource.java:274) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder. assertCreateRequirements(Folder.java:27) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:90) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:121) 	at org.eclipse.uide.wizards.ExtensionPointWizard. createSubFolders(ExtensionPointWizard.java:296) ...  This error can be avoided by manually fixing the package name on the wizard.
my_mothod: When a language _begining with a capital letter_, say "MyLang", is defined via  the language descriptor wizard, two packages are generated: "MyLang" and  "MyLang.preferences".  On defining a parsing service, however, the Parser wizard proposes, as the  default package name for parser classes, "myLang.safari.parser", i.e. the first  char of the package name is lowerCase()'ed. Following this default proposal results in failure of auto-generating package/ sources, with the error "Could not add extension points" whose stack trace is: org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: A resource exists with a  different case: /LatexMath/src/TypeDecl. 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource. checkDoesNotExist(Resource.java:274) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder. assertCreateRequirements(Folder.java:27) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:90) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:121) 	at org.eclipse.uide.wizards.ExtensionPointWizard. createSubFolders(ExtensionPointWizard.java:296) ...  This error can be avoided by manually fixing the package name on the wizard. Default package name mismatch between Language wizard and Parser Wizard minor IMP z_Archived

description: and do the same for any similarly named related units.  As has been long recognized, this class really addresses the enablement of extensions, not extension points.  Priority is not too high, since it all works as named; it's just confusing if you don't know what's going on (and a little embarassing for us if you do).

Priority is not too high, since it all works as named; it's just confusing if you don't know what's going on (and a little embarassing for us if you do). description: If you run a wizard on one IDE project to create a new service, then select another IDE project and run a wizard on that project, the wizard comes up with the project field set to the initial project, not the newly selected one.  I think that if a project is selected then it should have priority over the previously access project (unless, perhaps, the newly selected project is not one for which a language is defined).
my_mothod: If you run a wizard on one IDE project to create a new service, then select another IDE project and run a wizard on that project, the wizard comes up with the project field set to the initial project, not the newly selected one.  I think that if a project is selected then it should have priority over the previously access project (unless, perhaps, the newly selected project is not one for which a language is defined). New service wizards not sensitive to change in selected project minor IMP z_Archived

description: It's not currently being used by anything. Since the meta-data available on Language is pretty scant, it's not clear that this API method could ever do anything other than giving the moral equivalent of an "instanceof" test for service implementations.  Further, if there's a case for a given (nominally language-specific) service implementation to have to be told what language it's processing, let's introduce appropriate API elsewhere to provide the necessary processing hooks that it can call, rather than having the service implementation contain code like    if (fLanguage.getName().equals("java")) {       // do java-specific stuff   } else {       // ...   }
my_mothod: It's not currently being used by anything. Since the meta-data available on Language is pretty scant, it's not clear that this API method could ever do anything other than giving the moral equivalent of an "instanceof" test for service implementations.  Further, if there's a case for a given (nominally language-specific) service implementation to have to be told what language it's processing, let's introduce appropriate API elsewhere to provide the necessary processing hooks that it can call, rather than having the service implementation contain code like    if (fLanguage.getName().equals("java")) {       // do java-specific stuff   } else {       // ...   } Remove ILanguageService.setLanguage() from API minor IMP z_Archived

description: In the method  public void endVisit(functionCall n) {     String funcName= n.getidentifier().toString();     functionDeclaration func=         (functionDeclaration) innerScope.findDeclaration(funcName);     int numArgs= func.getfunctionHeader().getparameters().size();  it is assumed that the declaration returned will be a functionDeclaration. That seems reasonable, but in some cases it turns out that the declaration is a functionHeader, leading to a ClassCastException.  The fix should be straightforward, i.e., to compute numArgs based on the type of declaration.
my_mothod: In the method  public void endVisit(functionCall n) {     String funcName= n.getidentifier().toString();     functionDeclaration func=         (functionDeclaration) innerScope.findDeclaration(funcName);     int numArgs= func.getfunctionHeader().getparameters().size();  it is assumed that the declaration returned will be a functionDeclaration. That seems reasonable, but in some cases it turns out that the declaration is a functionHeader, leading to a ClassCastException.  The fix should be straightforward, i.e., to compute numArgs based on the type of declaration. ClassCastException in LegCompiler (bug in compiler.java template) blocker IMP z_Archived

description: When you try to set a breakpoint in a SAFARI editor, say using Shift-Ctrl B, you get a null pointer exception in UniversalEditor. findParseAnnotationForMarker(..), which starts around line 737.  The exception comes up because CHAR_START and CHAR_END attributes are not defined for the marker (but are referenced to get their values).  We weren't seeing the exception before because there was a handler for CoreException (needed for working with Markers) but not for any other exceptions.  I'm not sure what causes the NPE or how to fix it, but I put in a handler for it, so now it's at least trapped, which helps some later code to behave more normally.  This was discovered in trying to address bug #147.
my_mothod: When you try to set a breakpoint in a SAFARI editor, say using Shift-Ctrl B, you get a null pointer exception in UniversalEditor. findParseAnnotationForMarker(..), which starts around line 737.  The exception comes up because CHAR_START and CHAR_END attributes are not defined for the marker (but are referenced to get their values).  We weren't seeing the exception before because there was a handler for CoreException (needed for working with Markers) but not for any other exceptions.  I'm not sure what causes the NPE or how to fix it, but I put in a handler for it, so now it's at least trapped, which helps some later code to behave more normally.  This was discovered in trying to address bug #147. NPE in UniversalEditor when creating breakpoints blocker IMP z_Archived

description: The NewCompiler wizard was failing to make AST-related substitutions in the compiler template.  The problem turned out to be that the substitution values were found through the "parser" extension.  However, when the new grammar/parser wizards were revamped recently, a new extension point was put into use that was more appropriately named "parserWrapper."  GeneratedComponentServiceWizard and NewCompiler needed to be updated to account for this new extension-point name. For backwards compatibility, these wizards will also continue to check for extensions with the "parser" name.
my_mothod: The NewCompiler wizard was failing to make AST-related substitutions in the compiler template.  The problem turned out to be that the substitution values were found through the "parser" extension.  However, when the new grammar/parser wizards were revamped recently, a new extension point was put into use that was more appropriately named "parserWrapper."  GeneratedComponentServiceWizard and NewCompiler needed to be updated to account for this new extension-point name. For backwards compatibility, these wizards will also continue to check for extensions with the "parser" name. NewCompiler wizard fails to make appropriate substitutions into template critical IMP z_Archived

description: The dialog that we use in our wizards for selecting a project is a ContainerSelectionDialog, which allows tree navigation from projects into all of their contained elements (and so on recursively).  We don't really need all of that for selecting a project--we just need a list of projects.  I'm not sure yet whether there are other places where this dialog is used when a more selective dialog might be more appropriate (but I wouldn't be surprised if there were).  I'm giving this a relatively low priority and severity since we've evidently lived with this for many months and it's never bothered us, any of our users, or anyone to whom we've shown a demo (insofar as I know).  Still, we could put a better face on things.

We don't really need all of that for selecting a project--we just need a list of projects. I'm giving this a relatively low priority and severity since we've evidently lived with this for many months and it's never bothered us, any of our users, or anyone to whom we've shown a demo (insofar as I know).  Still, we could put a better face on things. ContainerSelectionDialog used for selecting projects minor IMP z_Archived

description: Practically all of our wizards have a "class" field that has both a Class Browse button and a label hyperlink that brings up the New Class wizard.  We have a few wizards that have fields that have browse buttons for things other than classes, such as for projects, packages, and files (the New Preferences wizard is one of these).  The problem is that the labels for these fields also get created with hyperlinks to the New Class Wizard.

We have a few wizards that have fields that have browse buttons for things other than classes, such as for projects, packages, and files (the New Preferences wizard is one of these).  The problem is that the labels for these fields also get created with hyperlinks to the New Class Wizard. Class hyperlinks appear for non-class wizard fields minor IMP z_Archived

description: The backgrounds of the other label fields (the large majority anyway) are the same as the background color of the wizard, so the backgrounds of these labels are not being set properly.  The labels of the "class" fields are actually hyperlinks, so they are created by a mechanism other than the one used for labels for other sorts of fields.  Also, as you would expect in this case, the problem applies not just to the standard "class" field that most of our wizards have, but also to other fields that represent classes that also have hyperlinks for labels (regardless of their names).
my_mothod: The backgrounds of the other label fields (the large majority anyway) are the same as the background color of the wizard, so the backgrounds of these labels are not being set properly.  The labels of the "class" fields are actually hyperlinks, so they are created by a mechanism other than the one used for labels for other sorts of fields.  Also, as you would expect in this case, the problem applies not just to the standard "class" field that most of our wizards have, but also to other fields that represent classes that also have hyperlinks for labels (regardless of their names). "Class" field labels on wizards have white backgrounds minor IMP z_Archived

description: Created attachment 99376 dead lock stack traces  This deadlock was found while trying to debug bug 228750. description: Right now only the top level of the javadoc you've contributed is visible in the infocenter - this unfortunately means that the content you've contributed is pretty much unsearchable.  This is because the plugin.xml file must list all table of contents (TOC) files as extensions of org.eclipse.help.toc or it just thinks they're random xml. Once those are listed I'm 99% sure that your docs will apear as they're supposed to. I'm appending patches with the fixes (since it's partially my fault for not mentioning this in the first place), but I'd appreciate if you'd test them locally first.

Javadoc contents not searchable - plugin.xml needs all TOCs listed major documentation Web Tools

description: Build ID: 3.4 m6  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Within an Eclipse Help system running in infocenter mode, use the ?topic= parameter on the URL to specify a fully specified URL to another site. e.g.  http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wpdoc/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=http://www.google.com 2. 3.   More information: The topic parameter on the URL is vulnerable to exploitation and *is* being used to deliver spam and potentially more harmful code while making it appear that the information center being hosted is the source of the material.  Instances of this exploitation have been found out in the 'wild'.  It will pull in content from whatever URL you add on the end there and embeds it into content pane in the infocenter. This can be used to deliver malware and spyware to unsuspecting victims,  making them think they are clicking on a legitimate link within that infocenter.  Suggested fix would be to not allow URLs outside the current domain within the topic param.  Additionally, to allow more flexibility, make that level of security a configurable startup option to the help system.  Final note, this bug has been found in EHS 3.1, 3.2, and 3.4m6
my_mothod: Build ID: 3.4 m6  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Within an Eclipse Help system running in infocenter mode, use the ?topic= parameter on the URL to specify a fully specified URL to another site. e.g.  http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wpdoc/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=http://www.google.com 2. 3.   More information: The topic parameter on the URL is vulnerable to exploitation and *is* being used to deliver spam and potentially more harmful code while making it appear that the information center being hosted is the source of the material.  Instances of this exploitation have been found out in the 'wild'.  It will pull in content from whatever URL you add on the end there and embeds it into content pane in the infocenter. This can be used to deliver malware and spyware to unsuspecting victims,  making them think they are clicking on a legitimate link within that infocenter.  Suggested fix would be to not allow URLs outside the current domain within the topic param.  Additionally, to allow more flexibility, make that level of security a configurable startup option to the help system.  Final note, this bug has been found in EHS 3.1, 3.2, and 3.4m6 [Webapp][Security] Site redirection vulnerability in Eclipse Help System major User Assistance Platform

description: We would like to be able to start the COSMOSUI and immediately execute a graphQuery on an MDR.  The COSMOS UI URL needs to support additional parameters to specify the name of the MDR and a graphQuery request. For example:  http://localhost:8080/COSMOSUI/?page=cosmos;mdr=ExampleMDR;graphquery=<...>  This URL would open the COSMOS UI, execute the graphQuery on the MDR and display the query result.
