description: The EMF Model Validation framework should define an Ecore model of the meta-data required by the framework for the definition of constraints.  This would capture, basically, the information defined for the default plugin.xml-based provider's extension-point schema.  The advantages are:    - removing the burden of large plugin.xml content from the     Eclipse extension registry   - modeling your data is always a good thing  :-)  The     generated editor is easy to use, and potentially even     a graphical editor (GMF-based) could be provided by the     SDK   - access to constraints defined in EMF resources, anywhere     that EMF can find them:  plug-in contents, HTTP on the     web, repositories via CDO/JCRM, etc.
my_mothod: The EMF Model Validation framework should define an Ecore model of the meta-data required by the framework for the definition of constraints.  This would capture, basically, the information defined for the default plugin.xml-based provider's extension-point schema.  The advantages are:    - removing the burden of large plugin.xml content from the     Eclipse extension registry   - modeling your data is always a good thing  :-)  The     generated editor is easy to use, and potentially even     a graphical editor (GMF-based) could be provided by the     SDK   - access to constraints defined in EMF resources, anywhere     that EMF can find them:  plug-in contents, HTTP on the     web, repositories via CDO/JCRM, etc. Constraint provider based on Ecore model of constraint meta-data enhancement Validation EMF Services

description: Build ID: wtp 3.0x  Steps To Reproduce: Right click on a server in the server view.  It will bring up the Add and Remove Project wizard.  Our server doesn't support adding loose modules like web and EJB modules except EAR to the server.  In previous release, when any modules inside and EAR is selected, the Add button is disabled.  However, in the current release, the button is not disabled and modules like EJB, WEB can be added to the right side of the table.  I think this isn't the correct behaviour.   More information:  My ref:00313564

description: Code completion (Ctrl-Space) is currently single-threaded, and blocks the UI thread, which is inconvenient:  1) when project is large  2) when certain computations take considerably more time than other (e.g. completing "public" is always cheap, whereas completing to class names requires the indexes to be happy, etc).  This applies to some other languages as well, such as C++.  We (Zorzella and Douglas Pollock) have put together a small patch, which is an attempt to show how this might be done.  We have tried, where possible, to be completely backward compatible. However, we are aware of two cases where we have not initially made it to be backward compatible. First of all, we have changed the interface of IJavaCompletionProposalComputer to allow its implementors to run in the background. Also, we have changed the contract of CompletionProposalCategory. Now, categories from the extension point must expect that they might be run in the background. We have a few ideas on how to work around these issues (without changing the public APIs), but we wanted to show a simpler patch first.  Since the processing does not happen in the UI thread anymore, it was necessary to change several places that wanted to calculate the selected range. What we do now is to pass the "selectedRange" around as a parameter, which seems better anyway. This is responsible for a lot of "noise" in the patch. This is also responsible for the change to the IJavaCompletionProposalComputer interface (some places may eventually be simplified, since they continue on passing the offset as well as the selectedRange, which is now redundant).  The basic principle is to change the way in which ContentAssistProcessors returned information about which completions were possible. In the old model, these implemented computeCompletionProposals, which returned an array or ICompletionProposal. In the new model, the same method (defined in ICompletionProposal2 for backwards-compat) is "void", and it receives a ProposalList, which is an object that accepts new ICompletionProposals to be added to it.  This ProposalList interface is implemented by two classes (again, for backwards-compat). The fancy implementation of this interface -- DefaultProposalList (currently a private inner class of CompletionProposalPopup) -- is where the "meat" of this patch is.  What it is is a call back. As different threads (as many as we want) find more valid completions, they add to this data structure. This, in turn, periodically (for perf reasons) updates the UI (calling the "old" setProposals) with its current state. It also knows (with the help of ICompletionProposal2) how to sort the entries it receives, so it is *always* in a consistent state. It abstracts (handles) filtering, which used to be special-cased.  In terms of threading (and yes, we could convert this to jobs), there are two levels to the hierarchy of threads.  Immediately on code complete trigger, a background thread is launched to gather data.  After this is started, detached from the UI, it is also free to create multiple other threads, as desired. In fact, this implementation creates a thread per potential computer, and then executes all the computers in parallel.  The parallel execution of computers can be seen in ContentAssistProcessor. One thing not done (but supported) in this patch is to extend the use of the ProposalList deeper, so that *each* entry is calculated to be valid (within a single computer), it can be displayed immediately in the UI.  Issues (other than breaking the public APIs).  1) Cycling between types of completions (java, template, SWT, etc) does not currently work  2) Always need to ESC to kill the completion popup (even when backspacing to empty)  3) If there is only a single completion, we do not auto-complete  4) we lack some polishing, e.g. an "in progress" message  5) We don't have support for proposals that aren't ICompletionProposalExtension (or Extension2)s  6) CompletionProposalPopup.fMessageText becomes corrupted in a particular code path
my_mothod: Code completion (Ctrl-Space) is currently single-threaded, and blocks the UI thread, which is inconvenient:  1) when project is large  2) when certain computations take considerably more time than other (e.g. completing "public" is always cheap, whereas completing to class names requires the indexes to be happy, etc).  This applies to some other languages as well, such as C++.  We (Zorzella and Douglas Pollock) have put together a small patch, which is an attempt to show how this might be done. First of all, we have changed the interface of IJavaCompletionProposalComputer to allow its implementors to run in the background. Also, we have changed the contract of CompletionProposalCategory. Now, categories from the extension point must expect that they might be run in the background. We have a few ideas on how to work around these issues (without changing the public APIs), but we wanted to show a simpler patch first.  Since the processing does not happen in the UI thread anymore, it was necessary to change several places that wanted to calculate the selected range. What we do now is to pass the "selectedRange" around as a parameter, which seems better anyway. This is responsible for a lot of "noise" in the patch. This is also responsible for the change to the IJavaCompletionProposalComputer interface (some places may eventually be simplified, since they continue on passing the offset as well as the selectedRange, which is now redundant). This ProposalList interface is implemented by two classes (again, for backwards-compat). The fancy implementation of this interface -- DefaultProposalList (currently a private inner class of CompletionProposalPopup) -- is where the "meat" of this patch is.  What it is is a call back. As different threads (as many as we want) find more valid completions, they add to this data structure. This, in turn, periodically (for perf reasons) updates the UI (calling the "old" setProposals) with its current state. It also knows (with the help of ICompletionProposal2) how to sort the entries it receives, so it is *always* in a consistent state. It abstracts (handles) filtering, which used to be special-cased.  In terms of threading (and yes, we could convert this to jobs), there are two levels to the hierarchy of threads. One thing not done (but supported) in this patch is to extend the use of the ProposalList deeper, so that *each* entry is calculated to be valid (within a single computer), it can be displayed immediately in the UI.  Issues (other than breaking the public APIs).  1) Cycling between types of completions (java, template, SWT, etc) does not currently work  2) Always need to ESC to kill the completion popup (even when backspacing to empty)  3) If there is only a single completion, we do not auto-complete  4) we lack some polishing, e.g. an "in progress" message  5) We don't have support for proposals that aren't ICompletionProposalExtension (or Extension2)s  6) CompletionProposalPopup.fMessageText becomes corrupted in a particular code path [content assist] Asynchronous code completion [with patch] enhancement Text Platform

description: Build ID: M20080221-1800  Steps To Reproduce: Cannot really reproduce this with Eclipse or the JDT itself, so I will explain it.  The DetailJob has been changed to add a 30 second timeout to the wait to prevent an infinite wait and allow the job to be cancelled.   It now calls wait(30000) when it used to call wait().  Our debugger code that implemented the computeDetail method did not process the value on a separate thread, but instead computed it immediately and notified the listener before returning.   After returning, the wait(30000) is then executed and since the listener already did the notifyAll, then it must wait for the 30 seconds to elapse.  Apparently the wait() function behaves a little different and works whether the notifyAll was executed before or after the wait.   The wait with a timeout apparently ignores the notifyAll executed before the wait.  I believe the code needs to be changed to check the fComputed status prior to executing the wait(30000).   That way if an implementation has already computed the value then it will not wait unnecessarily.  NOTE: Working around this was easy, we simply modified our code to execute the computeDetail on another thread as intended, so this is a low priority for us.  More information:
my_mothod: Build ID: M20080221-1800  Steps To Reproduce: Cannot really reproduce this with Eclipse or the JDT itself, so I will explain it.  The DetailJob has been changed to add a 30 second timeout to the wait to prevent an infinite wait and allow the job to be cancelled.   It now calls wait(30000) when it used to call wait().  Our debugger code that implemented the computeDetail method did not process the value on a separate thread, but instead computed it immediately and notified the listener before returning.   After returning, the wait(30000) is then executed and since the listener already did the notifyAll, then it must wait for the 30 seconds to elapse.  Apparently the wait() function behaves a little different and works whether the notifyAll was executed before or after the wait.   The wait with a timeout apparently ignores the notifyAll executed before the wait.  I believe the code needs to be changed to check the fComputed status prior to executing the wait(30000).   That way if an implementation has already computed the value then it will not wait unnecessarily.  NOTE: Working around this was easy, we simply modified our code to execute the computeDetail on another thread as intended, so this is a low priority for us.  More information: [detail] DefaultDetailPane$DetailJob run method can unnecessarily wait for 30 seconds before displaying variable value minor Debug Platform

description: With the JIRA connector moving to Atlassian the only feature remaining on the extras update site is the Trac connector. Trac is a committer supported component that satisfies the requirements listed under http://wiki.eclipse.org/Mylyn_Contributor_Reference#Main therefore I propose that Trac is moved to the main update site instead of maintaining a separate site for the sole purpose of distributing a single feature.  As part of this we can consider changing the requirement that all features on the main update site are contributed to the Eclipse release train but I am confident that the Trac connector is sufficiently mature to be hosted on the Helios update site.  Please comment here if there are any concerns with moving the Trac connector to the main update site and into Helios.
my_mothod: With the JIRA connector moving to Atlassian the only feature remaining on the extras update site is the Trac connector. Trac is a committer supported component that satisfies the requirements listed under http://wiki.eclipse.org/Mylyn_Contributor_Reference#Main therefore I propose that Trac is moved to the main update site instead of maintaining a separate site for the sole purpose of distributing a single feature.  As part of this we can consider changing the requirement that all features on the main update site are contributed to the Eclipse release train but I am confident that the Trac connector is sufficiently mature to be hosted on the Helios update site.  Please comment here if there are any concerns with moving the Trac connector to the main update site and into Helios. [releng] remove extras update site trivial Core Mylyn

description: Prior to r11456, the buckminster.build.timestamp was supposed to be in ISO-8601 format (as documented). However, now the format needs to be one of the common formats:  public static final String[] commonFormats = new String[] { "yyyy-MM-dd_HH-mm-ss", "yyyyMMddHHmm", "yyyyMMdd-HHmm", "yyyyMMdd" }; //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$  Note the difference is in one line -- the new code calls timestamp = DateAndTimeUtils.fromString((String) isoTS); while the old code called timestamp = DateAndTimeUtils.fromISOFormat((String) isoTS);
my_mothod: Prior to r11456, the buckminster.build.timestamp was supposed to be in ISO-8601 format (as documented). However, now the format needs to be one of the common formats:  public static final String[] commonFormats = new String[] { "yyyy-MM-dd_HH-mm-ss", "yyyyMMddHHmm", "yyyyMMdd-HHmm", "yyyyMMdd" }; //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$  Note the difference is in one line -- the new code calls timestamp = DateAndTimeUtils.fromString((String) isoTS); while the old code called timestamp = DateAndTimeUtils.fromISOFormat((String) isoTS); Property buckminster.build.timestamp no longer ISO-8601 normal Buckminster z_Archived

description: The XPlanner connector has been part of the Mylyn incubator for several years and is currently not actively maintained. Over the lifetime of the connector we have only received a handful of user bug reports or enhancements requests. There has been no activity for several month now. Furthermore, the last release of XPlanner was in 2006 and the SourceForge project shows no recent activity.  Since there is no indication of community interest in the XPlanner connector and there are no plans to graduate the component in the Mylyn project I believe it would be best to archive it and remove it from the incubator update site. Currently the cost of maintaining the sources and build is much higher than the benefit provided by the connector.
my_mothod: The XPlanner connector has been part of the Mylyn incubator for several years and is currently not actively maintained. Over the lifetime of the connector we have only received a handful of user bug reports or enhancements requests. There has been no activity for several month now. Furthermore, the last release of XPlanner was in 2006 and the SourceForge project shows no recent activity.  Since there is no indication of community interest in the XPlanner connector and there are no plans to graduate the component in the Mylyn project I believe it would be best to archive it and remove it from the incubator update site. Currently the cost of maintaining the sources and build is much higher than the benefit provided by the connector. [releng] archive XPlanner connector trivial Releng Mylyn

description: Build Identifier:  20100617-1415  For accessibility and general usability reasons, I wish to map some keys to handle "move row" on the grid. The grid uses "UP/DOWN" with CTRL or SHIFT to do select and focus operations, and the plain keys (without modifiers) to do traversal. Since the ALT+UP/DOWN keys are unused by the grid, I thought I'd use these.    Alas, the way that the grid listens to key events prevents this; it does special handling of both CTRL and SHIFT, and defaults to "traversal". I can add the key listener and have it do what I want, but cannot prevent the traversal operation. Also, since the Grid gets notified first, I cannot "consume" the event by setting "KeyEvent.doit" to false. I can get the desired behavior by using other keys (e.g. ALT+NUMPAD_8 and ALT+NUMPAD_2).  The problem seems to be located to org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.onKeyDown(Event), where the UP/DOWN key behaves the same way whether or not the ALT (MOD3) key is used.   I can see two solutions: a) make org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.onKeyDown(Event) ignore keys if an undefined modifier (such as MOD3) is used b) make Grid consume key events last in chain, allowing externally added listeners to prevent grid default actions by setting 'KeyEvent.doit=false'   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Grid myGrid = new Grid(....) 2. myGrid.addKeyListener(new KeyListener(...) {    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e):         switch (e.keyCode) {        case SWT.ARROW_UP:            if ((e.stateMask & SWT.ALT) != 0) {                doMyStuffInsteadOfTraversing();                e.doit = false;            } 	break; <snip>
my_mothod: Build Identifier:  20100617-1415  For accessibility and general usability reasons, I wish to map some keys to handle "move row" on the grid. The grid uses "UP/DOWN" with CTRL or SHIFT to do select and focus operations, and the plain keys (without modifiers) to do traversal. Since the ALT+UP/DOWN keys are unused by the grid, I thought I'd use these.    Alas, the way that the grid listens to key events prevents this; it does special handling of both CTRL and SHIFT, and defaults to "traversal". I can add the key listener and have it do what I want, but cannot prevent the traversal operation. Also, since the Grid gets notified first, I cannot "consume" the event by setting "KeyEvent.doit" to false. I can get the desired behavior by using other keys (e.g. ALT+NUMPAD_8 and ALT+NUMPAD_2).  The problem seems to be located to org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.onKeyDown(Event), where the UP/DOWN key behaves the same way whether or not the ALT (MOD3) key is used.   I can see two solutions: a) make org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.onKeyDown(Event) ignore keys if an undefined modifier (such as MOD3) is used b) make Grid consume key events last in chain, allowing externally added listeners to prevent grid default actions by setting 'KeyEvent.doit=false'   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Grid myGrid = new Grid(....) 2. myGrid.addKeyListener(new KeyListener(...) {    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e):         switch (e.keyCode) {        case SWT.ARROW_UP:            if ((e.stateMask & SWT.ALT) != 0) {                doMyStuffInsteadOfTraversing();                e.doit = false;            } 	break; <snip> Grid consumes all "arrow" keys minor Grid Nebula

description: The indigo repository for M3 (indigo/201011120900) only includes one version of org.eclipse.jdt.core, whereas the features listed in the repo require two versions. Indeed org.eclipse.jdt.feature.group requires org.eclipse.jdt.core 3.7.0.v_B22, and org.eclipse.objectteams.otdt.core.patch.feature.group requires 3.7.0.v_OTDT_r080_201011100445.  I suppose that the problem is caused by the fact that the object team feature is a patch and that the aggregator does a complete dependency resolution which takes the original jdt.core out of the result.
my_mothod: The indigo repository for M3 (indigo/201011120900) only includes one version of org.eclipse.jdt.core, whereas the features listed in the repo require two versions. Indeed org.eclipse.jdt.feature.group requires org.eclipse.jdt.core 3.7.0.v_B22, and org.eclipse.objectteams.otdt.core.patch.feature.group requires 3.7.0.v_OTDT_r080_201011100445.  I suppose that the problem is caused by the fact that the object team feature is a patch and that the aggregator does a complete dependency resolution which takes the original jdt.core out of the result. Indigo repository does not include all the versions of jdt.core critical CBI p2 Repository Aggregator CBI

description: As documented at http://wiki.eclipse.org/Mylyn_Integrator_Reference#Deciding_on_a_version Mylyn 3.6 which is part of Indigo and all 3.6.x service releases will be the last Mylyn versions with support for Eclipse 3.5 (in addition to supporting Eclipse 3.6 and 3.7).  The upcoming Mylyn 3.7 release will support Eclipse 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8 (latest milestone).   Please comment on this bug if there are any concerns with ending support for Eclipse 3.5 (also see bug 280832 and bug 313436 for more background on Mylyn's support for different Eclipse versions).

description: CQ:WIND00253872 Build ID: TM 3.3  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open the terminal view (Window > Show View > Terminal). 2. Press the "Connection Properties" buttons and pick Telnet connection. 3. Enter a host name, and 77777 as the port number. Press OK. 4. The dialog says the settings are wrong without mentioning what is wrong.  The problem as per a TODO comment in the header of ISettingsPage.java -- the ISettingsPage doesn't provide API for settings implementations to give an error string when validation fails.   It may be possible for each SettingsPage to use an error indicator on a Field that has a wrong value... but that would require each settingsPage to code the respective UI work, rather than just returning a common error text similar to existing Eclipse Wizard framework.
my_mothod: CQ:WIND00253872 Build ID: TM 3.3  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open the terminal view (Window > Show View > Terminal). 2. Press the "Connection Properties" buttons and pick Telnet connection. 3. The problem as per a TODO comment in the header of ISettingsPage.java -- the ISettingsPage doesn't provide API for settings implementations to give an error string when validation fails.   It may be possible for each SettingsPage to use an error indicator on a Field that has a wrong value... but that would require each settingsPage to code the respective UI work, rather than just returning a common error text similar to existing Eclipse Wizard framework. [terminal][api] In case of an error on a terminal settings page, no indication is given what's wrong minor Terminal Target Management

description: It appears some connectors are not always returning taskID when asked for (e.g. JIRA in connector.getTaskIdFromUrl, returning key). The documentation of the API should clearly indicate what the difference is, so connectors return the correct value.  While in Mylyn, returning key for this method might (most of the time, always?) work, other systems relying on that API might not be so forgiving, so the framework should do it's best to help connector implementations do the right thing.

description: org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.batch.source_3.7.0.I20120409-0926.jar org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.batch_3.7.0.I20120409-0926.jar  org.aspectj.weaver_1.6.7.20091231194938.jar org.aspectj.runtime_1.6.7.20091231194938.jar  These are 4 bundles unsigned by the Eclipse Project. I just wanted to document, and document the reasons.   The first two, I've raised before, and was told "oh, too much trouble and not really needed since just used by 'runtimes' (not IDE)"   Well ... if its just a matter of "trouble", might be easier now on build.eclipse.org?  But, if purposely desired not to be signed for technical reasons, then we should probably document those reasons better.   The second two, I'm assuming are intentional? And, similarly, if purposely avoided for technical reasons we should document why?    (sorry, if this is covered elsewhere ... I just wanted to capture in a bugzilla so I wouldn't forget ... not urgent).

And, similarly, if purposely avoided for technical reasons we should document why?    (sorry, if this is covered elsewhere ... description: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #396822 +++  CQ:WIND00394839 Build ID: CDT 8.1.1 Juno on top of Eclipse SDK 3.8.1  When I right-click a project for the first time in our commercial product on top of the CDT, I find the following error logged:  Error instantiating adapter factory for "org.eclipse.core.resources.IResource" declared by "org.eclipse.cdt.debug.ui".  Investigation showed that while logging of the error is not ideal (to be fixed in Eclipse Platform through bug 396822 and/or CDT through bug 398136), the reason for the log entry is in TCF.  This was fixed in the tcf-1.0 and tcf-master Streams with build #282 on Dec 20:  https://git.eclipse.org/c/tcf/org.eclipse.tcf.git/commit/?h=1.0&id=8759e8304d98200d1192f52fcd516f8d4a37c6ff  https://hudson.eclipse.org/hudson/job/tcf-1.0/282/changes  This bug is to track the fix also in Bugzilla.

description: I've noticed in many of our features, the epl-v10.html document is the "old style" MS Work document that was "fixed" 4 or 5 years ago by Eclipse Foundation.   The more modern, vendor-neutral, pure HTML version is at available from   http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/epl-v10.html  recommended, I've heard, to use   wget http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/epl-v10.html  and then import that into workspace/git.   (that is, I've heard, using the browser's "save as ..." function will sometimes "mess with" the file or formatting).  Normally, this is probably not an RC1 issue but ... in the event source features have to be changed anyway, I'd recommend updating to the pure HTML version -- mostly to be more "vendor neutral" ... but, in theory, would be more likely to "look the same" in all browsers.
my_mothod: I've noticed in many of our features, the epl-v10.html document is the "old style" MS Work document that was "fixed" 4 or 5 years ago by Eclipse Foundation. (that is, I've heard, using the browser's "save as ..." function will sometimes "mess with" the file or formatting).  Normally, this is probably not an RC1 issue but ... in the event source features have to be changed anyway, I'd recommend updating to the pure HTML version -- mostly to be more "vendor neutral" ... but, in theory, would be more likely to "look the same" in all browsers. many epl-v10.html files in Git repo are "old style" MS Word documents and are not needed minor Releng Platform

description: In order to guarantee a good quality for a contribution (definition of quality to be discussed, cd bug 419746 ), it would help to enforce a review of changes in simrel aggregator using Gerrit. Every contributor would then push change requests on Gerrit, and simrel maintainers would be allowed to discuss of this specific contribution, ask for some improvements, and when the contribution is good enough, merge it into the simrel repo so next builds would use it.  From a contributor POV, it doesn't make a big change, and the discussion with simrel maintainers can give some hints to better understand the aggregation process. For simrel maintainers, it means that they'll have to review incoming contribution, that may take some time (not much as most changes are quite simple and explicit). If we go for it, I guess David would have to choose 2 or 3 people to assist him in the task of reviewing incoming change in Simrel repository.
my_mothod: In order to guarantee a good quality for a contribution (definition of quality to be discussed, cd bug 419746 ), it would help to enforce a review of changes in simrel aggregator using Gerrit. Every contributor would then push change requests on Gerrit, and simrel maintainers would be allowed to discuss of this specific contribution, ask for some improvements, and when the contribution is good enough, merge it into the simrel repo so next builds would use it.  From a contributor POV, it doesn't make a big change, and the discussion with simrel maintainers can give some hints to better understand the aggregation process. For simrel maintainers, it means that they'll have to review incoming contribution, that may take some time (not much as most changes are quite simple and explicit). If we go for it, I guess David would have to choose 2 or 3 people to assist him in the task of reviewing incoming change in Simrel repository. Contribute to simrel with Gerrit enhancement Cross-Project Community
